That which is proposed by Senator Lewis and now by Senator Harradine is not correct. What the Government was proposing, just to refer to a change from three years to four years, will be taken by people as not representing an adequate display of the whole effect of this particular Bill. Therefore, I urge the Government and honourable senators generally to be careful not to allow these questions to be so manipulated as to give unfair support to some aspect of the particular proposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before we go further, I should make clear what the Committee is doing. We are considering proposed new clause 28A, which contains the Attorney- General's amendment No. (10)-to which a number of amendments have been moved in regard to the forms annexure. We have dealt already with the proposed amendments to the simultaneous elections definition. We are now dealing with the proposed amendments in respect of parliamentary terms. One amendment has been moved by Senator Lewis. Two others, by Senators Missen and Harradine, have been foreshadowed. I will call on them if the first amendment fails. The amendment moved by Senator Lewis is now before the Committee. I call Senator Lewis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —First let me respond to Senator Missen's comments about certain senators not doing what their party has decided to do in this matter. For Senator Missen, of all people in this place, to be making such an allegation is utterly incomprehensible. Of all the senators on this side of the chamber who have constantly crossed the floor--
—That is untrue--

—He has done so when we were in government, against the wishes of the government of the day, and when we have been in opposition, against the wishes of the parties in opposition. For Senator Missen to be making this allegation is absolutely beyond me.
—You know that that is untrue.
—He is now alleging it to be untrue but we can show him, from the Journals of the Senate, that time after time he has voted against everyone else in his own Party.
—Even to gag us.

—Indeed, as Senator Walters has said, even to gag us on occasions. He has joined the Democrats and the Labor Party in order to gag his own colleagues. For Senator Missen to be making such allegations in a debate of this nature is absolutely beyond me. Let me go on to say that it is quite clear that around Australia Liberal Party and National Party organisations have decided that they are going to work against these proposals. It is not clear, as Senator Missen would know, where the Liberal Party in any State of the Commonwealth stands in this matter. It is about time he kept his mouth quiet instead of making such allegations against me and the rest of his colleagues, because we will certainly blow them up.

SPEECH.PARA: Having got myself worked up about that, let me turn back to the proposals. The truth is that there are attempts here really to conceal or obscure from the people of Australia the true purpose of this proposal. The Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, last night conceded that there was need for some sort of hiding from the people of the true meaning of these constitutional questions by saying 'Well, the psychology has to be right. We have to phrase the question in a particular way'. What does he mean by all that? It is clear what he means by that. He means that we dare not tell the people that what will happen is that members of the House of Representatives will get a four-year term as a result of this measure and senators will be elected for an eight-year term as a result of this measure because the people will not be happy about that. They will not like seeing that because they are unhappy about politicians. They have a latent insipient dislike of politicians. The plan then is to confuse the people by talking about extending the term of parliament. I suggest to the Senate that that frankly is just an act of dissimulation. By talking about the term of parliament, it is hoped that in some way or other the people will not realise that that will mean extending the terms of service of politicians.

The important point about the proposal to alter the Constitution to extend the duration of the House of Representatives and the terms of the senators is that the question posed by the Government is quite clearly designed to deceive. It is clear by the number of proposed government amendments that there is great concern. The question posed by the Government proposes to extend the maximum life of parliaments from three to four years. I suggest that there is no doubt that that is designed to obscure from the people the inevitable result that members of the House or Representatives will have a maximum term of four years or, as Senator Harradine says, it could be a term of four years plus 120 days and that the fixed terms of senators would go from six to eight years. That is what the Bill says. Senator Missen said that what I am saying is inaccurate but that is what the Bill says. The Bill also has another qualifying section that, in the event of another thing happening with the referendum proposal, a different result would occur in relation to senators so that instead of having an eight year term they would hold office for a period equal to two terms of the House of Representatives. But the fact of the matter is that the Bill provides for terms of senators to go from six to eight years. Unless the Government wishes to extend the question to become a book I suggest to the Government that the proposition I have put fairly places before the people the facts which they ought to be aware of in order to make a decision on this question.

I turn to the next proposal. If my proposed amendment fails for one reason or another, certainly I would support Senator Harradine's proposal. At least that places a greater degree of explanation before the people. Senator Harradine apparently is concerned about the possibility of the term being four years plus 120 days. I suggest to him that that is insignificant and that a term of four years adequately covers a possibility of four years plus 120 days. However, if he experiences some difficulty with that and if my amendment is lost I would certainly fall back on and would accept his proposal to extend the maximum life of the House of Representatives from three to four years and to extend the maximum terms of service of senators from six to eight years. I can see merit in Senator Harradine's proposal, especially in the way he has phrased the question with regard to senators. I point out that if Senator Harradine's proposal also fails to achieve acceptance in the Senate I would fall back on Senator Missen's proposals because I acknowledge that Senator Missen's proposal is certainly a lot better than the Government's proposal.

TALK.START.PARA: —It does not mention the years that they may serve.

—Senator Walters is right. She said that it does not mention the years that they may serve but at least Senator Missen's proposal does talk about the terms of service of senators whereas the Government's proposal does not make any reference to the terms of service of senators at all. In fact it talks about some other, I suggest, dissimulation by talking about the term of the life of the parliament as though it is some marvellous thing that the people of Australia could grasp with both hands. At the same time the people would not understand that they would be giving to those politicians whom they dislike so much a term of service of four years or eight years and fixing up the Parliament in some way. I suggest to the Senate that the way in which the amendments are proposed-they are referred to as forms 1, 2 and 3-is the order in which, to my mind, they carry merit.

— Last night I asked Senator Chipp whether he believed that people, when they read the description put forward by the Government that the term of the Parliament be extended from three to four years, would think of a Senate term of eight years. Senator Chipp acknowledged that people would not automatically think from such a description that the senators they elect would have an eight-year term. It does not matter how the elected senators perform or how they work.
—They do not know that we are here for six years now.

—That is a ridiculous statement. How far does the honourable senator want to extend the term? We are here for six years and I think six years is a long term for the people of Australia to elect senators.
—Senator Coleman says that the people do not know that they give us a term of six years.

—They do not know that they give us a term of six years, but if we intend to extend it to eight years people should realise that. It is absolutely ridiculous for the people of Australia to be hoodwinked by not being told. I ask what Senator Evans is frightened of. Is he really frightened to put on the ballot paper that senators are to be elected for a term of eight years? He knows darn well that the people of Australia would not agree to that. So he is not putting it on the ballot paper. I am disappointed that Senator Chipp, having acknowledged that the proposed wording on the ballot paper does not clearly tell people that the term of senators will be extended from six to eight years, will not join us and vote for our amendment. I think we on this side have agreed now to Senator Harradine's amendment, or a combination of it with Senator Lewis's amendment. I do not mind about the precise detail, so long as the eight- year-term for senators is mentioned. I think it is imperative, honest and just for the people of Australia to be told that they are electing senators for eight years. I am willing to come to any compromise to include that eight years on the ballot paper. I ask again why the Attorney-General, Senator Evans, who has been, in my opinion, underhanded in all the matters concerning the referendum, will not come across and put in the description in the Bill the fact that the Senate' s term will be extended to eight years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened carefully to such contributions as there have been to the debate today and, with the exception of a couple of technical points made by Senator Missen, there has been absolutely nothing new said. There was a long debate on this subject matter last night. It looks as though we are settling in for another long debate this morning. The issues have been canvassed in an exhaustive and exhausting fashion. There are obvious problems about getting universal acceptance for any particular formula which is of less length than that of an essay. The Government, having listened to all the arguments, proposes to stick exactly where it began with the simple, straightforward and non-deceptive proposal in terms of increasing the life of the parliaments.

SPEECH.PARA: The essence of the particular referendum proposal is about extending the life of the Parliament, the life of the Government. That is the attraction of the proposal. That is what appealed to the majority of representatives at the Constitutional Convention which considered this matter. This is the way the matter has been argued in this place and the basis on which it attracted the support of the major parties in this Parliament. Everything else is incidental to that proposal to extend the life of the Government and the Parliament from three years to four years. It is the case, of course, that senators' terms will be affected by this, but that is incidental; it is not the essence of the proposal. It is not as if the electorate will be confronting this proposition about senators' terms for the first time when they get into the ballot box. I doubt very much whether the No case proponents, on the evidence of debate in this chamber, will be quiescent on that subject matter. Equally, it will be the case that full details of the Yes/No proposals will be put in every letter box in the country. Certainly, the question of extended terms for senators will undoubtedly be addressed in both the Yes and No cases. This will not hit anyone by surprise.

What we are simply trying in the formulation of these questions on the ballot paper to ensure is that the average voter whose capacity for absorbing large slabs of written information, particularly when confronted in a ballot box type situation, is limited, will appreciate which proposal it is that he or she is being asked to pass upon and will recognise accordingly what the basic proposal is. It is as simple as that. That has been the argument all the way along. If I thought for a moment, responding to Senator Harradine's remarks last night, that accepting this amendment would ensure that for the remainder of the debate in the referendum campaign we would not be subject on the part of the No case proponents to irrational, emotional argument, to an emotive approach, to allegations of dishonesty on the part of the Government or on the part of those propounding the Yes case, if that were the guarantee, I would be in it like a shot. Of course, the reality of the matter is that the No case proponents will grab at every straw along the way between now and 25 February to disguise the real matters in issue in this campaign, to generate sound, fury and emotion about these issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should take away the opportunity.

—There is no point in capitulating on an issue on which a sound and defensible stand has been taken. There is no question but that. Looking at the way in which the No case proponents on the opposite silde are lined up smirking at the moment, there is no way whatsoever the Government can capitulate. I know honourable senators opposite well enough to know how this case will be conducted on their side. I know that whatever goes on the ballot paper, the character of the arguments that will be put to the people in the public forums and the media with the help of money from Mr Bjelke-Petersen and Mr Gray will be, regrettably, full of arguments that are tendentious in character and not directed to the real issues involved. There is no guarantee whatsoever that the performance will be any different from that. If there were to be a guarantee, if I were to be given undertakings of that kind, from all honourable senators opposite it might make me think otherwise. But I know honourable senators opposite all too well. I do not incorporate you, Mr Chairman , in that suggestion. So I believe the stance that the Government has taken is perfectly defensible. There is no element of deception about it. I propose to insist upon the language originally proposed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Evans thinks he is placating us in any way, I assure him that he has not succeeded. We on this side are not smirking. We know that he has worked a swiftie. We are attempting to alert the people to exactly what he has done and, boy, will we do that. I assure Senator Evans that we will tell the people that for the very first time in Australia's history this Government has allocated money after the Appropriation Bills were passed for one side of the case only. That is the sort of Australian Labor Party democratic system we have in Australia. We will also tell the people that for the first time in Australia's history this Government has changed the ballot paper. It snuck in the change, by attempting to put it in regulations which it would not table. That is the first time that a government has attempted to distort matters in this way. Other governments that have run referendums have at least conducted them honestly. But this Government has made no attempt to do it in an honest fashion.

SPEECH.PARA: It was extremely interesting that Senator Evans said-and I should like the Australian Democrats to listen to this bit-that it would not be the first that the people of Australia have heard about it. He said that we do not need to put in the eight years because there will be a lot of publicity, all the letter- boxing will have been done, the people will know about it, it will not come as a surprise, and there is no need to put it as eight years. That completely undermines his original proposal that there should be a description of each Bill . He said that they need the description of the Bill. Indeed, Senator Chipp said that a description of the Bill is necessary because the people will not know what it is all about. When I pointed out to Senator Chipp that it would be in their letterboxes, he said: 'Who is going to read it?' Now we have Senator Gareth Evans saying: 'This is not coming to the people as a surprise. They will have it in their letterboxes. They will all have read it. There will be a lot of advertising'. He is taking up the exact point that I made. We do not need a description. We do not need the ballot paper to be altered. We need the long title of the Bill only. But he has decided to add a description. He said originally: 'People do not understand it. They will not read the stuff in their letter-boxes. They will not understand the advertising being put across. So we will put a description on the ballot paper'. He cannot have it both ways. Either the people read the stuff in the ballot box or they rely on the description of the Bill. I ask Senator Evans to reply to that criticism that I am making of the speeches that he has made in this place on this issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — A couple of things raised in the debate this morning require clarification or answer. Senator Missen's accusation and complaint about Senator Lewis's amendment and my amendment was that it presupposes the defeat of the first proposition.
—That is right.

—Senator Missen says that that was his situation. The interesting part about it is that the Government's proposal presupposes the support of the first proposition. That is the problem. What we have to address our minds to is a form of words which truly reflects the Bill that has been passed by the Parliament and requires approval of the people. I believe that Senator Lewis's amendment and my amendment, and Senator Missen's amendment, neither presuppose the defeat nor presuppose the support by the people of the first proposition. My difficulty with the situation is that the Government's proposal nominates three to four years. It is quite clear that it is proposing an extension from three years to four years. If it does that, it must then add the extension of terms proposal for the services of senators from six years to eight years.

SPEECH.PARA: I just do not see why the Government, if it wants plain language, if it says that the title of the Bill, which is essentially what Senator Missen is proposing, is not appropriate and not clear enough for the electorate-and, by inference, both Senator Lewis and I accept that now that Senator Durack's amendment has failed-that will obviously mean that Senator Missen's proposal will fail, because essentially Senator Missen's proposal is the title of the Bill. But the Government has, by its actions, defeated that. So now we are therefore left with Senator Lewis's proposal and my proposal.

As mentioned last night, there is just that minor technical problem with Senator Lewis's proposal. Honourable senators would know that the Statute Law ( Miscellaneous Provisions) Act, No. 39 of 1983, deals with the interpretation of when a member is a member. As I said last night, that could be three years and 120 days. It could be of durations of less than that time, too, for the purposes of remuneration of members of the House of Representatives. We are really talking about the term of the House of Representatives, not the term of members of that House. But as Senator Lewis said, that is only a minor point, and my amendment has simply picked that up.
The final point I must raise is that last night the Attorney-General, at the dying stages of the debate, called into question my honesty in-

TALK.START.PARA: —Just your arithmetic, not your honesty.

—I am sorry, my arithmetic-which is often bad, anyhow. He called my arithmetic into question when I indicated that if one were to read the Bill and look at the proposal as is suggested by the Government, one would immediately see that the majority part of the Bill is not referred to in the question; that is, majority by volume. I invite honourable senators to look at the Bill. If I were preparing the No case on this matter, as I am involved in this situation, I would be inclined to just send out the Bill and let the people read it. If they read the Bill they will see that clauses 2 and 3 deal with senators' terms, and that it is only in clause 4 that there are six lines dealing with the duration of the House of Representatives. The rest is dealing with the terms of service of senators and with the interim arrangements for the terms of senators.

SPEECH.PARA: We have reached the stage at which we are either honest or we are not honest. If we are not honest, we will support the proposal put forward by the Attorney- General. Senator Missen's proposal is doomed to failure, because we have voted on that already.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, we have not.
—Well, we have voted on the principle of the issue, which is to have the title of the Bill-
—I have not even moved it yet.
—I thought that last night we voted on the proposal by Senator Durack to have the questions in the terms of the title of the Bill.
—That general direction.
—That has been rejected. Senator Missen's proposal is essentially that.
—No; it is only on this one.

—Therefore, we come back to Senator Lewis's proposal and my proposal. For the sake of the record, I will vote for Senator Lewis's proposal. If that is defeated, naturally I will vote for mine, but I am not sure which way they will be put.

—The only amendment before the Chair at the moment is Senator Lewis 's amendment. If that fails, I will give Senator Missen the opportunity to put his amendment. If that fails, Senator Harradine will be given an opportunity to put his amendment.
—Mr Chairman--
—Fair go! For goodness sake.
—I have not started yet. Senator Chipp should hang on with bated breath. He might learn something.
—He has not spoken yet.

—That is quite right. I have not spoken this morning yet . The Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) says that people will understand the Yes case and the No case because of what they read in stuff posted out to them.
—They won't read it.

—Of course they will not read it. There is no prospect of their having the slightest idea of what they are voting for by reading the question. The Attorney-General knows that. It is very presumptuous of him to suggest for a moment how the No case will conduct its campaign, to suggest that there will be--
—Would you like to tell us?
—If I did, I do not think it would influence the honourable senator, quite frankly.
—It would be a dirty tricks campaign in Western Australia, that is for sure.

—It is so sad for us to see Senator Cook learning so quickly from some of his colleagues. The question that is being put really shows that the Government is being thoroughly dishonest. The Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, knows that the question being put in the words in which it is being presented is not a fair reflection of what is intended. The average person in the community will not understand the implications and ramifications of the question. The Attorney-General knows that. That is why he is spending $1.25m. He said that people are invariably confused by referenda, and he is seeking to confuse them further. He said that the Yes case is always behind the eight ball because people do not understand the question. He is seeking to perpetuate that position. Nobody of normal intelligence reading that question would automatically presume that senators will have a maximum of eight years. That part of the question is as fundamental as the terms of the House of Representatives.
—Or, indeed, even that they would recognise that they might have two terms of the House of Representatives.

—Or that the Senate might have two terms of the House of Representatives, whichever is the case. I am opposed to senators having eight- year terms but I support the House of Representatives having four-year terms in the hope that we might have responsible government in respect of economic considerations. If we want four years for the House of Representatives, we are compelled to support eight years for the Senate. But in my view the whole thrust of the Government's style reeks of absolute dishonesty. The question is not a reflection of what is being put. I support Senator Lewis's proposal and, if that fails, I will support Senator Harradine's and Senator Missen's proposals. but it really matters not how I cast my vote. Ultimately, it depends upon the Australian Democrats. I am quite sure that the Democrats recognise that the question being put to extend the maximum life of Parliament from three to four years does not imply that senators will have eight years. I hope that the Democrats, who have declared that they want these questions put to the people, will want them put truthfully, honestly, fairly and accurately and that they will support any one of the three amendments which make reference to the life of the Senate and the length of terms of senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just one short matter relating to the honesty and integrity of the Government's proposal which I omitted to mention in the course of my somewhat less than totally temperate contribution to the debate earlier this morning. I just want to put on the record that on the authority of both the red and green 'Bibles' that we employ in this place and the other place, I believe it is perfectly proper for the question on the referendum ballot papers relating to the parliamentary terms proposal to refer to the maximum life of parliaments. On page 163 of Odgers Australian Senate Practice it is stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The life of a Parliament . . . is regarded as the duration of the House of Representatives for the time being.
The same point is made by Pettifer in House of Representatives Practice at page 118 and also at page 243 where it is stated:
The Senate . . . does not officially include itself in the description of what constitutes the life of a Parliament.

There is a further reference in Odgers but not in Pettifer to the proposition that parliaments are numbered according to the number of the newly elected House of Representatives. That is in a sense stating the obvious.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are introducing a whole new debate.
—I am not intending to do that, Senator Chipp. Since integrity and honesty keeps being-
—You will bring another five of them to their feet.

—That may be so but I think it is important when the integrity of the Government is being impugned, as Senator Chipp would appreciate , at least to put those propositions on the record without any further argument.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — I wish to respond to that argument. We are simply dealing with how we will put a question to the people which embodies the provisions of the Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) Bill which has passed. The Bill that has passed talks about the duration of the House of Representatives. We are asking the people whether they agree to section 28 of the Constitution being amended. Section 28 of the Constitution deals specifically with the House of Representatives, not with the Parliament. An interesting question came up to which, I think, Senator Missen adverted. I certainly will do so at this stage. The Government presupposes that the first measure will be adopted, that is to say, that the life of the terms of senators will be for two parliaments. Two times four equals eight. What is wrong with putting eight years in here?

—This is the point I do not follow. I want to follow it. If the simultaneous elections measure is passed, surely if there is a premature House of Representatives election the term of the Senate will not be eight years or four years.

—That is right. But that is for the people to decide in respect of the first question, not in respect of this question. People in this chamber, such as Senator Hill, will vote against the first question and vote for the increase in parliamentary terms. So will Senator Crichton-Browne.
—But you must read to the end of the Bill to realise that that is affected by the Opposition.
—That is correct. The Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) Bill states:

SPEECH.PARA: If, at or before the commencement of this section, a law to alter the Constitution entitled ''Constitution Alteration (Simultaneous Elections) 1983'' comes into operation, sections 2 and 3 of this Act shall not take effect.

But we are proposing to place that option before the people. We will place the first option in the first question, surely to goodness. Let us be clear about this. If the Government is not prepared to do that, what it is really saying is that it does not want four-year parliaments. If it does want four-year parliaments and it is dinkum about giving a guarantee to the people that the life of the House of Representatives will go to its full term, of course it is saying that the term of senators will in every case be eight years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —One simple matter that I wish to refer to is, quite frankly, the question of the people of Australia reading the case which is sent out to them by the Australian Electoral Office. It is my belief that a large majority of the people of Australia will read that case. In particular, I suggest that practically in every family in every home around this nation at least one person will sit down and read that paper through. I think any suggestion that it will get tossed in the rubbish bin is a nonsense. The people understand that it is an important document and will read it. But I say also to the Senate that what happens after they receive it is that the questions will start to resolve themselves down to one or the other very simple matter in their minds. They will pick on some aspect which will become the deciding factor in their minds. More often than not that one factor will be the nature of the question. That is why it is important that the question properly reflects the matter which is before the people at the referendum. Last night, Senator Evans said:

SPEECH.PARA: Let me begin at the beginning . . . There is a certain fundamental principle of communication which says if you want to convey a message to anybody, including a voter- . . .
and then he went on and said:
you use concrete language rather than abstract language;

I agree with him. The point is that it is clear that the question is trying to communicate a message to the voter. That is the important thing. The question is very important to the voter because it will convey that message to him. I know, for example, that Senator Chipp said that the Australian Democrats were elected on one occasion to keep them honest. Here is a perfect chance for him and the members of his Party to vote to keep this Government honest in what it will present to the people on this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think the Attorney- General (Senator Gareth Evans) has helped his case by quoting Odgers or any other authority. That seems to fly in the face of and is contradictory to every good reason that he has put to us so far for having these amendments in the first place. It is not a question of whether the wording is technically correct or whether it is legally correct by his own argument. It is really a matter of whether or not the question is put in such a way that it is understood by the ordinary voter to be a reflection of its implications, its ramifications and its ultimate intention. The Government's argument has been that the long title confuses people and does not lead them to the obvious conclusion to decide what they are voting for. That is what we are about today. That is the very argument and the reason that we are having his debate and the reason that the amendments have been put before us.

SPEECH.PARA: I find it very confusing to follow the Attorney-General's argument that, technically he is correct and, on the other hand, he says being technically correct is not the argument; the argument is to put the proposals in such a form that they can be understood by the people. It is clear to everybody in this chamber who is being honest with himself that the question as it is put at the present time will not be understood by the great majority of the voters as meaning a maximum term of eight years for senators. I have no doubt that that is the reason for the Government spending $1.25m. I have no doubt that that is the reason that part of the $1.25m is being spent on surveys. The surveys are intended to find out what the public understands and what it does not understand . That will manifest itself in the television, newspaper and radio commercials for which the taxpayers are paying.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Lewis's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed new clause 28A, proposed Forms 1, 2, and 3, leave out 'To extend the maximum life of Parliaments from 3 to 4 years' (wherever occurring), insert 'To extend the maximum duration of the House of Representatives and the terms of service of senators'.

I abstained from the last vote of the Committee because, although I think the amendment was a better proposition than the Government's proposition, as the Government's proposition can well be claimed to be deceptive because it does not set out anything about the Senate, it was still an inaccurate description of it. That is why I was opposed to it.

I have not sought leave to make a personal explanation in regard to the attack which Senator Lewis made on me a little earlier this morning. I resent it very bitterly and I regard it as most offensive, coming from a colleague. It is totally inaccurate. I will not go through my record in this Parliament to justify my position; I do not have to justify it to Senator Lewis. He well knows that on this subject I have defended him and others who are indeed dissidents in the Opposition parties on the subject of the referendum matters. I have defended their right to take that stand. He probably knows that I have already done that. I object to the bullying tone in which he endeavoured to tell me that I should not speak on these matters and cannot take a view because I have on some occasions voted differently either from our previous Government or from the Opposition's stand on very rare occasions. I have done so with restraint. I just say that I resent very much the abusive attack which he made on me this morning, which was totally inaccurate. I leave it at that.

I have endeavoured in this matter to take a view on this question which I hope is a fair view. I still plead to the Government to recognise that these aspects wil be used as red herrings against it if it does not make a reference in the question to the extension of the Senate term. The last clause of the Constitution Alteration (Parliamenary Terms) Bill makes it clear that the six- year to eight-year term change does not operate if the first referendum question , on simultaneous elections, is passed. So, if we are to spell out these facts, we have to spell out not only the six-year to eight-year term but also the fact that the period of service of a senator may be two terms of the parliament if the first proposal is passed. We cannot have the question put before the people in the form of an essay. We must have reference to these things. I hope my amendment, with the addition to the long title of the word which Senator Harradine recognises is correct-the 'maximum' duration-is the way in which the question will be expressed.

I believe that is a fair raising of the question and an expression of it in regard to the matters to be put before the people. I cannot support those wordings which inaccurately describe the question, which unfortunately is what the motions of Senator Lewis and Senator Harradine do. I cannot support the Government's proposal which leaves it out altogether. I do hope that the Committee will adopt that reasonable course and that it will therefore support the amendment I have moved which, as I say, but for one word is exactly the long title of the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I propose to the Committee that Senator Harradine's amendment should be considered before the amendment moved by Senator Missen. It seems to me that the fall back position of some honourable senators in the Committee is that they would prefer Senator Harradine's amendment, and putting Senator Missen's amendment first will force us to vote against that amendment in the hope that Senator Harradine's amendment will get up. Putting Senator Missen's amendment after Senator Harradine's amendment would, I think, suit the purposes of the Committee.

—The reason I put them in the order I did is that that is the order in which they were received by the Chair. Only if Senator Missen is prepared to withdraw his amendment for the moment, can we follow that procedure.
—I withdraw my amendment, at the moment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed new clause 28A, proposed Forms 1, 2 and 3, leave out 'To extend the maximum life of Parliaments from 3 to 4 years' (wherever occurring), insert 'To extend the maximum life of the House of Representatives from 3 to 4 years and to extend the maximum term of service of senators from 6 to 8 years'.

Frankly, Mr Chairman, I would rather have Senator Missen's proposal put first but, seeing that everyone wants my proposal to go up, I might as well move it; and I have done so. In fact, this proposal comes at a place where people have to face the truth. In the interests of truth, either we accept this proposition or we adopt the Government's proposal. As I understand it, the Australian Democrats are voting against Senator Missen's proposal. They voted against that sort of proposal last night, from Senator Durack, which essentially was a proposal to put the question to the people in the form of the title of the Bill. The Democrats are going to oppose Senator Missen's proposal. Therefore if they and the Committee reject this proposal, they will be allowing the Government's proposal to go to the people; and the Government's proposal is deceptive. There is no doubt about that. If one looks at the Bill which is to go as a question to the people of Australia, to leave out any reference in the title to increasing the term of service of senators is deceptive. There is absolutely no doubt about that.

Let everybody be aware of what they are doing. If we are to keep them honest, we should at least keep them honest on a very major issue such as an alteration to the Constitution. That is the question; and the responsibility is heavily upon those who vote against this proposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall endeavour to be brief, but before I turn to this question I must say-I do not want to continue on endlessly-that in regard to Senator Missen's comments it is my belief that a fair reading of today 's Hansard and a proper analysis of the Journals of the Senate will support the contentions that I made. As to this matter, I believe we are involved in a charade. Those of us who have taken great interest in these constitutional referendum proposals were led to believe, by discussions which took place outside this chamber, that the honourable senators who were in the Opposition area-in other words, the Australian Democrat senators-were going to give some fair and proper analysis of the arguments presented and the proposals presented because our proposals had not previously been considered by the Government when it came down with its regulation. It is clear that that is not going to happen and that it is a charade. I suggest that the debate be wound up and that we get on with the vote.

—I did not want to contribute to what I believe has become a very poor debate in many ways, but we have had a series of accusations of bad faith all around. I believe the various people who have contributed to this debate have all done so on the basis that the propositions they have put forward most accurately represent what this constitutional question was all about. Undoubtedly there will be divergent views about that matter. For example, I personally am opposed to this referendum question, but I believe one must try to transcend one's views and try to get a reasonable and fair proposition. In looking at the ones we have before us I must admit that I find them all, in various ways, fair and reasonable representations of what it is that we are on about, and that is essentially the absurd problem of having a Committee debate when such debate ought to have been had elsewhere. We really cannot get to a reasonable and sensible conclusion in this type of atmosphere in this Committee. Therefore I must admit that personally I am drawn to Senator Missen's proposal, which seems to me to be a fair and reasonable representation of the situation, but the Government's proposition is technically correct. In that case it seems that the choice which one is forced to make between one and the other is really quite invidious. I am still interested as to what the Government's response might be to Senator Missen's proposal, but at this time we are discussing Senator Harradine's proposal. I indicate that we will not be supporting it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — That was a most amazing contribution--
—Don't you think you have spoken enough on this?

—No. I want to make the point that it is all very well for Senator Macklin piously to say that the best thing would have been to have consultations about it. The Australian Democrats were consulted by the Attorney- General (Senator Gareth Evans). Those who oppose the proposition were not. It is all very well to come in here and say: 'Oh, yes, all of these questions are matters which are very relevant and very real and the unfortunate part about it is that there were no consultations'. They were consulted; I was not. Those of us who had the legal responsibility of preparing the No case were not in fact consulted; and that is a disgrace. Senator Macklin should have been condemning the Government, before it brought these matters before the Parliament, for not in fact doing the right and fair thing.
—I said that. Go and look at the Hansard record.

—Excuse me. What Senator Macklin said was that there should have been consultations. What in fact happened was that the Attorney-General contacted the Democrats and got the agreement of the Democrats to these proposals so that they could go into the regulations. That is what the Government did. In any event it was inconsistent with section 128 of the Constitution. That is point number one. Now we come to point number two. Senator Macklin said two things after that: He favours Senator Missen's proposal and he believes the Government's proposal is technically correct. Could I just repeat that? This is a very important aspect--
—Every time you get up you say the same thing.
—I am not saying--
—Tedious and tiresome.

—Mr Chairman, I was finished with this debate until Senator Macklin made comments which required response. The two points that he made were that he personally favoured Senator Missen's proposal and that he believed the Government's proposal was technically correct. Those two statements are mutually exclusive because Senator Missen's proposal talks about the terms of service of senators. The Government's proposal does not. What is the definition of ' technically correct' in this context? The terms to be put forward to the people must surely reflect what is contained in the legislation in the Referendum ( Constitution Alteration) Act. Clearly if Senator Missen is right, Senator Evans is wrong. Clearly Senator Missen's proposal includes what the Bill says. It talks about the extension of the maximum terms of service of senators. All that my proposal which is now before us and which is in plain language-if Senator Evans is technically correct on the extension of terms of members of the House of Representatives from three to four years-does is extend the maximum term of senators from six to eight years. Now under those criteria Senator Macklin and the other Democrats must support my proposition. On this occasion, on a matter of major importance, of constitutional importance, the Government must be kept honest.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Harradine's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed new clause 28A, proposed Forms 1, 2 and 3, leave out 'To extend the maximum life of Parliaments from 3 to 4 years' (wherever occurring), insert 'To extend the maximum duration of the House of Representatives and the terms of service of senators'.

I have already spoken to the amendment. I do not intend to say anything further except to urge, in view of the intransigence of the Government, which I think is foolish, the Australian Democrats in particular to put into this question a statement which is a reasonable and fair statement and one which will not be easily controverted by irrelevancies in the campaign that goes on. I very much urge the Australian Democrats to support this amendment. I hope the Opposition will support the amendment as a fair statement of the proposition.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Missen's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed new clause 28A, proposed Forms 1, 2 and 3, leave out 'To enable the Commonwealth and States to refer powers to each other by mutual agreement.' ( wherever occurring), insert 'To enable the Commonwealth and States unilaterally to refer powers to each other.'.
My amendment seeks to change the Government's description of the interchange of powers. The wording that the Government proposes to use on the ballot paper is:
INTERCHANGE OF POWERS: To enable the Commonwealth and States to refer powers to each other by mutual agreement.

That is completely inaccurate. There is nothing in the Bill that says a State must agree before the Commonwealth refers powers to it. There is nothing in the Bill that says the Commonwealth must agree before a State refers powers to it. That wording is a complete distortion of the Bill. It is not accurate.

I have already discussed this matter with the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) who has told me that I am right, that technically I am correct, but that in practice, of course, that would not happen. I do not believe that the Attorney is such an oracle that he is able to say what will happen in future. We cannot describe what is in a Bill on the basis of what the Attorney thinks will or should happen. As has already agreed that the words 'mutual agreement' are not technically right, my amendment seeks to substitute the following words: 'To enable the Commonwealth and States unilaterally to refer powers to each other'. I would like the Attorney to take note of the length of time I have spoken on this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the force of what Senator Walters is saying about the technical force and effect of the Bill because if the States want to refer a power to the Commonwealth there has to be, as a technical legal matter, either a request or a form of consent by the Commonwealth to that. The justification for putting it in these terms is, as Senator Walters in fact foreshadows, a practical matter. The States will never be interested in going to the trouble of referring powers unless there is some request or clear indication by the Commonwealth that the power is both sought and will be exercised. The endeavour here is to make absolutely clear, in the event that people might otherwise be in some doubt about it, that this is a purely voluntary machinery measure which does not in any way compel anybody to do anything.

SPEECH.PARA: It may be that on reflection there is a better form of words to convey that particular flavour. I do not think, with the utmost respect to Senator Walters, that the word 'unilaterally' helps us much. I do not think there are many people in the community, apart from perhaps Senator Walters and those of us here, who feel entirely comfortable with words like 'unilaterally' in terms of understanding precisely what they mean and what is intended. I may be doing a disservice to the average--

TALK.START.PARA: —More people would understand that word than would understand ' tendentious'.

—Yes, but then again I was employing that word only today. I would not use an expression like that when the proceedings were being broadcast. But in this chamber, I think on a non-broadcast day, 'tendentious' suits the mood perfectly. 'Unilaterally' I think is an inappropriate and unhelpful word and in fact it throws rather much of the emphasis totally in the other direction, which was no doubt the thought that Senator Walters had in mind when she moved her amendment. Perhaps we can reach some accommodation here. I accept the proposition that 'mutual agreement' is perhaps putting it too highly. It is also tautological. If it is an agreement one does not need the word ' mutual' as well. That is another point that has been made to me. I would be prepared, accordingly, to delete the words 'by mutual agreement' at the end of this question and to substitute the word 'voluntarily' earlier on so that the question would read as follows: 'To enable the Commonwealth and the States voluntarily to refer powers to each other'. I believe that accurately captures exactly the flavour of this legislation. It removes the technical objection which Senator Walters, with her usual perspicacity, has pointed out to me and it ought to be acceptable all round the chamber.

—I wish to speak briefly on this matter. For the reasons that have been given, I do not think the Government's proposal is an accurate statement. The proposal emphasises mutuality. I imagine, of course, that there would be a lot of agreement in regard to the exchange of powers between the States and the Commonwealth. There would be an interchange of powers . But that is not the essential nature of the legislation. I also do not think the word 'unilaterally', as proposed by Senator Walters, is also the essential nature of it. I go back to the long title. After what has happened this morning I do not think I have any faith left in the ability of argument in this place to get anywhere on this matter. Obviously, there is a longstanding arrangement between the Australian Democrats and the Government to support various proposals . Irrespective of their own views, the Democrats are sticking with this arrangement. I will not move an amendment but I suggest that we should have stuck with the long title, perhaps altering a word here or there. The long title states: 'An Act to alter the Constitution with respect to the inter-change of powers between the Commonwealth Parliament and the State Parliaments'. That wording is all right but we could alter the wording to read: 'to facilitate the inter-change of powers' because there is already an existing power for the States to deal with the interchange. However, there are defects and the Commonwealth has no power in this respect at the moment. As I said, we should have stuck to the long title, or the long title with a slight variation, 'to facilitate' the interchange of powers. I think that would be the correct way of proceeding, because the situation would not be pushed either way. If we say the arrangement is mutual we are moving in the Yes direction. We emphasise the fact that the arrangement must be by agreement. To say it is unilateral suggests that one is forcing power on the other. I think that in either way we would be pushing the Yes or No case. I have endeavoured to suggest that there is a middle and sensible course and that the long title pretty well has it right. I just regret that reason makes it not likely to be worth while my moving any amendment .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — It is most interesting, as Senator Missen has said, that there is obviously a long-standing agreement between the Australian Democrats and the Government in regard to the wording to be put to the people. No matter what honourable senators say in this chamber the situation will not change, apart from the adoption of a simple suggestion which again does not reflect what is contained in the Bill. The Bill to which we are referring is the Constitution Alteration (Inter-change of Powers) Bill 1983. Let us say that the Commonwealth Government wished to cede its powers to the States in relation to the collection of sales tax. Although the States may not want those powers the Commonwealth, under this proposal, could do that.

SPEECH.PARA: That is not a voluntary act on the part of the States. It is not an interchange of power. An interchange of gifts denotes sending and accepting; it is in the nature of offering and accepting. That is what 'voluntary' means. In fact, the Commonwealth, if it so desires, can cede its powers in respect of certain issues -though certainly not on foreign affairs and such matters-to the States, whether the States like it or not. Senator Missen has made the point that, if anything, in this particular matter there may be a question concerning the title of the Bill. Unfortunately we did not discuss the title of the Bill, but it does not reflect-

TALK.START.PARA: —It is just not descriptive.
—It does not reflect what the Commonwealth could do under this proposal, if accepted.
—It is more accurate than what is here, though.
—I believe that what Senator Walters is putting forward is more accurate than all of them. It is a question of unilateral transfer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly do not agree with the amendment proposed by Senator Gareth Evans. It does not make any difference, none at all. As far as I am concerned, he can go back to his use of the term 'mutual agreement' because the use of the word 'voluntarily' just does not make any difference. It does not express the fact that the interchange of powers is undertaken unilaterally. The amendment does not help me in any way.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Delete the expression 'by mutual agreement' and add the word 'voluntarily' before the expression 'to refer powers'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have only one thing to say. What has occurred does disappoint me because when I showed that provision to Senator Macklin he said: 'It is by mutual agreement; they must both agree'. I said: 'No, I discussed that with the Attorney and he told me that he agreed that technically that was not so'. Senator Macklin then said: 'Oh well, if so I could be supporting your amendment. We will give it some thought'. But obviously the agreement was made outside this chamber, not after listening to the debate. The honourable senator did not listen to my remarks on this matter. He had already come to an agreement with the Government and it seems to me to be quite futile to go on debating in this place if deals are being made all the time, with no true appreciation of the debate that goes on in the chamber.
— The discussion that was had in relation to the amendment just moved by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) took place in this chamber. In fact, it took place only a short time ago.
—Certainly not publicly.

—If Senator Walters will just listen she might learn something. I raised with the Attorney Senator Walters's proposition about the use of the words 'mutual agreement' and said that her point seemed to us to be correct; that it would not be possible to support the terms as set out because they were not technically correct. That was accepted by the Attorney. In the course of discussion, the Attorney then suggested that this was the case and that to meet Senator Walter's objection the word 'voluntarily' could be inserted. It seemed to us that that did meet Senator Walters's proposition and therefore we were in agreement with the Government on that issue. I would hope that if honourable senators wish to make personal accusations they will make them personally and go outside this chamber to do so.

—I am not suggesting for one moment that Senator Macklin went outside the chamber, but an agreement was made between him and the Government on this particular issue without its being debated in this chamber.
—Could we know what is the wording of the amendment?
—In the third proposal, relating to the interchange of powers, the proposal is to delete the words 'mutual agreement' and insert before the words ' to refer' the word 'voluntarily'.

— I wish to refer to something that Senator Macklin has just mentioned. In my previous contribution to this debate I referred directly to the points that he made in his contribution. It is clear, evident and recognised by all honourable senators that discussions took place outside this chamber prior to these matters being dealt with and debated here; that an agreement had been made between the Democrats and the Government without the benefit of either having heard the points to be made in this debate.
—That discussion was in the context of the regulation. It takes place outside the chamber anyway. That is a fair point, is it not? You are talking about in the context of the regulations?
—In the context of the regulations, I thank the Attorney very much.
—That was weeks ago.
—I am glad that that is now officially on the record.
—It has always been on the record.
—It has been on the record. I had discussions with the Opposition too.
—The Attorney-General has had no discussion as he would surely , given his position--

—Because the Democrats were worthy guardians, if you like, of the national interest in this respect because they do not support all the cases. They do not support the Yes case on every proposal, as they have made very clear.
—Order! There are too many interjections. Senator Harradine has the call.

—The point that I am making, and Senator Evans has now made it , is that the arrangement had been made, not between him as the Attorney-General and those who have the legal responsibility for preparing the No case, namely, those senators and members who voted against the third reading of these referenda Bills, but with other persons. As has been clearly stated, that is an inappropriate and unfair way of dealing with it. In general, it is quite disconcerting to me to feel that fix-ups and arrangements can be made on all sorts of issues before a matter is finally determined in this place, particularly on questions of this nature. We are to have before us a number of other pieces of legislation which impinge on areas of cross-party concern. Will the Government attempt to get the agreement of the Democrats either to gag debate in respect of those issues, or have matters cut and dried before they come into the chamber-without benefit of debate? No reflection is being made on anyone personally. I referred specifically to the matters that Senator Macklin raised. I now express my deep concern that it appears that the Australian Democrats do, and that they are prepared to, come to agreement with the Government on matters of not only cross-party concern but also very grave concern to individual honourable senators and not hear debate in this chamber before they make their decisions.

—I thought I had finished speaking in the debate on the Referendum (Constitution Alteration) Amendment Bill 1983. As I said earlier I did not propose to take any further part in this charade which is all this whole proposal has been over the past three days. We now discover, on the third day of debating this Bill, that we have been involved in a charade. I did not intend to take any further part in this debate until I heard the Attorney- General (Senator Gareth Evans) of this nation describe the Australian Democrats as-I cannot remember the words--
—The guardians.
—He described them as 'the guardians of this nation' or similar words, as Hansard will record.
—The guardians of the national interest.

—'The guardians of the national interest' were the words used by the Attorney-General, as Hansard will record. I will bet my bottom dollar that the Attorney-General lives to regret ever saying that. I bet at some stage in the future he ultimately rejects as totally false his claim that the Australian Democrats are 'the guardians of the national interest'. In this debate, the Australian Democrats have shown themselves as the pawns of the Government. They have been described as the limpid fish of the Australian Labor Party and properly so. Since the time they have been in this Parliament they have voted, acted and worked in conjunction with the Australian Labor Party. It is about time the people of this nation became aware of what the Australian Democrats are all about. There is no doubt that a vote for the Democrats is a vote for the ALP .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) said all the way through this debate, when we accused him of conferring only with the Australian Democrats, that he also conferred with the Opposition. Is he so ignorant that he does not realise that the people who are opposed to these referenda are those honourable senators who voted against the various questions put in relation to the Constitution? If the Attorney-General is not aware of that it is about time he was made aware of it because the legislation states that the people who voted against the various questions that the Government proposes to put at the referendum are the people who must prepare the No case that is to be distributed. The Attorney-General made sure that he conferred with the Australian Democrats because he wanted their votes, nothing else. Very simply, he wanted their votes. It did not matter one iota because the Democrats voted in favour of the questions relating to the Constitution. The Australian Democrats, therefore, will play no part in drafting the No case. Legally, they are unable to play any part because they supported the Government and voted for the legislation. For Senator Gareth Evans to keep saying that he did confer with us all is absolutely untrue. There is no truth in that statement at all! He knows that. He is deliberately stating as facts arguments that are not true.

SPEECH.PARA: I feel, I suppose, very similar to the way in which Senator Lewis, who has just spoken, feels. The statement made by the Attorney that the Democrats are the guardians of the national interest is similar to many other statements that the Attorney has made off the top of his head. For example, he said: 'Please, your Honour, I thought the spy flights over Tasmania were a good thing at the time. I have since re-thought the matter and have decided that it was not such a good idea'. Senator Robert Ray made a very good interjection the other day when the Attorney was saying that he had not quite said what appeared in Hansard. I thought Senator Robert Ray's interjection was very timely when he said: 'Oh, haven't you read the amended Hansard?' We even have the Attorney's own colleagues pointing out that the Attorney amends the Hansard record. I think that the Attorney-General does get a little carried away and makes numerous comments off the top of his head when he is just being verbose.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you do what Senator Lewis did and leave? Go on, storm out.

—I do not intend to storm out, Senator. I am afraid that the Attorney will have to put up with my being here for quite a while yet. If Senator Gareth Evans continues with his policy in relation to the description of each Bill and does not accept the suggestion-he has not accepted it so far-made by the whole of the Opposition that we go back to the original ballot paper, there is very little left I can say because the Attorney has already done a deal with the Australian Democrats. The Australian Democrats are supporting the Government. I will not say any more. The Democrats are not listening and there is very little point in going any further.

—I wish to refer only briefly to the points raised by Senator Lewis. As Senator Lewis is a member of the Opposition, I presume he may well have been speaking on behalf of the Opposition. I would certainly like to hear from the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) or the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Senator Durack) in relation to the points raised by Senator Lewis. If Senator Lewis wishes to take that particular stance, we will certainly accommodate the Opposition by in fact not discussing matters with its members, if that is what it wants. I remind Senator Lewis, who sits on the back bench and does not frequently involve himself in legislation, that it is an important part of the process of legislation that discussions be held with all parties. We engage in such discusions at all times. If the Opposition wishes to exclude itself from such discussions, I would be happy to accommodate it. I would save a hell of a lot of time.
—He was not speaking for the Opposition; he was speaking for himself.

—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition is here. I want to hear from him whether he accepts what Senator Lewis said. If he does accept what Senator Lewis said, I, for one, will not be discussing matters in future with anybody from the Opposition. In fact only about 10 minutes ago I was holding discussions with Senator Peter Baume on the States grants legislation. I will refuse in future to do anything of the kind.

—I guess I ought to put it on the record, as Hansard does not quite catch the nuances of these things, that there was just a slight touch of irony about my statement that the Australian Democrats were the guardians of the national interest but it was not entirely--
—Are you going to change Hansard?

—No. I am not going to change Hansard because I was making a genuine point in the context in which it appears. I was making a genuine point , that is, that my discussion with Senator Macklin, on behalf of the Australian Democrats-I held a similar discussion, of course, with Senator Durack but I cannot be held to account if Senator Durack does not choose to communicate with his own back bench in this respect because it was certainly my intention and hope that he would-occurred in the context of an attempt to get some agreed language between all the parties that would be acceptable. The discussion took place in the context of the proposals to promulgate regulations in this respect. There was, of course, an opportunity for parliamentary debate, had the matters worked out that way, in relation to those regulations. The position that was taken by the Democrats-I do not think Senator Macklin will mind my saying this- was that they agreed with the basic aim that I was endeavouring to promote, that is, to get some simplified and more concrete language and not the abstract and impenetrable language of the existing long titles. But the point was put to me very forcefully by the Democrats, who were and are divided themselves as to their views about the merits of these various proposals, that the language employed had to be fair, had to be neutral as between the competing cases and could not have any whiff of campaigning about it. That point was put to me very strenuously by Senator Macklin. I readily acceded to it. The attempt all along has been to try to find language that accommodates that need. It was at Senator Macklin's suggestion, for example, in relation to the first item dealing with simultaneous elections, that the reference was added to the variation of the terms of senators which was not in the long title.
—Why was it not added to the second?

—All these accusations of bad faith and lack of integrity, apart from being poor debating points to make in the context of the debate, are getting very tiresome because they are quite unfounded. Indeed, they are becoming quite intolerable. I hope it will not be necessary for me to say anything more than that in this debate. I put on the record the nature and character of that exchange which was an entirely honourable one between all the parties concerned.

—I speak only in relation to the statements made by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) about the so- called consultation he had with me. I do not know whether I will be allowed to comment at this stage. If I do not do so now, I will have to make a personal explanation. I think the record needs to be put straight. Senator Evans came to see me in my office a day or two before 11 November. I do not recall which day it was, but it certainly was only a day or two before that date. He put to me the proposition which he had about making regulations. I do not understand whether regulations were to be made, but in some way a change was to be made in the questions to be put at the referendum. When he saw me he had obviously had very full negotiations with the Australian Democrats and it appeared as though agreement had been reached with them. I told him that one of the difficulties I had in negotiating on the matter was that a large number of honourable senators on the Opposition side opposed the referendums and that I could not speak for them.
—I understood that.
—Senator Evans did not tell the Committee that. He gave the impression that I was in some way at fault. I want to get the record straight.
—It is your own backbenchers who say you did not consult them.

—I told Senator Evans that I could not speak for the Opposition backbenchers on this matter and that he ought to consult them. As he had asked me for the official Opposition view, I told him that I would take the matter to the shadow Cabinet and obtain its reaction. I agree with Senator Evans that I was not enthusiastic about the proposal and that I preferred the long title. Perhaps Senator Evans can recall whether we had that conversation one day or two days before 11 November. I am not sure of the date, but my submission to the shadow Cabinet on the matter is dated 11 November. The shadow Cabinet was to meet on the following Monday. It did so and dealt with my submission then. I replied to the Attorney-General on 15 November telling him the official Opposition view. I told him that I could convey only the official Opposition view to the Attorney-General and that I could not speak for those who supported the No case. To my utter astonishment, I learnt that the regulations were in fact made on 11 November, a day or two after I had been first approached and the day on which I prepared my submission for the views of the Opposition to be obtained.

—I want to explain something to the Committee. It may seem that this discussion is out of order, but, in fact, it concerns negotiations that led to the preparation of the wording of these parts of the Bill and it is relevant to their consideration; therefore, this discussion is in order. How long the Committee wishes it to continue is in its hands.

—I think Senator Durack's remarks clarify the situation as I understand it. I am surprised that Senator Evans did not take up Senator Durack's suggestion to approach those members who have the legal responsibility to make up the No case, but he obviously had no intention of doing so. As Senator Durack said, the Attorney-General made the regulations without even bothering to table them. Eventually, we found that regulations had been made and had been in force for some time and that the Attorney had not even tabled them in this place. He did not table them until forced to do so by questions put to him.
—Come on! I have explained that. Behave yourself. I have explained that properly.

—Senator Evans should not tell me to behave myself. He is at risk in the community because of the underhand way in which the Government has handled the referendum proposal. I advise the Attorney to be very careful of his behaviour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am concerned that people such as Senator Evans and Senator Macklin are taking umbrage at what is being suggested and are making accusations of bad faith. No accusations of bad faith have been made, at least not by me. The fact that discussions have taken place between the Government and the Australian Democrats is not disconcerting. I am not concerned about that. As somebody by way of sotto voce interjection said, in case it was not caught up by Hansard, this happens all the time. Discussions between various people outside the Parliament happen all the time; but there are two things about the matter which I find disconcerting. One is that discussions on matters of this nature are highly selective and not undertaken with persons who have the legal responsibility to prepare the No case. The other disconcerting aspect is that those discussions come to conclusions which are then forced upon us and no chance is therefore given for a receptive audience for arguments which may be advanced in the Parliament. If discussions take place, well and good; but it should be ensured that all the points are discussed. It should not be assumed that those points are totally outlined until such time as the debate takes place in this Parliament. Otherwise, the whole show is a charade, as Senator Lewis said.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —We now turn to the fourth amendment to Government amendment (9), on the advisory jurisdiction of the High Court. There are two foreshadowed amendments. I call Senator Walters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Government's description on the ballot paper proposed to be used for the referendum is again very far from accurate. It is proposed that the description of the legislation on the advisory jurisdiction of the High Court read:

SPEECH.PARA: To enable the Commonwealth, the States and the Northern Territory more easily to obtain from the High Court its views on certain constitutional questions.

We have debated the Constitution Alteration (Advisory Jurisdiction of High Court ) Bill in this place. I do not agree with the Bill, obviously. I voted against its being put to the people. I believe the long title is the description we should use, but as that has already been defeated--

TALK.START.PARA: —No. Senator Harradine has an amendment to that.
—The Opposition put it and it has already been defeated. I now propose that if we have to describe this Bill, that description should be in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: To give power to the Commonwealth, State and Northern Territory Governments to seek advice from the High Court as to the full extent of their powers under the Constitution.
That is exactly what it is all about.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not true.

—What absolute rubbish! What the Government is attempting to do is what it did in Tasmania-use the external affairs powers. What it is doing now is to go to the High Court of Australia and seek its advice as to the full extent of its powers under the Constitution. How much further can we go in taking away the States' rights? The Government is proposing that a question be put to the people, and not giving the reasons for its judicial powers. The true reason is as I have already stated.

SPEECH.PARA: I will not take up the Committee's time. We all know very well what the Government is proposing. We all know very well that the description of the Bill that was agreed to between the Australian Democrats and the Government is not accurate. We know very well that the Government is asking the High Court to give it information as to how it can use its powers to the full extent against the States, because we also know that the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has stated publicly that there is no reason for State governments and that there should be a central government only in Australia. We know very well and understand completely that the Government is attempting to make a central government for Australia and to take away the States' rights completely.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is using the High Court as a political tool.
—As Senator Jessop has said, it is using the High Court as a political tool to enable it to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to oppose Senator Walters's amendment, for obvious reasons. She is not coming to grips with the subject matter of this proposal at all, but just advancing another and very familiar ramp of her own. The simplest way of describing how Senator Walters's own account of this is itself misleading is to point out that a variety of matters, for example, interpretation of sections 44, 45 and 57 of the Constitution, are expressly vested in the jurisdiction of the High Court of Australia by this measure, and those provisions have nothing whatsoever to do with the powers vis-a-vis each other of the Commonwealth or the States. The reference to certain constitutional questions is deliberate, in order to cover the whole range of matters that are within the scope of the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: To anticipate Senator Harradine's objection, I just say that the whole problem was to try to get away from the use of a technical expression such as 'advisory jurisdiction'. 'Advisory' is understandable enough, but 'jurisdiction' is another mumbo-jumbo lawyer's word so far as the average Australia voter is concerned. What we are trying to do is simply find some neutral, concrete language to explain as precisely as possible what this Bill is about. There is no attempt to mislead and no attempt to be deceptive. Certainly there is no question of us accommodating the kind of proposition that Senator Walters is advancing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I regret to hear what the Attorney-General has said. I do not think that the Government's proposal is a correct description of it. It is a long description about enabling the Government more easily to obtain views from the High Court of Australia. It certainly does that in a sense, but it is not 'more easily'. The power does not exist at the moment; that is the point. There is no such power at the moment to obtain an advisory opinion. For years now the terms 'advisory opinion' and 'advisory jurisdiction' have been known and have been a matter of controversy. The Senate brought down a report on advisory opinions. It has been discussed in the Constitutional Convention and it is known as an expression in that way. That is what the Bill is about. Its title is 'Constitution Alteration (Advisory Jurisdiction of the High Court) Bill'. Once again, I say that we should be sticking to the long title. That will be understood and vigorously argued. What the Attorney-General says is not right, because it is not just 'more easily'. It is creating a new jurisdiction which does not exist at present in the High Court. But likewise, Senator Walters's description is also inaccurate. One despairs at the attempts to push things one way or another according to different views on these matters.
—Hear, hear!
—Senator Walters had better stop saying 'Hear, hear'.

SPEECH.PARA: Progress reported.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.
