TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, as I understand it, there is no opposition to this measure, and we want to get it through before the adjournment. It is to increase the number in the Public Accounts Committee. It is a bipartisan measure. Perhaps that could be indicated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the Public Accounts Committee Amendment Bill 1983. We wish it a speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to the Opposition for its support.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its reamining stages without amendment or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 1 December 1983, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bills be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Primmer Sen C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like many other senators, I have long held very strong reservations about the propriety and competence of Australia's intelligence establishment. Whilst initially supporting the Hawke Government's ' steady as she goes' policy of hastening slowly and getting rid of poor performers and corrupt operators at the top of the bureaucracy, I now believe that events have proved that the Government and the nation would have been better served by an early wielding of the axe.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators are very well aware of my view that the Department of Foreign Affairs is one example. I intend further broadening my allegations against the hierarchy there in the very near future. But today I intend to concentrate on one area of the intelligence community. I believe that I am voicing the views of many honourable senators and colleagues in another place and, indeed, the views of a majority of Australians when I say, admittedly with the benefit of hindsight, that the Government erred badly in not putting the cleaners right through the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation as soon as it came into office. Its failure to do so has resulted in the Government being implicated in the sustained persecution of two loyal and long-serving stalwarts of the Labor movement. I refer, of course, to David Combe and Mick Young. In implicating the Government, ASIO has demonstrated a blend of criminal cunning and sheer bumbledom which would make Laurel and Hardy blush. Its head, Harvey Barnett, learnt his stuff during the many years he spent in the Australian Secret Intelligence Service, and it is about ASIS that I shall speak today.

ASIS is a mysterious body which does not appear in the telephone book. By repute, its activities seem to fall somewhere between hard line Central Intelligence Agency and Dad's Army or Fawlty Towers. We had a stunning example of its capacity in Melbourne last week, and I only trust that Premier John Cain will put those lunatics where they belong. ASIS is modelled after the British equivalent, the Secret Intelligence Service and perhaps falls into the British mould all too clearly. ASIS comes under the control of Bill Hayden, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, and I want it to be clearly understood that I would have conveyed to him what I am about to expose to the Parliament had his door not been closed to me on the issue of bureaucratic corruption. It is a truism that an organisation can be only as good as the man who runs it. Since 1981 ASIS has been headed by a Mr John Edmund Ryan, OBE, who comes from the Foreign Affairs Department stable. On the basis of information made available to me from a number of sources, which have been carefully checked, I can conclude only that Mr Ryan would seem to be about the last person who should be allowed to be in charge of any operation, let alone the Australian Secret Intelligence Service. Let me explain.

According to Who's Who in Australia, Mr Ryan joined the Department of Foreign Affairs in 1946 and served in Athens, Rio de Janeiro and New York until, in 1965 , he was made High Commissioner to Ghana. I understand a phantom was detected on the High Commission payroll at that time but I am told that Mr Ryan was apparently not to blame. In 1968 Mr Ryan was appointed Australian Ambassador to Laos at a time when the Australian Embassy there was little more than a minor branch office of the Central Intelligence Agency. I am reliably informed that, as so often seems to happen in the Department of Foreign Affairs, as Ambassador in Laos Mr Ryan engaged in financial malpractice and embezzlement and, having enriched himself in this way, was promoted as Australian Minister to the United States of America-a very highly sought after position.

In 1971 Mr Ryan returned, on promotion, to Canberra, and like so many other corrupt senior officers before and after him, was appointed to a management job as First Assistant Secretary in charge of the whole management and financial area of the Department. One of his first jobs was to cope with the fallout of his own financial misconduct in Laos in 1968 and 1969. The cover-up that was set in place somehow unravelled itself to the extent that it was decided that the Secretary to the Department, Sir Keith Waller, would have to go through the charade of rebuking Mr Ryan in writing. But that is not the whole of it. The Secretary's written rebuke to Mr Ryan-let us remember that if Mr Ryan had been a clerk, a shop assistant or a tradesman, he would have been instantly dismissed- was prepared by Mr Ryan himself. That was quite a slap on the wrist.

Firmly esconced as head of the Department's management from 1971 to 1974, Mr Ryan was directly and indirectly involved in collusion with his subordinates, some of whose names have a familiar ring. Mr Ryan was involved in covering up various embezzlements by his ambassadorial colleagues across the whole range. These included false entertainment claims, such as that in Stockholm, phantom servants, tax evasion, furniture removal frauds, importation of dangerous goods like machine guns and frauds of every conceivable description all over the world -from Peking to Paris, if one likes. Needless to say I hold the details of many of these.

Mr Ryan also developed a reputation for crude and abrasive treatment of his subordinates, but he reserved the best for officers who had been honest or silly enough to blow the whistle on frauds involving senior officers. These he humiliated, blocked from promotion and even tried to expel from the Department. In that regard I seek the incorporation in Hansard of an article from the Bulletin dated 13 December concerning Mr Ryan.

TALK.START.PARA: —As nobody on the Opposition has seen the article, I suggest, Senator Primmer, that you continue with your speech and give somebody on the Opposition bench the opportunity to look at the article and that you seek leave again at the end of your speech.

—Thank you, Madam Deputy President. I realise that much of this is reminiscent of exposures I have made of Foreign Affairs shenanigans in recent times. Others have followed in Mr Ryan's footsteps. In 1974 Mr Ryan moved overseas as Ambassador in Rome where, I have it on good authority, he managed to muck up arrangements for a visit by Prime Minister Whitlam. But this time his increasingly frequent bouts of drunkeness and disorderliness were a source of embarrassment to Australians and Italians alike. I am informed that Mr Ryan's wife was reduced to begging journalists not to report her husband's doings.

SPEECH.PARA: When he moved on to Canada as High Commissioner in 1977, the general opinion at that time was that he had been put out to grass, which was probably better than he deserved. But general opinion was wrong. In 1980, under the very suspect regime in Foreign Affairs, about which I have had so much to say, and will have more, Mr Ryan was transferred back to Canberra and promoted. Yes, he was promoted to Deputy Secretary in charge of-wait for it-management and finance. To the surprise of most, in 1981 he was appointed head of ASIS, a position he still holds today. Whilst I do not know how highly he rates in the field of trade craft, I hardly need to say that he is obviously totally unsuitable for his present position. He is a crook, a bureaucratic bully, a professional liar, a bad drunk, a social embarrassment-in fact a man tailormade for blackmail, just as were Burgess and McLean. This is the sort of person we have presiding over one of our most super-secret intelligence bodies.

If anyone seriously harbours any doubts about the accuracy of my information about Mr Ryan, I suggest that he come down from his ivory tower and speak to honest retired and serving Foreign Affairs staff and to the media. If he does this, he will find support for my allegations, and more. In any event, I am placing on the Notice Paper a range of questions aimed at uncovering the details of the allegations I have made today, and more. I hope that they will be answered quickly and honestly.

This is clearly a situation where the Government must act without delay. Any hesitation will cause further damage to Australia's foreign relations and what remains of the Government's good name. The longer the Government allows these corrupt operators to remain in positions of trust and influence, the more painful will be their eventual removal. I for one am not prepared to wait around until the next session to see Mr Ryan removed from a job which is obviously beyond him.

I happen to be old fashioned enough to believe that the misleading of Parliament is one of the most serious offences that can be committed in a democracy. Once it becomes routine for Ministers to rubber stamp false material put through them by dishonest or incompetent officials, the very basis of our deliberations in this chamber and in the other place is grievously damaged. I think many honourable senators will agree with me when I say that the most frequent offenders in this regard have been the defence, foreign affairs and intelligence bureaucracies.

Despite the entertainment afforded by the recent Dad's Army episode at the Fawlty Towers Sheraton, there are very serious matters deserving attention. As an example I refer to questions asked by Senator Giles and myself last week about the misleading of parliament by bureaucrats of the defence establishment, through senior Ministers, about the tragic effects herbicides used in Vietnam.

But again only last week this chamber was subjected to a clearly misleading statement by the Attorney-General concerning the shenanigans of ASIS and the Australian Security Intelligence Organization in South America and in the Chilean coup in particular. Since the Attorney-General read the two sentences concerned into Hansard I hope that he will freely admit that the material was supplied by bureaucrats who will be exposed, suspended and punished if, as I intend to demonstrate, they have wilfully misled Parliament. Should Senator Evans, or any member of the Parliament, be inclined to assert that my allegations are without foundation, I warn them that this is one of several matters-crusades if one likes-that I will not drop just because Ministers find it too bothersome to deal with corrupt and lying senior officials.

Let me put it bluntly: The Attorney-General's assertion about intelligence activities in Chile was totally misleading. Let me explain. While Mr Whitlam, to his credit, ordered the ASIS station in Chile-even the CIA term was used-closed in March 1972, it is now well known that the senior ASIS official whom I will call Mr D stayed on in Santiago, actively involved in the CIA destabilisation program, until just over one month before the military coup and the murder of President Allende. The Attorney-General's second sentence is therfore false and obviously so.

But there is more to come. Thanks to honest officers in ASIO, and there are some even there, I can now state without a shadow of doubt that ASIO has maintained at least one representative in South America from 1972 to the present day and that most of the time of those agents has been spent in Argentina and Chile, and that includes 1973, the year of the coup. I will call the agent concerned at that time Mr J. Four Corners claims that ASIO was active in Argentina during the Falklands War. Therefore, Senator Evans's first sentence is also totally false. While I am fed up to the back teeth with Minister's purveying lies prepared by corrupt officials to this chamber, I nevertheless retain my belief in Senator Evans's basic honesty. To put it simply, he was lied to and passed those two sentences full of lies to the chamber and into Hansard.

I demand that he initiate all possible action to expose and punish the responsible officials, whoever they are-ASIS, ASIO, the Foreign Affairs Department or the Attorney-General's Department-and give a full and truthful report to the Parliament. Let him tell Mr Hayden and any other Ministers involved that the Senate, at least, has at last called a stop to this sort of performance. Let him know that honourable senators are no longer prepared to accept the words of these anonymous liers in preference to the facts as asserted by many parliamentarians, academics, the media-especially Four Corners-and plain citizens.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Primmer sought leave during his speech to incorporate in Hansard an article from a recent Bulletin. Now that members of the Opposition have seen it, is leave granted for it to be incorporated?

INTERJECT.PARA: ASIS chief not new to hot water
Last week's Sheraton Hotel raid is not the first incident that has brought the head of ASIS, John Ryan, into conflict with Labor ministers.

Back in the Whitlam years when Ryan was with the Department of Foreign Affairs he prepared a draft letter for the foreign minister to send to an unhappy job applicant who believed he had been passed over on security grounds. Not so, said Ryan's answer.

But Foreign Minister Don Willesee called for the file to see for himself and it showed that security was the ground. Willesee referred the matter to Whitlam who was so annoyed that he ordered Ryan not be appointed as ambassador to Rome. Whitlam was eventually placated and Ryan became ambassador.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is not the first time that I and, I think, the whole of the Opposition have been concerned with the way that Senator Primmer has used Parliament to deal with matters which he obviously believes are major grievances. I have no personal knowledge about the matters which have been raised by Senator Primmer. But I express the strongest possible concern about the way Senator Primmer has gone about this use of the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: This debate is termed a non-contentious debate. We are speaking through what is normally the luncheon adjournment. It is, perhaps, highly undesirable that there is not even a Minister in the chamber in charge of the Senate. So we have a situation in which very serious allegations have been made against an Australian citizen in the absence of a Minister and, so far as I know, without notice to a Minister who might have been able to be advised on this matter. Great damage could be done to somebody who may well be innocent. Whether that person is innocent or not of the very serious allegations made about him is not open to this chamber to find out or to determine. I believe for Senator Primmer to simply come in here and to make the sort of allegations which have been made in the way that they have been made is a procedure which will diminish the status and the standing of this place and which may give rise to a very serious injustice to one of the people whom we are supposed to be here to represent.

We carry a very heavy responsibility because we have a very special privilege. We are allowed to come into this place and to say absolutely anything about anybody that we like to mention. The rules of this place, the Standing Orders, give some very special protection to a very select group of people. They protect us, for example. Senator Primmer cannot come into this place and say that Fred Chaney is a crook because we have been careful to provide a set of rules which determine that that is unparliamentary. There has to be a resolution to justify that. The Standing Orders would ensure that you, Madam Acting Deputy President, would sit him down and demand a withdrawal if he said that in the chamber. Because he has come in here and said it about a citizen, there was no point in my taking a point of order because, although that may have interrupted Senator Primmer's flow, I understand the Standing Orders well enough to know that you, Madam Acting Deputy President, could not have intervened.

We protect ourselves, we protect our House of Representatives colleagues, we protect members of State parliaments, we protect statutes, but we provide no protection for the people of Australia. We do that because of a very important principle. We are supposed to be able to expose matters fearlessly and to have no fear of legal action. The constitutional principle which underpins our complete freedom to come in here and say what we wish is based on important considerations of public policy which I am sure we all support. Parliamentary privilege is an important protection for the Parliament and an important way of guaranteeing that we can carry out our duties. But, I think the fact that we have that power means that we must exercise it with the very greatest care, because we have it in our hands to do people enormous damage without those people having redress if what is said is subsequently proved to be wrong or to be beyond proof.

It is not open to Senator Primmer to say that he is powerless to try to redress these grievances in a way which would be fairer to the citizen involved. He is a supporter of the present Government. I think, even if he were not, even if he were in Opposition still, he would know that he has access to Ministers and that he should surely, as a first step, make detailed representations on these serious matters to the Executive Government and seek an explanation. I know that it is part of his complaint that he is not satisfied with the explanations he has been given in other cases. He made that clear again in speaking today. But there is no indication from what I have heard from Senator Primmer today that these matters have been raised in detail with the Government and dealt with either satisfactorily or unsatisfactorily. I understand that it may well be that it is not possible to get satisfactory redress from the Executive Government. The Ministers may not, for whatever reasons. They may not choose to deal with the matter, they may not be capable of dealing with the matter, they may be prevented by the bureaucrats from dealing with the matter, they may be prevented for a whole range of reasons from dealing with the matter. I would have thought that some very substantial steps and attempts should be taken before this sort of allegation is made against a member of our community, the community that we are here to serve. I do not see any evidence that that first step has been taken .

If a member of this Senate has a serious allegation to make and if he cannot get satisfaction through the normal channels, even through the Government of which he is a supporter, then surely the matter could be raised in Parliament in a way which provides some protection for the citizen. Surely the responsible Minister could be alerted; surely the basic facts could be provided so that at least if there is a defence, there is a chance for that to be aired at the time when the calumny and the detraction are aired. I do not believe it is good enought simply to come in here and air a matter in the way that this matter has been aired today. If a matter of detail requires investigation or if there is a serious possibility of maladministration and scandal, it could be dealt with otherwise than by coming in here and making general accusations. We have a number of parliamentary forms. If the honourable senator concerned feels that he must make the accusation here, surely a Minister who has the administrative responsibility for that department and that person should be present to hear the complaint and be armed at least with the basic facts so that if there is some saving point that could be put forward it could be put forward immediately.

There are other procedures available to Senator Primmer. If there is major maladministration in a department, we have a very good committee system. For example, the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations has a high reputation. It has gone into matters. I believe that any honourable senator with a sense of responsibility for the people whom he is here to represent would do everything possible to canvass ways which would fairly and justly raise what he obviously thinks are serious matters going to the public administration of this country, to its foreign affairs and to its security services.

It is not for me to respond to Senator Primmer. But on behalf of the Opposition I express my very great reservations about the procedure that he has adopted. It is not for me to question Senator Primmer's beliefs or integrity or the honesty of the belief he holds. But I question very seriously the appropriateness of the way that he has gone about this. He has come in here and told us that he believes that one of his own Ministers, Senator Evans, has told lies to this chamber. No more serious allegation can be made against a member of the Government. To make it during lunch time on Thursday during a non-contentious debate when a Minister is not here I find nothing short of extraordinary. I condemn this use of parliamentary privilege.

I know that Senator Jessop is also listed to speak. I do not wish to trespass on some very important views which he has on the sorts of issues of principle which I have raised in response to Senator Primmer. I think Senator Primmer's performance today has demonstrated yet again that we, as members of this Senate, need to look at the power which has been given to us and at the very great privilege that we have to speak on any subject without redress being offered to those whom we might hurt. I think I would support our very carefully examining how we could provide proper avenues of redress and protection for those who might be damaged for what may be a very careless exercise of the very great privilege that we carry.

So, Madam Acting Deputy President, on behalf of the Opposition, I express very great concern through you to Senator Primmer for this further use of the Parliament which I think comes very close on the face of what we have before us to being an abuse of the privileges we have, and I believe that Senator Primmer should enter into the most careful dialogue with his Government to try to find some way of tackling these matters other than by dragging the names of people into the public arena in this way when they have no opportunity to reply, no opportunity to defend themselves and no opportunity to contest what may well be hotly contested questions of fact.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I think I am the only Minister who heard some of Senator's Primmer's contribution to the Senate-I was in my room-perhaps I ought to respond and at least say that the allegations he has made are very serious. I believe they are allegations a member of the Senate is entitled to make if he feels that the questions require some public ventilation. I wish to give my other colleagues who have come into the Senate an opportunity to appreciate the degree to which Senator Primmer has referred to a number of matters that have caused him concern for considerable time. I noticed that, in respect of his allegations about our intelligence agencies in Chile, he did not name the persons in that country but he did, nevertheless, name Mr Ryan, a person of whom I did not know until the unusual incident and activity at the Sheraton Hotel in Melbourne for which he was responsible. Mr Ryan was named by Senator Primmer. Of course it is on the public record that Mr Ryan did give certain information to the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden), who I am pleased to see rejected it, which was designed to keep from the Minister and from the Parliament the illegality of that particular incident in Melbourne last week.

SPEECH.PARA: However I rise only to give my fellow Ministers the opportunity to make an evaluation of what Senator Primmer has done. I must say in respect of what the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Chaney) said that individual members of Parliament do have the right, untramelled, under the Westminister system to raise matters in the Parliament. It may well be that other steps could have been taken. Senator Primmer has shown over recent times his desire to raise a whole number of matters which may or may not be true but which obviously are matters which he has expressed with some vehemence and some consistency. To that extent I supose I can note the statement that Senator Chaney has made on behalf of the Opposition, that he has grave reservations about the matter, but I think it would be a sorry day for parliament if members were expected somehow to conform to certain standards in respect of Ministers of governments even though that is probably regarded as part of the tradition and the practice of parliament. Nevertheless, there is always the overriding consideration that members do have to express in the Parliament matters which they believe have not had sufficient ventilation. The Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Grimes, who is in charge of the day to day administration of the chamber , might now be in a position to make some response to the remarks of Senator Chaney.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak for only two minutes. There are two aspects of this matter. First of all, I did not hear Senator Primmer's speech. I certainly did not know that what was obviously a controversial matter would be brought up at a time when there was by agreement to be a non-controversial debate. Secondly, the fact that there was no Minister here is certainly my responsibility as manager of Government business. I have since ascertained, by talking to my colleagues, that there was a mix-up in the roster but that is no excuse. I know it has happened before. I remember once when I was shadow Minister for Social Security I sat down and there was only myself and the Deputy President in the place, and no one else to speak. It should not happen and I will certainly ensure that it does not happen again. I will ascertain the details of what Senator Primmer has said and consult with the Government and the Minister concerned and ensure that the honourable senator receives a response to what he has said. I make the point that I had no warning that this was going to happen during this debating time. I will try to make sure it does not happen again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Jessop for allowing me the opportunity to speak briefly. This is the latest in a series of attacks that Senator Primmer has made upon various senior officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs. I have risen before on this issue and have said with all the force I can command that I reject what he is saying; I reject his methods. I find I have to say to Senator Primmer, as a senator whom I have respected, that I find it despicable that he should pursue the matter in this way. I say that to someone to whom I wish I did not have to say it. The fact of the matter is that I have known of old that his attacks on, for example, Sir Nicholas Parkinson in regard to his medical condition are totally without foundation. I have seen the medical evidence and I know the allegations to be untrue. I find it quite wicked-I used that word-that Senator Primmer should make such attacks. To come in here fed and fuelled each day by written leaks from somebody disaffected in the Department does no credit to him, no credit to the Senate and no credit to his political party and is very destructive of the Government and the Department.

SPEECH.PARA: But let me quickly put in perspective what he has said today. He said: 'I come in here because two very well respected members of the Labor Party, David Combe and Mick Young, have been attacked and savaged by the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation and I am therefore going to reveal things that are damaging to the intelligence services of Australia'. In other words, he is saying that, because there have been revealed increased breaches of the law and of procedures, we will not deal with the miscreants; we will sack or destroy the police force. This is a nonsense situation. I could not help but marvel at what he said-I put down his words:
. . . misleading of Parliament is one of the most serious offences that can be committed in a democracy.

My goodness! Senator Primmer has come in here and defended Mick Young as being one who has been savaged, when Mick Young has misled the Parliament and misled his Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) quite apart from the offence of which Mr Justice Hope found him guilty. Indeed, if ever there was misleading it was in the case of that ex-Minister. It is not good enough to say that a person has the right and freedom to come in here and say things such as Senator Primmer has said. I do not think that the Australian Labor Party Caucus gives Government members the right and freedom; I do not think the Labor Party Caucus, which governs the Labor Party of which the Prime Minister has demonstrated himself to be a captive and prisoner in recent days, is willing or ought to be willing to see a whole department destroyed, one by one.

I now say that I believe that Peter Henderson is a man of first class integrity and he does not deserve the mischief that has gone on. I know and respect Sir Nicholas Parkinson and I reject any allegations made about him. I do not happen to know Mr Ryan but, in the absence of any kind of fair judgment, I reject those allegations too. What nonsense it is to be angry about the fact that David Combe was not given a fair go because, if ever there was a Moscow trial of any person, it was by the group of six people on the National and International Security Committee that tried him and hanged him and put out a Press statement about him before he could go before any kind of judicial inquiry. We are talking about the fact that-and most of the Labor Party holds my view-whatever were the faults of David Combe the way that the Prime Minister and his Ministers handled this was heinously wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Senator Sir John Carrick's suggestion that the Labor Caucus does not endorse the Government's statement is entirely wrong and I ask him to withdraw it.
—There is no point of order.

—I can understand the desire to interrupt, but the fact is that today we have heard in here the most twisted and distorted forms of argument. Indeed the Labor Party tried and hanged David Combe, and published his crime and sentence in public, before he could even have a fair trial. Whether he ws right or wrong does not matter. Now precisely the same thing is happening as many members of the Labor Party have complained about in relation to David Combe . I am on record in Hansard as having said this here months ago. They are now doing the same thing to a senior officer of the Foreign Affairs Department. I have to say that I reject it. I have to say that unless this Government now takes this matter up and deals with it properly and effectively, by proper investigation and proper decision making processes, it will have abdicated its responsibilities. No government can sit back day by day watching a government member systematically destroying the character of the senior officers of one of its most senior departments. It cannot do that. It is not good enough to say: ' We have had an investigation and the evidence is not there'. After all the records of these people outside are being destroyed, but above everything Australians name overseas is being destroyed. What kind of situation is it in which we are now saying to the people overseas that our intelligence agencies ought not to be respected overseas, ought not to be consulted overseas because the leaders of them are people for whom we have no respect, they are people who are corrupt?

SPEECH.PARA: I have to say equally that if indeed it is true, as Senator Primmer said, that the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) came in here and uttered lies, however unwittingly, the Attorney-General had better look to the question of what happens in his judgment of Ministers who assume the responsibility of saying things and then finds them to be lies. I have never been more disturbed in this Parliament by any actions than those that Senator Primmer has triggered in the past and today. I repeat that his argument today has been that two of his mates in the Labor Party have suffered and therefore we should destroy the police force. The day we destroy the police force instead of looking at the miscreants is a sad day for Australia. I suggest that the Labor Party get its targets right instead of allowing the civil war of the Caucus today and yesterday to spill over into this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President--
—Madam Acting Deputy President--
—Madam Acting Deputy President--

—I call Senator Haines. I am sorry , there is some confusion. I appreciate that Senator Jessop's name is on the speakers list. I understood from the opening remarks of Senator Sir John Carrick that there had been some arrangement whereby he was replacing Senator Jessop.
—No.
—It is all right. I will have my say later.
—In that case I will call Senator Jessop. I am sorry , Senator Haines.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Madam Acting Deputy President, I wish to make a personal explanation. A number of honourable senators were under the impression that this period was set aside for debates of non-contentious matters and that was dealt with in the debate relating to sitting hours. As far as I am concerned, I have two meetings to attend; one which I had almost completed when I heard part of what Senator Primmer said, and another meeting which is an Amnesty International meeting, which is currently going on.

SPEECH.PARA: I am affronted, as a member of the Senate, at what I heard because it was an outrage on a public servant who has served this nation internationally and nationally under both Australian Labor Party and Liberal Party governments. Worse still, I am affronted by the attempt by the Minister for Veteran Affairs ( Senator Gietzelt) to clothe this attempt by Senator Primmer to underline the security and intelligence services of this country with some degree of respectability. That is in clear defiance of the clearly expressed attitude of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). The Minister should resign. This is a time for non-contentious debate and if the Government does not do something about it today I intend to use the forms of this chamber by not granting leave between now and the end of the session.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I did defer to my colleagues earlier because of the nature of the debate. I regret very much that it has become a little controversial. It is not the first time that I have risen in my place to defend people outside who have been accused under privilege of certain things, not only with respect to Senator Primmer's attacks on Mr Peter Henderson, but also other matters which have been raised. It has been my feeling for a long time that the Senate should do something about this in order to give redress to people who have been accused without the opportunity of reply. It seems to me that the Senate ought to give consideration perhaps to referring some matters of the Senate Standing Committee on Privileges with the object of giving the people outside, who regard something that is said in here as being damaging to their reputations or their business credibility, the opportunity to make a submission to the President and then for that submission, if the President warrants it, to be referred to the Privileges Committee to be dealt with. I think that would be fair. It would give the people outside the opportunity to present their cases or defences in an appropriate manner. I suggest we think about that seriously. Perhaps I will bring in a motion to that effect next year.

SPEECH.PARA: I originally rose to reply to something that Senator Colston raised on the adjournment on, I think, 8 November. I rise only to read to the Senate a letter that was written to me by Brigadier Greville. I mentioned this matter to Senator Colston and I thought that it was fair for me to read the letter I have received into the Hansard. It states:
Dear Senator,
I have read carefully pages 2138 and 9 of Hansard covering the proceeds of the Senate on November 8, 1983.
The statement made by Senator Colston (Queensland) about me upset my aged mother which I find quite offensive. I seek from you someway of redressing the wrong done me.
I think the particular matter he refers to was broadcast over the radio and this is the reason for this letter. He continued:
Should the Senator have made these statements outside of the Senate, I would not need to call upon you to redress this wrong.
I would like to make it quite clear to you, what it is that both my mother and I find offensive in the . . . statement.
In the first instance, I do not object to the Senator's accusations about my lack of taste in commenting adversely about the dead.
He is referring there to the late Wilfrid Burchett. He continued:
Taste is a matter of judgment, and depends on one's attitude in this instance towards the Soviet Union and the spread of communism.

I would suggest too, that I believe myself qualified to speak on behalf of other Australians who suffered the indignity of being prisoners in the hands of the Chinese Communists, some of whom did not survive the unpleasant experience.

Senator Colston's good friend Senator Georges complained bitterly a few years ago about the unhumanity of being in solitary confinement for twenty-four hours; I like many other Allied Prisoners in North Korea spent one hundred days, in solitary confinement, not in the friendly hands of the Queensland Police in a comfortable watch house, but in utter degradation and under constant threat.

My objection is to the statement 'If Greville felt so strongly about Mr Burchett, he should have said these things while Burchett was alive. It seems uncharacteristically cowardly for Greville to wait until a person has died to launch a vitriolic attack on him. Both the Brigadier and the Pacific Defence Reporter should be aware that often there is dignity in silence'.

There is dignity in the silence of the dead in Korea, especially in those whom Burchett may have saved if he possessed one spark of humanity for his fellow Australians and their Allies. Those of us who survived have our duty to ensure that they did not die in vain.

The facts are that I have been consistently vocal about Burchett ever since he tried to return to the country that he foresook, many of my efforts to expose him have been thwarted, but not for lack of effort on my part.
I attach, Sir, a deposition which I lodged as a witness in the case Burchett re Kane. I do not possess a copy of my evidence at the trial, but it is a matter of public property.

As that deposition makes clear, I had on two occasions written letters to the editors of papers stating clearly that in my opinion Burchett's conduct in Korea had been traitorous. Because Burchett had laid charges against Mr Denis Warner and the Melbourne Herald, the Editors of all the papers contacted considered the matter sub-judice and would not print the letters.

On his return to Australia I was given a chance to confront Burchett when I was invited to appear as part of a panel interviewing Burchett on a Four Corner's programme of the ABC. Although a serving officer, I risked offical censure to appear on the programme, and travelled to Sydney to do so.

When Burchett learned from the Director of the Programme that one of the panel was an ex-POW, he refused to take part. The ABC dropped me from the panel, but I was given an interview immediately afterwards in which I made it quite clear that in my opinion Burchett's conduct in Korea was indefensible.

As Defence Correspondent of the Advertiser under great provocation from certain sectors of the media, I retaliated by publishing three articles about Burchett, each of them making it clear that I believed him to be a traitor.
I have too, written the chapter on Australian POWs in the Korean War for Volume 2 of the Official History of that war edited by Dr Robert O'Neill.

In that chapter, I made it quite clear that as a soldier I was most disturbed by the fact that successive Governments of both political persuasions had ignored, or failed to comprehend the enormity of Burchett's crime towards Australian POWs.
It may be that this chapter is the cause of the volume being some eighteen months overdue.

When Burchett arrived in Australia on February 27, 1970, Mr Eric Donnelly, Chief Photographer of the Sunday Truth met Burchett in the course of his duties at Brisbane Airport. He publically accused Burchett of being a liar-see Sunday Mail, Adelaide February 28, 1970.

Donnelly had been severely wounded before capture and suffered greatly in those crude conditions; he was fortunate to be evacuated in 'Little Switch' but unfortunate to meet Burchett before being repatriated. He knew the facts.

Donnelly was so incensed about the treatment he was dealt by this fellow journalists that he had to remind the District Committee of the Australian Journalists Association that he had been a financial member of the organisation for twenty-two years, and was surely due some consideration over Burchett of whom he declared 'the word objectivity, impartiality and accuracy are strangers' .

Because citizens of Australia can be libelled with such impunity by their elected representatives I can only appeal to you, to have the record set right. I am not sure of the mechanics, but if the words cannot be expunged from Hansard , I would ask you to have included sufficient of the above and the attachments to ensure that it clearly established that at no time have I been afraid to say to the world at large, that Burchett was a traitor.

He made the point that he did this, of course, well before Mr Burchett unfortunately died. I know Brigadier Greville personally. As a prisoner of war he was in solitary confinement on a number of occasions. On one occasion he was thrown into a packing case left by the Americans. It was a wooden box arrangement measuring about 4 1/2 feet by 3 1/2 feet by 2 1/2 feet. He told me that he was reasonably happy there because he could see out through the cracks in the wood. However, the North Koreans threw into this confined space with him a South Korean soldier who had had an arm shot off and who had abdominal wounds. Even worse, later on a wounded civilian Korean also had to be accommodated in that small space. Brigadier Greville spent 21 days in that sort of situation so I think he can be excused for feeling very strongly about the fact that Wilfred Burchett during those years went behind enemy lines and tried to coerce Australian prisoners of war into saying that they were being treated very well, the Americans were the aggressors and so on, on the promise that they would be taken out of these degrading prisons and given better accommodation and better food. I think it would be fair to suggest that the feelings of Brigadier Greville plus those of a lot of other POWs would be quite strong against Mr Wilfred Burchett. I thought it a fair thing that I take this opportunity to present Brigadier Greville's case so that the Senate could study its contents. I apologise for delaying the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not delay the two honourable senators who want to make a contribution before 2 o'clock. It seems that I will not have the chance of replying on this matter before 2 o'clock. At this stage I indicate that I would like to comment on the remarks made by Senator Jessop today. However, I will do so at a later stage when I have the opportunity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter I want to raise today in what is supposed to be a time set aside for non-controversial debate, relates to what I believe is the wilful, if not actually blatant, disregard by the Government for the rights of an Australian citizen. The gentleman I refer to is Mr Rafe Slaney, a businessman who lives in Geelong. For the last six or so years Mr Slaney has operated a business in Geelong called Medicare-Doctors' After Hours Service. I see that the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) is in the chamber. I did not inform the Whip's secretary about the topic of my speech although I did so last Thursday night when I intended to raise this matter during the adjournment debate but changed my mind at the last minute. Mr Slaney' s problem has been raised in the media and I believe it is worth while raising it again in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: For those members of the Senate who are not familiar with the situation, Mr Slaney first registered his business in 1975 and the service commenced in 1977. The business is registered as 212 Shannon Avenue, Geelong West. I remind honourable senators, who actually should not need reminding, that in 1975 the then Government's health care scheme was called Medibank. It continued to be called Medibank despite the various changes that it went through for some years. Mr Slaney's service-Medicare-Doctors' After Hours Service-provides an after hours surgery, waiting room and toilet facilities for patients and accommodation for a locum doctor and family as well as for a receptionist/operator. It supplies on site medical requirements such as dressings, bandages, sutures, instruments, plaster of paris, slings and a host of other items including notepaper, account forms and envelopes. Medicare-Doctors' After Hours Service operates independently of, but in co-operation with, local doctors and hospitals . Over the past six years it has provided medical care for more than 20,000 patients. It conforms to the guidelines for locum services laid down by the Australian Medical Association. I suggest that the dilemma is a very obvious one . While Medicare, to the Government and a large number of the Australian population, means the new health care system which is due to commence on 1 February next, to a large part of the population of Geelong for the last six years the term 'Medicare' in that abbreviated form has been used to describe Mr Slaney's business, the long title of which is Medicare-Doctors' After Hours Service. But as we all know, when you have a title like that most people will shorten it, and in Geelong and surrounding districts the business has been known simply as Medicare. Therefore, for them it has become synonymous with the provision of medical care under private practitioners and locums when their own doctors are of duty.

I do not think that it takes anybody with the IQ of a genius to work out the effect that this could well have on Mr Slaney's business. In an open letter he has issued he makes the point that Medicare-Doctors' After Hours Service is listed in both the Geelong and Melbourne telephone directories. Their phones, he believes, could well be jammed with inquiries during the next year. He believes that his surgery will be overrun with people making claims, inquiries and so on in relation to the Government's new health system, which is also known as Medicare. Conversely, he says that to patients seeking their own doctors, or doctor's replacements, the name Medicare could well put them off ringing or coming to the surgery as they could well imagine that they would get 'government ' doctors. Thus, he believes, his business will be adversely affected because patronage will be lost and patients for whom the service was intended in the first place will not be seen.

Over the last eight months or so Mr Slaney has been trying to clarify this position with the present Minister for Health, Dr Blewett, in an attempt to try to come to some agreement and obtain some form of redress. To date the Minister has chosen more or less to wash his hands of the matter. I point out that the first letter that Mr Slaney sent to Dr Blewett was sent prior to the 5 March election, anticipating presumably that the Labor Party would get in, or at least having foresight that most good businessmen have, to forestall any problems. The Minister's latest answer of any note of which I have a copy is dated 28 June 1983. In fact, it is a letter to Senator Chipp, who took this matter up through correspondence with the Minister.
It begins:
I apologise for the failure to attached the relevant correspondence to my earlier reply concerning Mr Rafe Slaney.

Mr Slaney's then solicitor, John J Byrne, contacted me during the election campaign about the name 'Medicare'. On 23 March 1983 I telegrammed an acknowledgment to this solicitor (copy attached) and requested my department to investigate the matter.

I point out at this stage, Madam Acting Deputy President, that that telegram from Dr Blewett on 23 March was prompted by a number of requests for acknowledgment of, or answers to, previous letters sent either by Mr Slaney or his solicitor. Dr Blewett's letter goes on:
My department approached the Crown Solicitor's Office for advice on the matter, and as a result I sent the attached reply to Mr Slaney's present solicitors.

Investigations have revealed that there are about 17 firms who use the name ' Medicare' or names very similar to it. No company has 'Medicare' as a registered trade mark, and as I have indicated it is already in widespread use.

The government's Medicare health insurance programme will be widely explained in the coming months, so there should be no confusion with other products. We have no intention of interfering with the rights of persons who have already registered 'Medicare' as a business or company name, but we will consider limiting its further use.

It is jolly generous of the Minister to say that he has no intention of interfering with the rights of persons who have already registered 'Medicare' as a business or company name. Presumably by that he means that he will not stop them from going on using it, but by the same token, he apparently has no intention of making any sort of redress available to those who, over a number of years and in very good faith, have used that name and have established a business accordingly.

To go back to something else that the Minister said-that the Government's Medicare health insurance program would be widely explained in the coming months -I interpolate an anecdote that was repeated to me by a relative of mine who had been talking, at some social function or other that an Adelaide football club, to which he belongs, was holding, in a group of nine or 10 people. The topic of the Medicare cards and forms that have been sent out by the Government to everybody came up. It was confidently asserted by one member of the group, and agreed to by almost all the other members of the group, except my relative, who knew better, that there was no point in filling out the form and applying for the card because Medicare was not going to get through the Parliament. That happened within the last week. It shows how well the Government's Medicare health insurance program has been explained in the months since 28 June. Even if the Minister had made tremendous efforts in that regard, it is not possible to cover every member of the public. Many people simply do not care, many are not interested, many do not read papers and so on. People who have for the last six years been used to associating the term Medicare with a particular business in their country town are quite likely to assume that that business, if it continues, has either become some sort of a government organisation or has otherwise changed its method of operation.

So I suggest that the Minister's, and therefore I presume the Government's, rather off-handed approach to what is likely to happen to a medical service that is provided in Geelong is not good enough. It simply is not satisfactory to shrug one's shoulders metaphorically and say: 'Well, 17 other firms are using it . We are not going to make you stop using it. On the other hand we are not going to do anything about it if you lose business'. I therefore ask the Minister, through the good offices of this debate, to reconsider his decision and look at Mr Slaney's case again with a view to reaching some sort of reasonable agreement with him as to compensation, if any is necessary, and to do likewise with any of the other people who feel that they have been disadvantaged in this way. Presumably, the Minister does not want to give any sort of payment, ex gratia or otherwise, to Mr Slaney in case it will establish a precedent or set off some sort of rush for compensatory payments, but I would have thought that this particular case-other cases may be equally deserving-should be looked at on its merits with a somewhat more sympathetic eye, given that when the business was established Medibank was the term used in this country for a government sponsored and government run health care system and that this man has been operating a very successful business and providing a very necessary service in a country town in Australia. I think that he deserves better treatment than he has received so far.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would he have any civil rights?

—I have not the faintest idea, not being a lawyer, one of those noxious types that abound in this place. Perhaps we could find out from somewhere else. As Dr Blewett has said, he has approached the Crown Solicitor's Office for advice and that Office-not noted certainly for giving very radical opinions-has indicated that there is no legal requirement on the part of the Government to act. However, I repeat that the Crown Solicitor's Office is quite notorious for making ultra-conservative judgments in these cases, and perhaps it is worth challenging. Mr Slaney has already expended a large amount of money in solicitors' fees and so on in attempting to get some sort of satisfaction from the Government. I presume that his resources are considerably less than are the Government's. He may well not be in a position to fight this matter further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The annual report of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority was presented to the Senate yesterday but the Senate did not have time to discuss it yesterday. I thought that today, during a non-controversial debate, I would be able to say a few words about it. I am very interested in the report. I am sure that the cover of the report will make everybody who sees it think that it would be very nice to spend some time on the Great Barrier Reef. I have been to many of the islands, although I have not been fortunate enough to go to the outer reef. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Great Barrier Reef Region covers an area of almost 350,000 square kilometres. It is considerably larger in area than the United Kingdom or the State of Victoria. The area has been used by Aboriginals from time immemorial . . .

That, of course, is quite right. If one visits Lizard Island, one hears the story of Mrs Watson, the wife of a beche-de-mer fisherman who was left on the island by her husband while he went fishing. While she was there some Aborigines arrived for an initiation ceremony. I am afraid that they threatened to kill her . As a result she got into a ship's tank with her Chinaman helper and her baby and pushed off to sea. Unfortunately, the currents did not take her to the mainland which is within sight of Lizard Island but they took her to another island further away where there was no water. In the end Mrs Watson, her Chinese servant and the baby perished. It is, of course, a very sad story. If one happens to go to Cooktown and visits the museum one will be acquainted with this very interesting but particularly sad story. The report of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority states:

When the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act was passed in 1975 by both Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament, with the support of all parties, there already existed a complex set of mechanisms which regulated human activity on and near the Great Barrier Reef. These included State and Commonwealth regulations on fishing, mineral exploration and recovery, boating and shipping, tourist operations, operations of ports and harbours and the discharge of wastes from fixed installations and vessels.

As at June 1983, 14 per cent of the Great Barrier Reef region was within the Marine Park. That figure has now increased to 80 per cent; so it will not be too long before the whole 100 per cent of the region comes within the Marine Park. I think everybody accepts that the Great Barrier Reef is one of the great wonders of the world. The latest section to be declared is the Cairns section. The report states:

The Cairns Section is huge. It is physically and biologically complex and is subject to a wide spectrum of human uses. Development of its zoning plan, during which all the submissions of experts and the general community were taken carefully into account, was correspondingly difficult.
The Chairman of the Authority, Mr Kelleher, said:

The creation of a new Marine National Park Buffer Zone in which the only fishing activity permitted is trolling from moving vessels was necessary in order to provide protection for many reefs while avoiding unnecessary restrictions on fishing activity, which is an important component of human use of the Great Barrier Reef.

Of course, we know that when the marlin fishing time comes around Lizard Island is very important. Lots of people from America visit Townsville and go marlin fishing from there. The report of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority states that its objectives are:
to maintain essential ecological processes and life-support systems; to preserve genetic diversity; to ensure the sustainable utilisation of species and ecosystems.

These are some of the interesting comments in the report. Another point I wish to make in connection with this report is that when I visited Lizard Island in August this year I took the opportunity to visit the Lizard Island research station. I was asked about the Federal Government's policy towards supporting funding for research stations on the Great Barrier Reef. It has been claimed that all the island research stations could be funded by various universities but they are not university operated. It was drawn to my notice while I was there-I had an opportunity to look at the station properly-that funds for research on the Barrier Reef are spent at the Australian Institute of Marine Science in Townsville but that the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and fisheries and university scientists still need to use the island's research facilities. Having had a talk with the gentleman who is in charge, I feel that there is a need for the Government to consider providing funds to cover basic operating and maintenance expenses at the research stations on the reef which then, of course, should be supplemented by a reasonable user pays system. I ask the Government to give consideration to the need which I have outlined.
Debate (on motion by Senator Coleman) adjourned.
(Quorum formed)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to a question I asked the Attorney-General on 6 September this year arising out of his opinion to the Prime Minister on 29 August concerning the question of the possible prosecution of Mr Young for a breach of the Crimes Act. I referred to a passage in that opinion under the heading 'Need for Deterrence' in which he said:

QUESTION.PARA: In the official secrets area, sanctions that have been traditionally regarded as applicable . . . are not those of the criminal law but the political sanctions . . .
In answer to my question, the Attorney said:

The particular remarks to which Senator Durack referred were made in the very specific context of the proper grounds upon which the discretion to prosecute should be exercised in the event that it ever became clear that a technical offence had been committed.

I ask the Attorney-General: In the light of Mr Justice Hope's findings in the report tabled here on Tuesday last, does he still consider that Mr Young committed only a technical offence? If so, how does he justify that view? If not , will he now reconsider the question of prosecution of Mr Young?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not the case that Mr Justice Hope made any finding at all as to whether Mr Young had committed any criminal offence. Mr Justice Hope deliberately refrained from drawing any conclusion on that basis on the ground, as honourable senators will recall from reading the report, that to do so would be oppressive, given the way in which the matter had been handled up to that point and given, in particular, the circumstance that I had indicated that no prosecution would flow. Even had Mr Justice Hope found that a criminal offence, technical or otherwise, had been committed, my decision would remain the same so far as prosecution is concerned on the basis of the criteria which I set out carefully in that letter. There is no ground whatsoever for reconsideration by me or, I believe, anyone else of the basic foundations of that opinion and the decision as recorded in that letter.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I specifically asked the Attorney-General whether, in the light of all the findings of fact, comments on law, and views on Mr Young's unauthorised action and impropriety, and in view of the application of section 79 of the Crimes Act, does the Attorney-General adhere to the view he expressed on 6 September to me that Mr Young committed only a technical offence?
—Mr President, I have nothing to add to my previous answer.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Finance. I refer to the annual report 1981-82 of the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust which the Minister for Finance tabled with the Auditor- General's report in the House of Representatives last night. I do not ask about the accusations of recklessness in investment procedure and so forth in the Auditor-General's report, but because of the attention drawn to the whole report I had a closer look at it than I might normally have done. Appendix A of the SFIT report lists the property in which the Trust has invested. There are 50 or so properties listed, not one of which is in Tasmania. I think there appears to be a fair spread amongst all the other States and Territories, but there is not one property in Tasmania. Will the Minister raise with the Minister for Finance and the Trust the question of such investment bodies, especially public ones, taking into account a fair spread of investment, especially as the superannuation contributions of public servants in Tasmania ought to be reflected in the activities of the Trust and the benefits to everyone from it.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware in detail of the contents of the report that was tabled last night by Mr Dawkins in the House of Representatives. I have been told that what Senator Coates has said about the dearth of investments in Tasmania by the Superannuation Fund is correct. While everyone would expect the managers of such a fund to pay due regard to the likely return on investments they make, it would be unlikely, to say the least, that anyone would expect that there are no investments worth making in Tasmania. For that reason, it seems that the Fund ought to pay some more attention to Tasmania or to the potential for investment in Tasmania than it has in the past. On prima facie grounds one would expect that there ought to be opportunities for profitable investment in that State. Also, as Senator Coates pointed out, it is a reasonable expectation for Tasmanians, or, indeed, the people of any State, to hold, that a reasonable amount of the investment from the Fund to which employees in all States contribute, not necessarily on a 1:1 ratio, be distributed fairly equally throughout the country.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, I can understand Senator Coates's interest in that matter because like all Tasmanian senators on this side of the House, he is interested in getting productive investment in Tasmania and securing some economic growth in that State. As the Premier of Tasmania told me directly some four or five months ago, the private sector in that State over the last 10 years has not generated one net job. For that reason, among others, Tasmania, compared with other States , has had a chronically high level of unemployment, a situation which Senator Coates obviously would like to have repaired. I will refer the question to the Minister for Finance to see what, if anything, he can have done about the apparent neglect of Tasmania to which Senator Coates has drawn attention. But I am not sure what powers of direction, if any, the Minister has over that Fund. I will see what Mr Dawkins has to add to the answer that I have given and will ensure that Senator Coates is notified accordingly.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Attorney-General and follows that of Senator Durack in that it concerns the Attorney-General's opinion of 29 August on the possible prosecution of Mr Mick Young under the Crimes Act. Is it true that both the Attorney-General and the Solicitor-General agreed that should Mr Eric Walsh's evidence of the 21 April conversation be preferred to Mr Young's , it was possible that an offence under the Crimes Act could have been committed ? Does the Attorney recall suggesting in the opinion that, in this event, the question of the application of section 79 (3) of the Act would be 'much more finely balanced'? Does he recall Sir Maurice Byers's view that:

QUESTION.PARA: It would be open to a jury to find that Mr Young had committed a breach of section 79 (3).

In light of the decision of Mr Justice Hope to accept the Walsh account and his findings about Mr Young's conduct, will the Attorney-General now reconsider his position and his decision not to prosecute?

TALK.START.PARA: —The contents of my opinion of 29 August and that of the Solicitor-General are a matter of public record. I believe they speak for themselves. As to the question of reconsidering the contents of that opinion in the light of recent developments, I do not believe Senator Messner asks any different a question from that which Senator Durack asked a few moments ago. The answer is exactly the same. No, I do not propose to reconsider the opinion because the opinion and that part of it which related to the decision not to prosecute were expressly based on what I described as worst case assumptions.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. In view of the fact that, during the years of the Fraser Government, Australia's eight family planning associations were forced to charge those utilising their services, except for pensioners and other beneficiaries, can the Minister give any indication of changes likely to occur as a result of the introduction of Medicare on 1 February 1984?
—Here comes a ministerial statement.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry to disappoint honourable senators opposite. It is not a ministerial statement. I will make one if they like. Certainly, as Senator Giles has pointed out, over the seven years there were considerable difficulties with the family planning associations because of the necessity they had to charge patients except those with various health benefit cards. As a result, many of the people whom the family planning associations would have liked to assist, such as disadvantaged people who, for one reason or another, did not have such cards, were charged or, if they were not charged, the associations had to bear the cost or the people had to do without the assistance.

ANSWER.PARA: Under the new arrangements under Medicare Dr Blewett has announced a situation whereby family planning associations in future will be able to be reimbursed without having to charge patients. I think it is a step forward. It has been welcomed by the family planning organisations. On Dr Blewett's behalf, I shall be tabling a statement in this place, not reading it out at Question Time, as Senator Archer thought I would, giving the details of that program and the programs in association with the States.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Resources and Energy . How does the Government intend to guarantee sufficient supplies of motor spirit in Australia if political troubles or war resulted in a sudden lack of availability of Middle East oil? Is the Government aware that a highly respected and internationally used mathematical model, called Markal, to assess the best available energy options for national economies, has been applied to Australia by a Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation team, and that it has concluded that we could profitably begin to produce methanol as a motor fuel from natural gas, and possibly also petrol, from 1990 onwards? Since the lead time for such natural gas to methanol or petrol plants is at least five years, does the Government intend to commence planning this development over the next few years, perhaps using North West Shelf gas on a large scale, in view of the current dilemma of the North West Shelf partners? Finally, is the Minister aware that major natural gas to methanol and petrol plants are already complete and operating successfully in New Zealand?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Mason has asked a number of questions. In regard to the first question, as to the likelihood of a sudden disruption in supply from overseas, nothing could fully compensate for the complete withholding of supplies from overseas; not that that is likely. It is, however, possible, for a variety of possible reasons, that a smaller amount than is currently supplied from overseas could be supplied at some time in the future.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has before the Senate now, we hope that it will be passed during this session, the Liquid Fuel Emergency Bill, the pre-planning for which was done by the previous Government, and which is intended to cope as best as is possible with such a situation. The Government is also involved with the International Energy Agency's plans for coping internationally with such a possible major disruption to world oil supplies.

Regarding the mathematical model which has predicted that by 1990 it could be economic to produce methanol or even petrol from natural gas, I am aware of that study. It incorporates assumptions about real increases in oil prices which were made some time ago and which are higher than I think most people, possibly including even those who drew up the model, would make today if they were again drawing up the guidelines for that model. In other words, disregarding short term disruptions of supply, it now seems unlikely that real oil prices will increase in the time frame that had been previously envisaged. Therefore, the period in which it may be economic to produce petrol or methanol from natural gas needs to be pushed well back into the 1990s.

The third question was whether the Government would commence planning for development of production of methanol from natural gas next year. In view of the points I have already made, the answer to that is no, because we believe it would be premature to initiate such plans at this stage. Expectations about this question can be proved to be wrong. For example, it was only a couple of years ago that Senator Sir John Carrick was forecasting that by 1985 we would be producing 50,000 barrels of oil a day from the Rundle shale deposits. I do not think that anyone expects that to happen by 1995, let alone by 1985. That estimate is very generous to Senator Sir John Carrick. If it ever happens, it is more likely to be pushed some time into the twenty-first century.

On the last question, regarding the New Zealand natural gas to methanol and petrol plant, I understand that it is not yet complete but that it will shortly be completed. It is not for me to pass judgment on the policies of the New Zealand Government. Again, I believe that plant was commissioned and adjudged to be economic against an expectation of a very rapid increase in real oil prices, which has not occurred. I would therefore be surprised if the fuel produced from that plant in late 1984 or 1985, whenever it is completed, were price competitive, at least at this stage, with petrol produced from imported crude oil.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Treasurer seen a report in today's Age in which the former Prime Minister argues that interest rates in Australia are falling because of, firstly, big capital inflow; secondly, the fact that the money supply is running at about 2 percentage points above the upper reaches of the Government's objective; and thirdly, the extraordinarily weak private demand for funds? Does the Minister accept this as an accurate explanation of the fall in interest rates?
—It is accurate, but he will not accept it.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had with me that cutting to which Senator Zakharov referred, but I seem to have misplaced it. I have seen it. It is a most extraordinary article and a most extraordinary comment from the discredited former Prime Minister; although nobody who was aware of his record could reasonably dispute his expertise on matters pertaining to interest rates. It was he, for example, who said in 1977: 'Interest rates will fall by 2 per cent over the coming year. It is a target that can and will be met'. That was what Mr Fraser said in the run- up to the 1977 election.

ANSWER.PARA: It was not, of course, what happened; and it was not only Mr Fraser who said that. The discredited former Deputy Prime Minister and present Leader of the National Party of Australia was at the same time stating that if interest rates did not fall by 2 per cent he would eat his hat. Something might have eaten his hair since then but, as far as I know, he has not yet eaten his hat.

For good measure, I might add-including this comment to whoever it was who interjected when Senator Zakharov's question was being completed-that if Mr Fraser were correct in his assessment all the sycophants in the Liberal Party and National Party in 1977 did not dispute that ridiculous assertion which their then Leader made.

To return to the details of the remarkable statement by the discredited former Prime Minister, from which Senator Zakharov has quoted, he claimed that interest rates were falling despite the size of the deficit, which contradicts what was dogma throughout the years in which the Fraser writ ran in this country, because of the big capital inflow and the fact that the money supply was running at about 2 percentage points above the upper reaches of the Government's objectives . The important fact which Mr Fraser has overlooked in arriving at that conclusion is that the money supply in the earlier part of the last financial year was running at a very high rate. Therefore, at this stage, those months of the last financial year in which the money supply was running at a very high rate are still included in the current annual rate. Towards the end of the last financial year the money supply on a month to month basis was growing at a very much lower rate. I cannot quote the precise figures. That was the monetary target set by the Government. By the end of this financial year the annual figure will have shed the high monthly growth rates which had been recorded in the earlier part of the last financial year. In other words, to simplify it, the real growth in the money supply is somewhat lower than the crude annual figure suggests because of variations within a year in the month to month rate of growth in the money supply. I refer to M3.

He said that the private demand for funds is weak. That is certainly correct. It is weak because he wrecked the economy in the final years of his Government and drove it into the deepest recession which it had seen for 50 years. After he had wrecked the economy, with the assistance of his colleagues here who are gibbering on the other side of the aisle, he said that it was all due to a wages blowout, as if that were some extraneous event over which he had absolutely no control, whereas, of course, in June of 1981 he was more interested in abandoning any attempt at a government wages policy and ducking off to London for the royal wedding. He was not criticised for that piece of irresponsibility either.

In closing, on the Government's stated objective for money supply-M3-it was to fall on a June 1984 on June 1983 basis, between the range of 9 and 11 per cent. It was also stated by the Treasurer in the Budget Speech, or if not in the Budget Speech contemporaneously with the Budget Speech, that that was a target which would be reviewed during the year in view of possible changes in economic activity. As the most recent statistics show, economic growth has been more rapid than was anticipated at the time the Budget was presented. If that trend should continue, the money supply target could, quite consistently with the objectives outlined by the Treasurer at the time the Budget was presented, be extended. If we take a mid-point figure of 10 per cent in the anticipated target , the money supply growth rate incorporated an assumption that nominal gross domestic product would grow by around 14 per cent and that the velocity of circulation would increase by about 4 per cent. If nominal GDP growth in fact exceeds 14 per cent, which now seems possible, it is not reasonable to expect the velocity to increase by more than 4 per cent. Therefore, it would be inappropriate under those circumstances to choke off the economic growth which is currently occurring by an unduly restrictive monetary policy. That is a lesson which I suggest members of the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia fruitfully use their time in opposition to learn.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order. I have been very patient. We have had reasonable Question Times in the absence of Senator Walsh and on his return we get back into the business of destroying Question Time by debating questions. I ask you to impose some discipline on the Minister.
—I think the Minister has completed his answer.

—Does the Attorney-General agree that major factors in his decision not to prosecute Mr Young under the Crimes Act were the degree of culpability of Mr Young and his, Senator Evans's, view that the former Minister had not intended to harm Australia's security?
