It is now a fact that Mr Justice Hope has found that the potential and not actual damage to national security of Mr Young's disclosures is the determinant of impropriety, that there was a real risk that significant damage could have resulted and that, notwithstanding Mr Young's short ministerial experience, it should have been apparent to him that he should not have made the disclosures. In view of this, will the Attorney- General therefore reconsider his decision since one of the main grounds for it has now been seen in a much different light by the Royal Commissioner?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think Senator Scott would have asked his question, even though it was put in his hands by someone else, had he actually read the terms of my opinion on 29 August because he will find that the matter is squarely there addressed. The criteria that were spelled out as appropriate to be taken into account in determining whether a prosecution should flow, even on the worst case assumptions as described, were: Obscurity of the law, the need for deterence, the seriousness of the offence and degree of culpability. The question that I further drew attention to on page 9 of the opinion is that a conviction under section 79 (3) of the Crimes Act, which is punishable by two years imprisonment, would be likely to result in Mr Young's automatic disqualification from parliament.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the particular matter of the degree of culpability what I wrote was this, and I believe it conveys its own answer to Senator Scott's question:

Although the disclosure of the specific matters described in Mr Walsh's account would potentially have been very serious-in terms particularly of what it would reveal about, and the way in which it might have interfered with, security operations-it does not appear, in the event, that any such damage occurred. Nor was there, obviously, any intention to harm Australia's defence, security or international relations.

Mr Hope's finding was that no damage had in fact occurred. It was potential, certainly, but the findings of Mr Justice Hope were in a sense identical with those that were anticipated here in the articulation of this particular criterion. Once again, despite the probing and general neurosis and fidgeting that is going on from Senator Chaney and others on the other side, there is simply no substance in any of their suggestions about reconsideration, and I propose to do nothing of the kind.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CANBERRA: CRITICISM BY MR PAUL EVERINGHAM

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs been drawn to a statement on this morning's Australian Broadcasting Corporation news made by Mr Holley, Chairman of the Canberra Celebration Board? Mr Holley complained that Mr Everingham, Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, stated that Canberra was 'a hateful place, an awful place to live' and that it lived a 'lapdog existence'. Does the Minister support Mr Holley's condemnation of such statements about our national capital?

—I certainly join with Mr Holley in condemning these outrageous criticisms of the national capital by Mr Everingham, and I presume my colleague Senator Reid would also. It is rather offensive for citizens of the Australian Capital Territory to be abused in this fashion. I must say that it is a singularly inappropriate choice of abusive metaphor on the part of Mr Everingham to refer to Canberra citizens as lap-dogs when everyone is aware that the Commonwealth funds the Northern Territory to the tune of something like 87 per cent. We do not complain about that.
—I take a point of order, Mr President. I ask in what aspect of the Minister's responsibility this question lies and whether it is within Standing Orders.
—I understood that the question was directed to Senator Ryan in her capacity as Minister for Education and Youth Affairs and I ask her to answer in that regard.

—It is very unfortunate for Mr Everingham to decide to score points in this way. People of the Australian Capital Territory find it very offensive. This is a place where many people have chosen to live, and live very happily. The population is growing again, of course, since the election of a Labor Government. It is a place with a very lively community, as Senator Reid will attest. We have an enormous number of charitable organisations and sports organisations. We have the finest government school system in the country and a number of other community services which make life here quite the opposite of hateful. I point out again that Mr Everingham, presiding over a territorial administration that is 87 per cent funded by Commonwealth funds, ought not to point at this community, which is a very high tax-paying community and a very harmonious and pleasant community to live in and, I might add, to represent.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General. In the Attorney-General's option of 29 August did he rely on what he called the obscurity of the law as a ground for not prosecuting the former Special Minister of State, Mr Mick Young, under the Crimes Act? In the light of Mr Justice Hope's analysis of section 79 of that Act, will the Attorney now agree that the section is clearly applicable to the facts of the case and that there is no reason for declining to prosecute on that ground?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The point has, once again, been spectacularly missed by Senator Lajovic and the person who wrote all these spectacularly inept questions . The sheer fact that there has been so much controversy about section 79 (3), so many different options expressed about it and so many different submissions made about it, is in intself, demonstration that the law is not clear. It may well be clear in my mind; it may well be clear in Mr Justice Hope's mind. The considerations in determining what it does mean, the applications of it and whether it refers to legal duties or classes of non-legal duties as well, are very much matters on which perfectly reasonably and well informed legal minds, not to mention lay minds, may well differ. Were this matter ever to be litigated in some context or another, it is perfectly likely that differences of opinion would be carried through all the way up to the High Court of Australia. I read into the record, again, the relevant paragraph from that part of my opinion in which I was, at that stage, indicating reasons why it would be inappropriate to prosecute even in the event that a clear offence was made out. I said that the question of obscurity of the law was one relevant criterion. I said:

ANSWER.PARA: This element is clearly present here, as is evident from the terms of both the Solicitor-General's opinion and my own: the issue of criminal liability, in our view, comes down ultimately to an assessment of what is required by the ''nature '' of the information, the ''circumstances'' of the case, and ''any other reason ''. We are aware, moreover, that at least one distinguished constitutional expert (Professor Sawer) has expressed a view of the law contrary to our own.

That was all that was said, making the point that there are a number of very vague expressions in section 79. The meaning of a number of the provisions in the Crimes Act are eminently worthy of reconsideration by this legislature. I hope that reconsideration will proceed next year. In the meantime, nobody can be quite confident also what these terms mean. It is perfectly appropriate under those circumstances to proceed on the basis that someone who might potentially be liable under one reading of these sections ought to get the benefit of any doubt as to the conduct of a prosecution in relation to that. It is a well understood and traditional ground of considering the criteria for discretion to prosecute. It is one that I applied without any apology in this case and I make no apology now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Treasurer advise the Senate whether the employment and unemployment figures released today by the Australian Bureau of Statistics are consistent with Government forecasts made in the 1983 Budget? Is the Government satisfied with the progress being made in the labour force? What does the Government believe is the outlook for the employed and the unemployed for the rest of this financial year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The monthly ABS statistics have been somewhat erratic recently. Therefore, it would be a bit rash, I think, to draw unequivocal conclusions from the figures for any month. Nevertheless, the most recent statistics harden the trend which has been apparent for some time. Senator Ray's specific question was : Are the latest figures consistent with the Government's Budget forecasts. The latest employment figures are not consistent with the Government's Budget forecast because employment has grown at a very much faster rate, according to the most recent statistics, than was anticipated at the time of the Budget. In other words, should the most recent figures be confirmed in subsequent months, the Government's estimate at the time of the Budget was conservative. That was in marked contrast to the estimates that this Government's predecessor used to make about all sorts of favourable economic matters.

ANSWER.PARA: For the eight months since March 1983, total unemployment on a seasonally adjusted basis has increased by almost 100,000. The Government's Budget forecast for the whole year, if I remember correctly, was for about 90,000. That is in marked contrast to the eight months prior to the present Government coming to office when, again, on a seasonally adjusted basis, the total number of persons employed fell by 127,000. In the eight months of this Government, the seasonally adjusted unemployment figure has gone up by almost 100,000; in the last eight months of the previous Government the seasonally adjusted figure fell by 127,000 . We have not quite yet compensated for the damage which the previous Government did in its last eight months. However, we are approaching that figure.

As I said, the statistics have been somewhat erratic in recent months but they are following a consistent trend. That trend has been hardened by the most recent figures. Since the trough in employment in April to the most recent figure-that is, the figure for the end of November-employment has grown by 126, 000 which is, as I said, considerably in excess of the expectations and forecasts of the Government at the time the Budget was delivered.

The final part of Senator Ray's question concerned the prospects for the future . There seems little doubt that, for the immediate future, the prospects are good. That does not mean, of course, that unemployment will disappear overnight or even in one or two years. That is not a reasonable expectation. There is now a reasonable expectation that over the next 12 months or so there will be a very marked growth in employment and even, perhaps, a substantial decrease in the unemployment rate which has already fallen by almost one per cent in the last two months. The unemployment rate, of course, reflects other factors as well. But, for the longer term, the view of the Government, which has consistently been put by the economic spokesman and the Prime Minister over the last eight or 12 months, is that the crucial factor will be whether the prices and incomes accord is honoured. That was emphasised again today by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Ralph Willis, who, in his official comment on these figures, said:
For the growth in the labour demand to be maintained there must be firm adherence by both employers and employees to the guidelines of the Prices and Incomes Accord.

That is the view of the Government. Probably the most important factor, now that we have a stable and reliable government in power as distinct from the situation which existed 12 months ago, is the honouring of the prices and incomes accord. The Government intends to stress to all sections of the community that that matter is crucial.

TALK.START.PARA: —I again refer the Attorney-General to the opinion that he has been waving around, which he gave to the Prime Minister on 29 August, as to whether a breach of the Crimes Act could result from the conversation between Mr Mick Young and Mr Eric Walsh on 21 April this year. I ask the Attorney to confirm to the Senate that the decision to exercise his discretion not to prosecute Mr Young was substantially based on his view that the political sanction of resignation was more appropriate than the penalty provided for in the criminal law, that is, a possible two-year gaol term, as well as the constitutional penalty that would be exacted of Mr Young if he were prosecuted and convicted of an offence under that section, namely his expulsion from this Parliament. Now that the Prime Minister has said that he welcomes Mr Young's return to the Ministry, will the Attorney-General agree that the political sanction on which he placed so much weight, shortlived as that sanction was, has now been removed? In light of that removal and the substantial difference, therefore, between the circumstances now and the circumstances set out in this opinion, will he now reconsider his decision not to prosecute Mr Young?

—It is the case that the availability of the political sanction of resignation was one of the criteria I took into account. It was the fourth mentioned out of four criteria that were discussed and applied in that opinion and I can assure Senator Chaney that my answer would have been exactly the same had those considerations not been relevant at all. Of course, it is a matter of judgment as to whether or not one takes the view that the period of time that Mr Young has been out of very senior ministerial office in this country is such as to amount to the kind of resignation that would satisfy everyone. All I can say is that on all the available evidence, six months absence from the Ministry in all the circumstances is something that appeals overwhelmingly to reasonable and fair-minded Australians as a very serious sanction indeed. That penalty, that sanction, has been suffered, has been experienced, and I think the extent and significance of it should be treated with rather more consideration than the insensitive characters on the other side of this chamber seem able to do.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I simply ask the Attorney-General to confirm that in this important respect the facts as they were when he gave the opinion are no longer the facts now.

—It is the case that Mr Young has still not been restored to the Ministry. He has resigned and will remain out of the Ministry until such time as a place is available. To that extent the facts have not changed at all.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN SECURITY INTELLIGENCE ORGANISATION: PRODUCTION OF DOCUMENTS

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Attorney-General to a decision in the High Court of Australia last Friday ruling that the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation produce documents relevant to a Mr Seary, a key witness at the trial of three members of the Ananda Marga religious sect. I note that the Court further provided that the Attorney-General could object to the production of the documents or of any one of the documents. In view of the obvious importance of these considerations to the fair trial of the three people involved and in light of the Attorney-General's stated position on these matters, can he say whether or when he will make any such documents available to the High Court?

—It is not my intention to object to the production of any documents that ASIO may prove to have that bear upon the subject matter of this trial. Some attention is being given at the moment to digging out such material as there may be on this and I understand something will come to me in the form of a draft affidavit either later today or tomorrow. That has always been my position in relation to the production of documents. I know that the previous Attorney-General took a different view. I thought it was appropriate for that view to be tested in the High Court in order that the fundamental issues of public policy that were here involved might be resolved.
—Do you mean you have made up your mind without seeing the document?

—Okay, I will insert a further phrase-on what I know about the nature of any documents that might be possessed and the way in which those documents have been reported to me. It is not my intention to take the threshold objection in principle that Senator Durack took, that not under any circumstances should any document coming from within ASIO be produced to the Court. I do not happen to share that particular view of the world.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate: Has the Government decided to withdraw its application to the Federal Court of Australia for the de-registration of the Australian Building Construction Employees and Builders Labourers Federation unions--
—There is only one.

—I am sorry; union-when this matter resumes in Melbourne on Monday , 12 December 1983? Have employers in the building industry advised the Government that the undertakings of good behaviour suggested by this union and the Australian Council of Trade Unions provide no guarantee of future industrial good behaviour and most likely would be viewed as inappropriate by the Federal Court? I ask the Minister whether at the Vosti conference on 30 June, when Commissioner Vosti read out a telex from the Minister, Mr Norm Gallagher, the General Secretary of the union, said to Commissioner Vosti and three departmental officers-I quote him although I understand I have to delete an expletive:

QUESTION.PARA: I am not going to take this-
this is a deletion-
The Labor Party has welched on the deal with us. They took $20,000 to pull out the de-registration.
I ask further whether the minutes of the Vosti conference record that outburst by Mr Gallagher as:
He vehemently objected to the wording of the telex and accused the Government of breaking undertakings given to the BLF.
Has the Government now decided to honour its undertaking given prior to the last election?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know anything about any undertakings referred to by Mr Gallagher, allegedly given prior to the last election. I do not believe there were any such undertakings in the form which Senator Lewis suggested in the way he has couched his question. I am not personally aware of whether a telex was sent to the Vosti inquiry on 30 June from Mr Norm Gallagher in the terms which Senator Lewis had indicated. Might I say, however, that the wording which Senator Lewis read into his question sounds strangely familiar to me and I would have no doubt at all that Norm Gallagher said something like that, particularly with the expletive included.

ANSWER.PARA: I make the point that since 30 June the situation in relation to the building industry, including negotiations in the building industry, has come a very long way in terms of discussions which have taken place regarding the building industry agreement, undertakings that have been given by the BLF and undertakings that have been given by the ACTU in relation to those undertakings given by the BLF. I might also say that the situation in the construction industry has considerably improved. Those improvements have occurred as a result of the intervention of the Government in discussions on the building industry agreement and by the Government trying to obtain a better industrial relations situation in this industry. It is no tremendous comfort to Senator Lewis or anybody else to discuss what happened on 30 June or what Mr Gallagher said on that day.

If I might be unassisted by the clamorous multitude, Mr President, this Government has moved quite fast in relation to the situation in the building industry and to industrial peace in that industry since then. The first part of Senator Lewis's question asked whether the Government had made a decision in principal on withdrawing its participation in the deregistration proceedings against the Builders Labourers Federation. The answer to that part of the question is yes.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question which is directed to the Leader of the Government, is a good news question. Is it true that the national account figures posted today show a remarkable 4.4 per cent increase in gross national product for the September quarter? Does that performance indicate that Budget projections have been too modest and should now be revised to provide a bolder but on these results more realistic target? Taken together with the dramatic turnaround on the employment front, do these results vindicate the Hawke Government's economic strategy, and will the Government now invite the Opposition to cease its carping and senseless irrelevancies and, in tune with the good-will sentiments of this time of the year, back the Government's economic strategy.
—And refer to capital expenditure, won't you?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am asked a question by way of interjection. It is actually Senator Cook's question but Senator Chaney is piggybacking again and I will deal with his interjection first. The situation in relation to capital investment in Australia is disastrous and it has been now for 10 years. The Government, on the basis of the answer which I am going to give to Senator Cook's question, hopefully can look forward to an improvement next year in the capital investment situation, but the projections are not very satisfactory. If one looks at the situation of capital investment, particularly in the manufacturing industry in the last decade-
—Try the last quarter.

—He says: 'Try the last quarter'. I will try the two quarters before that if he wants me to. The point about it is that I take it that Senator Chaney's interjection is an expression of concern, rather than nitpicking, about the level of capital investment in Australia and I am saying that I share the concern. I believe the Government has taken all the steps that were available to it in the budgetary context to encourage an increased level of capital investment in this country.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Cook asked me an intelligent question, if I might say so; a concerned and genuine question as distinct from the piggybacking which Senator Chaney indulged in. Insofar as Senator Cook's question is concerned, I do not think the Government has been too modest about its achievements. I do not think a government can be too modest about these things. I think it is important that a note of caution be engendered in all the considerations of the figures which are now available and which have been available in the last couple of months in relation to improving employment trends and the national accounts figures to which Senator Cook referred. I do not think it is any time for any government to be throwing its hat in the air. What I would say is simply that in our view the task which we set out to achieve when we were elected is showing progress. We are showing progress in respect of that task which we set out to achieve and we will go on doing that. I do not invite the Opposition to abandon any different views it might have. I am delighted to find it is reduced today to talking about capital investment, because that is the only statistic which looks bad in the current picture.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very significant.

—Of course it is very significant, and I acknowledged that earlier in my remarks. Let me just make these points: The national account figures published today show that growth has resumed in the Australian economy in the September quarter at an annual rate of 9.1 per cent in respect of non- farm gross domestic product. Indeed that is a rate of advance that has not been seen in Australia since the December quarter of 1981, and it contrasts very sharply with the contractions in the economy recorded in six of the preceding eight quarters. Senator Chaney will no doubt, by way of interjection, want to tell us which six they were. I believe these things are a manifestation of confidence in the Government's policies. For example, I do not get up here and pretend that the fact the drought has ended is not significant, but these things are a manifestation of confidence in the Government's policies which is seen in a wide range of figures, including, for example, consumer confidence and things of that kind which have been published in the last month or so. These do reflect confidence in the Government's policies and put the lie to those pessimists who have consistently queried the soundness of the Government's approach. That approach is built upon a realistic incomes and prices policy coupled with responsible fiscal and exchange rate policies. The national accounts also show a welcoming decline in the broadly based measures of inflation.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not want to refer to the details of that but I will do so, of course, if anybody wants me to. I appreciate that sometimes answers to questions in this place are too long, just as questions are too long and sometimes the answers are painful and I do not want to inflict pain on anybody today because, as Senator Cook said at the start of his question, it is a good news day.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Attorney-General to a report in today's Age newspaper which quotes his spokesman as having said: 'The only reason we're not printing the No case is that no rational person would vote against the proposals'. I ask the Attorney-General whether he authorised this comment? In any event will he withdraw this gratuitous insult to the intelligence and integrity of millions of Australians who will undoubtedly vote No when the proposals to change the Constitution are put to the people in February?

—I do not recall authorising the comment in question. In fact it is not one that I would make. There are rational arguments that can be put into a reasonable public debate on all the matters in issue in the referendums. The point, however, is that we have not heard any of them from this place and certainly not from the honourable senator who asked the question.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the Attorney -General withdraw this gratuitous insult to the intelligence and integrity of the millions of Australians who will undoubtedly vote No when the proposals to change the Constitution are put to them in February?

—I did not make a gratuitous insult to thousands of Australians; I made a calculated insult to one honourable senator opposite. I do not propose to withdraw the latter and there is nothing to withdraw as far as the former.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General and refers to a matter which I have raised previously regarding current legislation for home video movies and the need to ensure that appropriate censorship is practised where children are concerned. Is the Attorney aware of a recent British research report on videos and children which found that children rerun the most bloodthirsty and violent sequences and that four out of 10 children aged five and six have seen videos showing scenes of sadistic sex and horrific violence? Is the Attorney aware that similar practices as found in the British study are occurring in Australia? Can he advise whether special consideration has now been given to drawing the attention of consumers to the dangers associated with children viewing certain kinds of material?

—I understand my Department is aware of the existence of this report but has not yet been able to obtain a copy as one is not yet available in Australia. As soon as it is I will certainly make it my business to look at it. The proposed uniform Commonwealth-State censorship classification scheme, which is due to be introduced on 1 February-there still needs to be some further discussion in the light of recent events in South Australia, but to my knowledge it is going into place elsewhere around the country-will ensure that guidance is available to parents on the contents of the extremely violent video cassettes which are referred to in the report and it will ensure that children will not be able to buy or hire them as a result of point of sale controls which are part of this particular scheme. There is a difficulty of course about such video cassettes being purchased nonetheless by adults and being taken into the home environment. Under those circumstances, I think one simply has to say that it is the responsibility of parents to ensure that their children are not exposed to offensive or potentially harmful material of this kind.

—I ask a question of the Attorney-General, which follows one I asked him last Wednesday concerning allegations in a National Times article about Australian Federal Police reports based on phone taps applied to a Sydney solicitor in 1980. I ask: Has he received the extra information he said he would seek from the Special Minister of State regarding these serious allegations? Is he now in a position to assure the Senate that the allegations have been or will be thoroughly investigated and that appropriate action has been or will be taken if it is found there have been breaches of Commonwealth law?

—The short answer is: No, I have not received the further information I have sought from the Special Minister of State in this respect. As soon as I do I will ensure that it is made available to the honourable senator, or released publicly if it is the kind of information that does in fact lend itself to that treatment. I assure him that, if there are any revelations of breaches of the law, the appropriate steps will be taken.
—Unless it is a friend.

—I am sorry; I have just picked up the substance of an interjection, 'Unless it is a friend', from Senator Archer. Mr President, I ask you to require Senator Archer to withdraw that palpably offensive interjection.
—I did not hear the interjection, but if Senator Archer made it-
—I made it. I am sorry, Mr President, but I missed the point of the request.
—It is obvious that Senator Evans regards it as an infringement of standing Order 418. I ask the honourable senator, in view of Senator Evans's objection, to withdraw.

—Mr President, I will assist the honourable senator's, if that is the appropriate description, recollection of this matter by reminding him that as I sat down I was saying that the Government would take appropriate steps to enforce the law if any evidence of breaches of the law became available . The interjection which then flowed was: 'Unless it is a friend'. That is manifestly, in that context, extremely offensive, quite unparliamentary and I ask that you request it to be withdrawn.

—I take a point of order. We had a long statement read to us in this place on behalf of the Government by Senator Button which indicated that the Government was withdrawing what it regarded as a sanction against Mr Young on the basis of his service to the Australian Labor Party, what a fine chap he was and all the rest. That seemed to me, Mr President, to be a quite clear statement that those matters of the personal characteristics and the association with the Labor Party that Mr Young had had were matters which influenced the Government in its decision as to whether or not sanctions would be applied. I see that as being no different from the point which was made by Senator Archer in his comment.
—Order! Senator Evans has asked for a withdrawal. I therefore ask Senator Archer under standing order 418 to comply with that request.
—I am happy to comply.
—Thank you.

—I address a question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. As the Christmas season approaches, what jurisdiction does the Government have in relation to monitoring the sale of children's toys throughout Australia? Are all Australian made toys checked to ensure that they are physically safe and do not constitute any risk when handled by young children? In particular, what procedures are adopted to guarantee that imported toys are subject to close scrutiny before being made available to the community?

—The Commonwealth has various powers, although not exclusive powers, over the supply of children's toys to the domestic Australian market. Monitoring is performed using the product safety provisions of the Trade Practices Act, the Quarantine regulations and the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations. A regular program is carried out by the Commonwealth, State and Territorial authorities to test the toxicity, constructional and flammability safety requirements for toys. The Australian Toy Association, which is the local sales body, assists with this testing program. All complaints about toy safety are investigated and all toys supplied in Australia are monitored by the Commonwealth-State Consumer Products Advisory committee. Toys subject to bans under the Trade Practices Act and the Customs Act are restricted from entering Australia by the Australian Customs Service in accordance with its normal procedures for examing imported goods.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed.
Proposed new clause 28A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee is considering proposed new clause 28A to which Senator Walters has moved an amendment concerning advisory jurisdiction. The question before the Chair is: 'That the amendment moved by Senator Walters be agreed to'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was, I think, in the middle of a sentence when the debate was adjourned to enable the rapid passage of another Bill through the Parliament. I have just a few other things to say about Senator Walters's amendment. I think I should go back for a moment to the Government's draft and refer to one other matter I have raised. I said that I believe the Government's draft is inaccurate not only because of the use of the words 'more easily' but also because it deals with obtaining from the High Court its views on certain constitutional questions. That also is inaccurate because the Bill deals with questions arising from the application of section 45 of the Constitution. Those questions could not properly be described as constitutional questions. Everything, of course, is done under the Constitution. However, these questions are not concerned with the validity or otherwise of such acts. The legislation will also deal with matters arising out of treaties. Of course, the description of constitutional questions is so vague. I thought that this was the thing that the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) said the Government wanted to get away from. In fact, I think the legislation becomes vaguer by the use of this language.

SPEECH.PARA: Before the debate was adjourned, I was dealing with Senator Walters's amendment which I think, likewise, is an incorrect description of the Bill. It is a long one. I, of course, urge that what we ought to do is get back to the long title which, though called long title, merely says: 'An Act to alter the Constitution so as to confer an advisory jurisdiction on the High Court'. Senator Harradine's proposed amendment, which is in the same words, contains a description even shorter than that. I believe he may not move his amendment. I hope that one could take over that amendment because I think it ought to be put to a vote before the Committee. I think that Senator Harradine's amendment is better. I think the public knows what is meant by advisory opinions or advisory powers. That has been discussed.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are living in a world of your own. What does ' jurisdiction' mean to most people?

—I agree that I am living in a world of my own. I am living in a world of reason which has deserted very much this chamber in the last few days. I am content to live in that rather than in the world in which many other people are living. However, I believe it is well worth trying to get accuracy into the question which is to be put before the people. I do not think that the wording will make a great deal of difference because people will be reading documents and hearing arguments and they will know generally what is involved. I do not think, therefore, that the wording of the question is of tremendous importance. It is rather more important to ensure that a proposal is not criticised because it does not accurately describe the position.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Walters's rather lengthy amendment proposes to give power to the Commonwealth, the States and the Northern Territory to seek advice from the High Court as to the full extent of their powers under the Constitution. That clearly is not true. It is not an accurate description of the Bill at all. The Bill, the title of which includes the words 'advisory jurisdiction of the High Court', is not concerned with the full extent of the power of the Commonwealth, the States and the Northern Territory. It will probably, if used, be used very often sparingly in regard to certain parts of their powers and whether certain parts of a Bill have constitutional validity or not. The legislation certainly does not involve the full extent of their powers. I appeal to any honourable senators of reason to let us have it simple, let us stick as far as possible to the long title and let us not go into either the drafts of the Government or Senator Walters, both of which are quite inaccurate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I was just wondering whether you could tell us how you are going to deal with the amendments. Will you be putting my amendment and then Senator Harradine's amendment? Does Senator Missen have an amendment?
—No, I will seek leave to take over Senator Harradine's if he does not move his.

—There is no need for Senator Missen to seek leave. If Senator Harradine, for any reason, does not move his amendment, Senator Missen is perfectly entitled to move a similar amendment. The sequence will be that I will put Senator Walters's amendment. If that fails, I will give Senator Harradine the opportunity to move his amendment. The question is: 'That the amendment moved by Senator Walters to proposed new clause 28A be agreed to'.
—Senator Harradine, do you wish to pursue your amendment?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — Yes, Mr Chairman. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (6) Proposed new clause 28A, proposed Forms 1, 2 and 3, leave out 'To enable the Commonwealth, the States and the Northern Territory more easily to obtain from the High Court its views on certain constitutional questions.' (wherever occurring), insert 'To confer an advisory jurisdiction on the High Court.'

My preferred position, of course, was for Senator Walters's amendment. However, we have been told that there is a technical problem. I believe my amendment expresses the proposal in more accurate terms than the wording used by the Government. The Government is proposing to use the words 'more easily' in regard to the advisory jurisdiction. Of course, as had been explained by Senator Missen quite adequately-and I will sit down so that he can do so again-we cannot have the people voting that the Constitution be altered so as to provide to governments the power more easily to obtain advisory opinions, when governments do not now have power to seek such opinions and are not able to exercise any such power in the manner provided for in the Bill. It just does not make sense. I rest my case on that.

TALK.START.PARA: —It makes sense to me. The language is 'To enable the Commonwealth, the States and the Northern Territory more easily to obtain from the High Court'-not advisory opinions, which it does not have the power to do at the moment as Senator Harradine points out, but rather 'its views on certain constitutional questions'. That is what it does do. It enables the Commonwealth, the States and the Northern Territory to obtain more easily the views of the High Court. Declaratory proceedings are available at the moment. What is now suggested represents a much easier procedure. I do not accept Senator Harradine's amendment, essentially for the reason that I have explained by way of interjection: It is not language which is comprehensible to the ordinary, average Australian. If Senator Harradine's amendment were to prevail, the heading on the ballot paper would be: '4. ADVISORY JURISDICTION OF HIGH COURT'. That would be followed by the words 'To confer an advisory jurisdiction on the High Court'. So, instead of having just one heap of gobbledegook, which we have at the moment, we would have two. Under the proposed Government form we have what will appear to many people to be the gobbledegook of the short title, but at least it will be followed by concrete language which is apt to describe the procedure here involved and the change involved in it. I commend it to the Committee without further argument.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The wording of this question is no different from the wording of the other questions, in that it is thoroughly misleading. Nobody in a booth, preparing to cast a vote and reading this, could reasonably understand its ramifications. It does not give any indication that it refers to proposed laws. It gives the impression very clearly that such a power already exists and that the purpose is simply to make exercising it easier. The power is not there.
—There is a power to seek declaratory judgments.
—If the Government is satisfied with declaratory judgments, why does it need advisory opinions?
—It needs to be done more easily.

—It is a different and stronger power, a power that the Government at present does not have. So it is not making easier, or facilitating , what is already available; it is not available, it is a new proposition. The langugage proposed gives no one an indication that the High Court of Australia will be sitting in judgment on legislation passed by the Parliament prior to that legislation being proclaimed. Nobody with average intelligence, reading the proposal, could be drawn to the conclusion that that is what is intended. As I said earlier in the day, the Government's contention is that we should not have the long title because it could be misleading, confusing and in many cases would not indicate the real intent. It is my view that the Government's proposed wording gives even less indication, is more misleading and is more likely to attract a Yes vote. It is certainly a mischievous way of putting questions and is distorting them which, it has been the argument of the Government all the way through, should not occur. The proposition, as it would be amended by Senator Harradine, would much more accurately reflect the intentions of the Government on this proposal.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply rise to seek information from the Attorney-General. Now that these questions are enshrined, what is the status of the regulations, bearing in mind that at least one of the questions, as now contained in the legislation, differs from those contained in the regulations?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I regard it as being clear, as a matter of law, that the regulations are superseded by the terms of the Bill. If that is not clear, if I have it wrong, I assure the honourable senator that the form of the ballot paper will be in accordance with today's debate rather than with the regulations themselves. Certainly, there is no intention to proceed with the regulations.
—Are the regulations thereby withdrawn?
—I do not know whether they are withdrawn automatically, but I suppose we can ensure that they are.

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed new clause 28A, as amended, agreed to.
Clause 29 agreed to.
Proposed new clause 30.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (10) Page 13, after clause 29 insert the following new clause:
Operation of Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918, &c., in relation to a referendum

30. (1) The succeeding provisions of this section shall have effect after the commencement of the Commonwealth Electoral Legislation Amendment Act 1983 (in this section referred to as the 'Amending Act').
(2) For the purposes of a referendum-

(a) the amendments made by the Amending Act to the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918, other than the amendments made by sections 3, 4, 5, 7, 8 and 150 of the Amending Act, shall be deemed not to have been made; and

(b) the Referendum (Constitution Alteration) Act 1906, the regulations referred to in sub-section (3) and the regulations that were, immediately before the commencement of the Amending Act, in force under the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 and the Referendum (Constitution Alteration) Act 1906, shall have effect accordingly.
(3) Notwithstanding the repeals effected by section 151 of the Amendment Act-

(a) the Australian Capital Territory Representation Regulations that were, immediately before the commencement of the Amending Act, in force under the Australian Capital Territory Representation (House of Representatives) Act 1973; and

(b) the Northern Territory Electoral Regulations that were, immediately before the commencement of the Amending Act, in force under the Northern Territory Representation Act 1922 and the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918,
shall continue in force for the purposes of a referendum.

(4) For the purposes of the application, in relation to a referendum, of any law of the Commonwealth or of a Territory, or any order or instrument under any such law, in relation to anything done or to be done after the commencement of the Amending Act-

(a) a reference to the Australian Electoral Office shall be read as a reference to the Australian Electoral Commission established under the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 as amended by the Amending Act;

(b) a reference to the Chief Australian Electoral Officer or to the Chief Electoral Officer for the Commonwealth shall be read as a reference to the Electoral Commissioner appointed under that Act as so amended;

(c) a reference to a Commonwealth Electoral Officer for a State or to an Australian Electoral Officer for a State shall be read as a reference to the Australian Electoral Officer for the State appointed under that Act as so amended;

(d) a reference to a Returning Office, in relation to a Division of the Australian Capital Territory or in relation to the Northern Territory, shall be read as a reference to the Divisional Returning Officer for that Division or that Territory, as the case may be; and

(e) a reference to a Registrar, in relation to a Subdivision, shall be read as a reference to the Divisional Returning Officer for the Division of which that Subdivision is part or, if an Assistant Divisional Returning Officer has been appointed for that Subdivision, to that Assistant Divisional Returning Officer.

The purpose of this amendment is simply to accommodate some technical problems that flow from the fact that we now have in force, as a result of the successful passage of the electoral legislation, amendments to the Commonwealth Electoral Act. However, it is not proposed that every single aspect of that new legislative arrangement be applicable to the February referendum. For example, the Electoral Commission will not have been established by that point in time and we need to pick and choose our way through those provisions in the new electoral law as it stands which are applicable to the conduct of the referendum , and those which are not. Proposed new clause 30 is designed to achieve that result. It is a purely technical amendment and I hope that it can be supported accordingly.
Proposed new clause agreed to.
Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole, and agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Gareth Evans) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 7 December 1983, on motion by Senator Button:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the third start that I have made on my speech on the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill (No. 2) and I hope that it will be a case of third time lucky. When I last addressed the Senate on the subject I was dealing with what the draftsman chose to call the rationalisation of industrial tribunals, which is legalese for bringing the Public Service Arbitrator within the ambit of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. The significance of that change I had gone into in some detail but the point that I wanted to make before I leave that alteration is that while the Bill does that it also restores to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission a number of powers dealing with staff selection, employment and promotion, and removes provisions on stand-downs and no work as directed no pay. This legislation provides that public employees will be treated in the same way as private industry employees. When industrial disputes arise they can be taken before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The Commission can deal with them as it sees fit and issue whatever directions it thinks are appropriate without building into the legislation what amounts to penal clauses for public servants. I think that is a significant change. It was supported by the Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration in 1976. That Commission recommended changes similar to those in this legislation. The National Labour Consultative Council also supported these amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: There is, of course, recognition in these amendments of what has developed as the normal procedure of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in having the Public Service Arbitrator sitting on major cases such as the national wage case and other major test cases. That procedure has evolved over time. I point out the significant dates in that evolution process. In 1952 appeals to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission were introduced from the Public Service Arbitrator. In 1956 the hearings of some cases were transferred to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. In 1972 the Public Service Arbitrator was put in a position in which he could deal with industrial action and so on. The introduction of these amendments is the culmination of a long evolution of powers to the Public Service Arbitrator which have caused that office to resemble more closely the Commission. It is apt and appropriate at this time that there should be a bringing together of those two bodies recognising, of course, that the Public Service Arbitrator's office is preserved as a discrete section within the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.

Having made those remarks I turn to another section of the Bill that I think is worthy of some comment. I refer to the provisions which deal with the financial accounting and reporting of organisations. The provisions that are subject to amendment in this legislation were included in the Conciliation and Arbitration Act by the previous Fraser Government. Those provisions resulted in long discussions being held by members of the National Labour Consultative Council. Whilst those provisions were not supported by representatives of the unions at those discussions nonetheless a considerable amount of progress was made in tuning the Fraser Government's proposals so that they were more acceptable. I suppose that there was resigned acceptance that the Government would wreak its will and, in that case, the union movement-it was the prime target of the amendments-felt that it should be done in a way which would make the unions feel comfortable with the amendments. One of the points that came out of the NLCC consultations was that there ought to be a monitoring of how the financial accounting provisions proceeded and that, therefore, at the end of a reasonable period of monitoring there should be a preparedness by the Government to make appropriate changes to the legislation. We are now at the end of such a period. It is now appropriate to make some changes based on the performance of those provisions.

In looking at financial accounting and the reporting of organisations to their members about their balance sheets and financial affairs, essentially two points arise. The first point is that the accounts must be properly compiled and accurately reported. The second point is that all members of the organisation should have access to those accounts. Bearing in mind those two principals, we can see that the provisions in the legislation before the chamber this afternoon base themselves on that understanding. They are also based on the fact that if the accounts are badly reported in normal accountancy layout members of some unions may not be able to comprehend the full importance and meaning of those accounts. Therefore, the accounts in their complete detail may serve to confuse or obfuscate the understanding of what is the real financial position of an organisation. These amendments require that a simplified and understandable version of the accounts should be produced and, importantly, that any simplified and more comprehensible series of documentation based on an organisation's accounts must go before the auditor and be approved as being a due and accurate copy of the accounts.

I now turn to another section of the Bill which has attracted some opposition from the other side of the chamber. I refer to the provisions dealing with disqualification from office. The first point I make about disqualification from office-this section was put in the Act again by the previous Government-is that the Hawke Government has announced an inquiry into the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, which will be chaired by Professor Hancock. That inquiry will be dealing in greater detail and more comprehensively with the whole subject of disqualification from office. Despite that inquiry it is appropriate that there be some remedy of the anomalies and inconsistencies that exist in the present prescription. We need not wait until the Hancock inquiry has been able to report to do some gardening of the provisions and weed out the inconsistencies and anomalies. There is not total agreement amongst members of the NLCC in relation to the changes that the Government proposes. I make what I think is a reasonable observation of the state of play between the parties represented on the NLCC. While organisationally, the NLCC is bound by particular policies to resist some of the changes that are being proposed, there is a recognition that the role of government is to propose reasonable compromise. Although policies might hold parties back from being able to commit themselves to that compromise, there is an acceptance that the compromise is reasonable. Although there is not a formal commitment to the proposals there is acceptance. I do not think that acceptance is attended by any bitterness or rancour.

As I have said, the Fraser Government put these offences into the Act last year . The offences deal, in the event of a person being convicted, with disbarment from holding office for a period of five years. The amendments to the Act which the Government is proposing will reduce the number of offences and modify the types of offences that can occur. Essentially, the offences that remain as offences for disbarment are those relating to ballots and elections. I think it is appropriate that they continue. The remark can be made about the offences that the Government proposes to move from the Act that they represent the overkill of the previous Government in trying to manipulate the Conciliation and Arbitration Act so that it would become an Act of penalties for industrial disputation rather than, as the title of the Act implies it should be, an Act for the conciliation and arbitration of disputes. The penalties we are seeking to remove had the unreasonable and unfair effect of applying two penalties for one offence. Nearly all the penalties we are seeking to excise from the Act were capable of resulting in directions or orders from the Commission, the contravention of which would of itself be an offence. It is unreasonable to load on top of an offence that could probably be dealt with by the Commission, a further offence which would have the result of disbarring someone from office, thereby removing his livelihood and, in fact, penalising the one 'crime' twice.

There is, I suppose, a quite clear distinction between the philosophy of the former Government and the Hawke Government on this matter. The Hawke Government believes that the Conciliation and Arbitration Act should be devoted to preventing and settling industrial disputes. It should not be an Act which beats one party around the head with massive doses of penalties which add a second tier of dispute to the original dispute which gave rise to the actions that attracted the penalities. This complicates the mess even more and leads to continuing disputation. Rather than take the big stick approach we seek to amend the current Act to provide that disbarment can occur for offences associated with ballots and elections. In our view, disbarment should occur for such offences, but it should not occur for matters that can reasonably be dealt with by the Commission itself.

I make two supplementary points. If the current provisions were to be consistent with the Companies Act they would resemble what we now propose. When the Act was amended last year, the then Government applied penalties much more extensively to unions than it was prepared to apply to companies. The basic element of reasonable justice is that if offences are provided for in two Acts there ought to be a comparability and an equity between the level and type of those offences in both Acts. On that point, I also remark that if we, in various Acts of Parliament, apply offences to officers in companies and in unions or industrial organisations, we ought one day to look at office holders of political parties. If some of these offences applied in that context, the whole financial committee of the Liberal Party in Western Australia might then be penalised for bottom of the harbour activities and may be removed or disbarred from office. With those remarks, I draw the attention of honourable senators to the fact that there is a philosophical difference here and we seek an understanding that the Conciliation and Arbitration Act should be so designed as to facilitate the settlement and prevention of industrial disputes rather than aggravate them as the Fraser-inserted changes have the potential to do.

Finally I turn to the remarks made by Senator Walters dealing with the registration of organisations. Although I am nearly out of time, I wish to point out that Senator Walters has misunderstood the provisions dealing with the registration of organisations. We seek to provide that owner-drivers or sub- contractors who want to join organisations, typically the Transport Workers Union, can do so. The amendments are aimed at providing that facility for people who elect to join such an organistion. Senator Walters wanted to prevent people from joining that union at all. As we see it, that is a deprivation of rights. The argument is about whether or not such people are workers. I think quite clearly from the record they are and that they should therefore be able to join the union of their choice. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the general thrust of the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill (No. 2). We see the need for ongoing improvement and updating of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act as, obviously, does the Opposition. Much of the Bill's contents come from the previous legislation either planned or even introduced by the Opposition during its term of office. It is also good to see that the main thrust of the Bill is supported by the National Labour Consultative Council and that it takes on board some of the suggestions that came out of the Economic Planning Advisory Council discussions in this approach to removal or reduction of conflict in the industrial area. The fact that many of the previous Government's legislative proposals lapsed because of the calling of the election ahead of time was rather unfortunate for the people involved with industrial relations in Australia. We are pleased to see that the Government has very quickly got hold of the bulk of those legislative changes and is now introducing them. We hope that there will be further and even more dramatic changes to the arbitration system in the next sitting of Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I suggest two or three of those immediately. One obviously, is the passage of the industrial democracy legislation which has been lying around for far too long in this Parliament. It is an Australian Democrat's Bill, originally introduced by former Senator John Siddons and picked up by me as the first Bill that I introduced in this Parliament. I was rather hopeful that the Government would run with that and include it as part of the proposals in this package. But we will have to wait a little bit longer for that obviously. It is also sad to see that there are still no provisions for the introduction of fee for service, another area of great conflict within the industrial relations scene in Australia. But we live in hope and we keep getting promises from the Government that such legislation is just around the corner. Once more, the Australian Democrats will introduce private members Bills for that particular provision if the Government delays its introduction much longer.

The other good thing to hear from the Government is that there is an ongoing review not just by the National Labour Consultative Council, but also by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis), who has the responsibility for continuing the review and, in part, is doing that through the Hancock inquiry. That is to be applauded and the Australian Democrats hope that the Government moves rapidly to implement the changes that are seen as necessary and does not just let them lie on the back burner. One of the specific provisions which is causing a little difficulty is the removal of penalties for officers in unions. We have recognised that this is a contentious provision. Clause 23, which amends section 132F of the Act, reduces the range of offences which leads to disqualification. The offences would now be confined to elections or ballots and only crimes associated with damage or violence, intentionally committed, and resulting in a prison sentence will be offences which will be prescribed under the Act from here on. I think that is a fairly reasonable approach. Again, we do not see the other minor offences as requiring a double penalty, which was the situation under the Act.

I indicate to the Government our extreme disappointment at its inability or unwillingness-perhaps I should be fair at this stage and allow that it could be inability-to resolve the problems of owner-drivers in this country. These people have been for some time, and are now, under tremendous pressures. They do not seem to fit anywhere-either under the conciliation and arbitration system or under the trade practices system. They fall between these two stools. They suffer economic pressures as a result of increasing costs which in turn result in repossessions, bankruptcies, and too many vehicles on the road. Consequently, they are played off against each other causing damage not only in economic terms but also to life and limb, not just to the drivers themselves but, as we have seen, to other road users. At this moment the major transport companies have these owner-drivers by the short and curlies. They really have them at a distinct disadvantage and within their power. The fear that was expressed by the Opposition of the power of the unions to coerce these owner-drivers into joining a union is balanced by the fear that I express that these people are being squeezed by the major transport companies in this country. I will read into Hansard the specific approach which was made to the Australian Democrats and which, I understand, has been circulated to other honourable senators. It is contained in a telex which reads:
That section 22 of the Bill be amended by inserting after sub-clause (2) the following additional sub-section: (1A) Section 132 of the principal Act as amended by sub-section (1) is amended:
(a) by adding after sub-paragraph (1) (B) (ii) the following sub-paragraph:-

(iii) persons other than employees or employers who follow an occupation in or in connection with that industry of driving a motor vehicle required to be registered and/or approved under the laws of any State or Territory for use or intended use on any public street, road or highway including a motor vehicle for use or intended use beyond the limits of any one State or Territory.
(b) By adding after sub-paragraph (1) (C) (ii) the following sub-paragraph:-

(iii) persons other than employees or employers who are engaged in that industrial pursuit or one of those industrial pursuits in driving a motor vehicle required to be registered and/or approved under the laws of any State or Territory for use or intended use on any public street, road or highway, including a motor vehicle for use or intended use beyond the limits of any one State or Territory.
(c) By inserting in each paragraph (1) (B) and (1) (C) after the words 'sub- paragraph (ii)', the words 'or (iii)'.

I hope that you will forgive me for taking up the time of the Senate by reading that, Madam Acting Deputy President, but it was important to have it incorporated, because this has been a genuine attempt by the Transport Workers Union to resolve the problem of owner drivers. I regret that the Australian Democrats do not go along with this proposed resolution of the problem, because we see it as only a partial solution of the major problem of owner drivers. It would not be sufficient for them simply to be thrown into a union pool and to be part of that union. They must have their own association, with its own rights, its own rules and its own arbitration provisions, because they are unique in this country. They are different from the normal employee who would come under the normal conciliation and arbitration system.

Regrettably, therefore, we shall not be putting forward that proposal. I say ' regrettably' in the sense that there has been a genuine attempt to solve the problem by the TWU, but we do not see that as any more than a short term solution and we want to keep the pressure on the Government for the long term solution. I ask the Minister at the table, Senator Button, to agree and to indicate that the Government will agree to introduce legislation early next year which will give rights to owner-drivers to have an arbitration system which will resolve the massive problems with which they are faced these days. It needs a new approach. I understand that, according to the Minister, it is being investigated by the Government right now. All that I need is the nod from the Minister that we shall have that new and enlightened resolution of the owner- drivers' problems early in 1984.

I speak briefly about two other aspects of the Bill which deal with matters of concern, and for which I again applaud the Government on its action as they have created major disruptions and anxieties around Australia. The first is the provisions for more co-ordination between Commonwealth and State industrial systems. To those I am sure that most people around Australia will cry ' Hallelujah', because this will help to remove some anomalies but, much more importantly, it will reduce the potential for conflict. It is pretty much identical with the 1982 Bill, the Conciliation and Arbitration (Complementary Industrial Relations System) Amendment Bill of 1982, introduced by the previous Government, and it is based on the recommendations of a Commonwealth-State working party. So one would hope that that would have the support of all parties in the Senate.

The other slighly less supported item in the legislation is the Public Service arbitration system, which is now incorporated under the jurisdiction of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. There can be arguments pro and con on this matter; I have listened to them. But there is an overwhelming argument in favour of this movement of the powers towards Australia's national, universal conciliation and arbitration system. That is, that it will have the effect of removing some of the powers of government to get directly and immediately involved in industrial conflicts. Regrettably, that was the perception of many people when it was introduced, because it seemed to give the government of the day the opportunity to declare the Public Service as the enemy and to declare war on that enemy whenever there was an industrial dispute involving the Public Service.

The Government must be more remote from industrial activity at that early stage of conflict. The way to achieve that is to leave the Government out of it and to let the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and its system get on with the job of resolving conflict, until, ultimately, there is perceived to be no resolution in sight, at which stage it may be necessary for the Government to become involved in it. We have suffered in this country for several years from a government becoming one of the protagonists in the industrial relations system with the Public Service. That is not acceptable in the opinion of not only the Australian Democrats but the great majority of Australians, not just trade unionists and not just public servants.

This measure puts into effect the recommendations of the 1976 report of the Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration. It has taken a long while to have that report's recommendations implemented. It is a natural progression and is similar in many respects to provisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration (Government Service) Amendment Bill, which was introduced by the previous Government. As I understand it, it has the support of the National Labour Consultative Committee. The Bill will be supported by the Australian Democrats. I gather that that will ensure its passage through the Senate and through this Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I may interject a note of slight disharmony into this debate. Up to date, there has been a bit of back scratching going on about this legislation picking up some of the things that were proposed last year. I am glad that it does not pick up all of the things that were proposed last year by the previous Government. The Senate should be reminded that a number of issues that are now incorporated into this legislation were canvassed before the Senate Select Committee on Industrial Relations Legislation last year, and that had it not been for the report of that Committee to this Senate, this nation could well have faced industrial relations conflicts the like of which it had not seen in its history.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me remind those members of the previous Government now in opposition that their proposals, as brought forward to this Parliament and discussed last year, were a recipe of industrial anarchy and a direct attack on the principles of conciliation and arbitration and on the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission itself. That would have been the net result of their propositions last year had they been adopted, as they very nearly were, by this Senate. It was only because the Senate decided by a majority vote, against the vigorous opposition of the then Government, to establish a Senate select committee, that an opportunity was given to those in the industrial relations arena-to representatives of employers, to representatives of unions, to the departments and to other interested persons and bodies-to make submissions to this Committee and in an open and constructive way to present their submissions and support them before the Committee.

What these people had to say was very revealing. Let us never forget that what the then Government was proposing, in addition to one or two of the things that are now contained in this legislation, was to restructure the unions in Australia to impose from above a structure which would fit into the economic concepts of those who were in power last year; to impose on unions an industry- based structure; to abolish the long-standing provisions in the Conciliation and Arbitration Act which encourage unions and the formation of unions, and I refer to the provisions relating to preference; to provide further amendments which would create various offences and penalties; and, finally, to impose automatic stand-downs at times of industrial disputes. Those provisions were prescriptions for industrial disputation.

I refer honourable senators to the report of the Select Committee presented to the Parliament on 28 October-it may have been a week before but certainly the tabling speech was on 28 October-and the debate of 11 November last year. That was only a year ago. We could have been in the midst of industrial conflict. That Committee made certain recommendations and, insofar as the imposition of structures on the trade unions is concerned, the Committee was most forthright. Of course, it recognised that there was a problem in respect of a number of unions attempting to amalgamate. In particular, we received some very worthwhile evidence from the boot trade unions and the clothing trade unions. We made certain recommendations which this Government has since picked up. I do not know whether it was the chicken and the egg situation because a particular member was on the Committee, but the Government has picked up those recommendations although without one of the safeguards that we recommended.

On that occasion we noticed that, for the first time in such a forum as was provided by the Committee, various and indeed conflicting concepts of industry unionism were aired and the desirability of encouraging by legislation the development of industry-based unions was seriously questioned. The Committee stated:

The Committee is not opposed to industry-based unions. However after consideration of the submissions and evidence the Committee does not consider that the proposed legislation is the best method of providing changes in the structure of Australian trade union organization.
The Committee at paragraph 8 stated:
There is considerable doubt among the industrial relations community that union structures predominately determine industrial relations outcomes.
So far as the abolition of preference was concerned, the Committee stated:

The Committee notes that the Government intends that its proposed legislation will weaken the power of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to deal with union membership disputes. The Committee shares the view generally expressed by witnesses that the proposed legislation would not be conducive to industrial peace and would further unsettle the industrial relations climate

We adverted to the question that was raised by Senator Evans in his speech when he talked about the fee for service proposal. I refer the Senate to paragraphs 18 and 19 in which the Committee stated as follows:
The Committee notes further that the Government intends that its legislation ensure 'the protection of the rights of the individual'.
It went on:

Some individuals are quick to recognise their perceived rights but are not also as quick to recognise their duty to associate with others for the common good. In addition there is a distinction between personal choice based on conscientious belief on the one hand and the dictates of self-centered individualism on the other.

The Committee acknowledges the need to retain the status of conscientious objection to union membership which is presently provided in section 144A. However, it believes that a less fundamental objection to union membership should also be recognised, namely that a person holds principles or belief which prevent membership of unions.

I interpolate here that there were varying views on the Committee on these and other matters, but this was a consensus approach and indeed this was what the Committee said. I read it because, as Senator Evans said, the Government may bring something up. This was the decision of the Committee on which Senator Siddons from the Australian Democrats played a very worthwhile role. He not only took a very positive approach but also worked very hard on the Committee. The Committee also stated:
The Committee considers that such persons should be entitled to be exempted from membership provided that they contribute a fee for the services provided by the appropriate union, to that union.

These are the people who are not covered by the conscientious objection provisions already in the legislation. The Committee went on to say a number of other things as to how that should be managed, et cetera. I remind the Senate and Senator Jack Evans that these people are provided for in paragraph 19 of the report of the Senate Select Committee on Industrial Relations Legislation.

The Committee considered that the provisions of the Bill relating to stand- downs would not contribute to industrial peace but would create industrial instability. It was concerned that a situation could not go to an independent tribunal for consideration but that automatic rights would accrue to the employer to stand down employees. The Committee considered a number of other matters, some of which are contained in this legislation. I apologise for introducing this note of asperity but I think the record must be kept straight. I am concerned, though I do not know the precise details of it, that a situation could develop in Queensland whereby some persons who may be well motivated might be attempting to introduce industrial legislation in that State which would create industrial turmoil and disadvantage some of the very people within the trade union movement who are attempting to preserve the integrity of the trade union movement and not allow it to be used for overt political purposes. As I said, I have only heard this; I do not know about the legislation. If it is similar to that which was proposed by the former Liberal-National Party Government, then let them beware of that. Let them also consider what happened to governments in South Australia and in Western Australia which tried to interfere in the industrial relations climate in that fashion. What happened to those governments, of course, is a matter of record.

I turn to the matters that were considered by the Committee, some of which have found themselves in this legislation. The Committee gave full consideration to the matter of casual vacancies. The report states:

The Committee recommends the adoption of the provisions . . . insofar as it is designed to remove doubts in relation to the filling of casual vacancies under well established collegiate systems of electing officials of organizations of employers or employees.
However, the Committee recommends that the Government redraft the relevant provisions to enable the greater flexibility sought by major employer and union organizations.

Overall, the Committee recommended that the matters outstanding be considered by the National Labour Consultative Council. I am the first to say that there is nothing magical about the National Labour Consultative Council. All wisdom in the industrial relations arena does not repose in the National Labour Consultative Council.
