Nor does all wisdom repose in the Hancock Committee of Review into Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems. It will be most interesting to read its report when it comes down. As has been indicated in this chamber that report will be tabled in the Parliament before the Government takes any steps in respect thereof. Hopefully, during the time of that tabling, it will be open to debate in this chamber and in the House of Representatives. I hope that that debate will be constructive.

I welcome the provisions in this Bill which create a climate and a framework to facilitate the work of organisations responsible within the industrial relations arena. Before closing, I must say that the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations in the former Government, Mr Macphee, whilst not able to pull off the pack with which we were confronted in this chamber when we had our backs against the wall last year, nevertheless took cognisance of what was contained in the Senate Select Committee's report and, in fact, he, his advisers and others were able to convince the Government that the more disastrous elements of that legislation that had been proposed should be jettisoned. I will support the Bill during its second reading stage. Again, I believe that we should never forget what occurred last year. I certainly shall not. We should, from time to time, go over the report of the Senate Select Committee on Industrial Relations Legislation to see what came out of it and what the situation now is both in the industrial relations sphere and, might I say, in the political sphere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank Senator Harradine for his contributions to the debate. They were splendid reminders of things past which have relevance to the present and the future. I even found his contribution poetical and was reminded of this couplet of Tennyson:

SPEECH.PARA: Yet all experience is an arch wherethro'
Gleams that untravell'd world whose margin fades
For ever and for ever when I move.

I am looking at the Deputy President because he frequently corrects me on matters literary, but I think I have it right today. Generally, the debate has reflected a positive and constructive approach towards this legislation. The speakers pointed to the fact that the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill (No. 2) contains a number of amendments, many of which are, in a sense, fairly technical and are supported, generally, by all sides of the Parliament. The only comment that has been made is that perhaps some of the amendments should not have been dealt with at this stage because the Hancock Committee of Review into Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems is yet to complete its deliberations and so on. But I think the amendments are not ones which do anything but improve the legislation and should not greatly concern honourable senators.

I think there are important points to emphasise about the legislation such as the provision for greater co-ordination between Commonwealth and State tribunals . Again, that is a matter-I think Senator Harradine would agree-about which we can very much learn from the experience of the past. It is tremendously important that we increasingly rationalise the activities of industrial tribunal throughout Australia and this legislation is part of that process. One could not estimate the cost that has been incurred in this country in years gone by because of the failure to take these steps earlier. I am not just referring to the last decade; I am referring probably to the last 30 years. That is a very important aspect of the legislation.

The proposal to repeal the Public Service Arbitration Act and transfer jurisdiction to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission again is a proposal which in the Government's view provides further co-ordination and rationalisation of the activities of industrial tribunals. The Government's general view, which is reflected in our attitude to amendments which have been foreshadowed, is that as far as possible industrial disputes in the Public Service should be dealt with in the same way as they would be dealt with in the non-government sector of the economy. That aspect of the legislation reflects that view.

Mr Deputy President, I also referred earlier to a number of various tidying up and machinery provisions. Not all of the suggestions of the National Labour Consultative Council have been adopted by the Government. Senator Harradine made the point that that body is not the source of all wisdom. The casual vacancy provision in respect of which it advanced a view has not been adopted by the Government but generally those tidying up provisions have had the support of the employers and the unions, as reflected in the NLCC.

Senator Jack Evans made a contribution to the debate on the position of independent contractors and particularly owner-drivers. He asked me whether I would repeat in the Senate the undertaking given by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service and Industrial Matters (Mr Willis) simply that early next year the Government would bring forward legislation which will address the question of independent contractors and particularly owner-drivers as they fall within the scope of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act.

In the course of the debate honourable senators have touched on various aspects of the legislation which reflect a general agreement with it and of course a number of matters remain the subject of amendments to be moved in the Committee stage which reflect, I would think, residual disagreement around the margin, as it were, of matters which the Government has taken into account in the course of preparing this legislation. I do not think I can usefully add anything at this stage, and I commend the second reading of the legislation to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 to 13-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 14.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 10, clause 14, proposed new sub-section 70A (1), definition of 'industrial matter', at end of definition, add 'but does not include any matter or question relating to, or to the selection or procedures for the selection of persons for, appointment, re-appointment, employment or promotion in public service'.

I dealt with this amendment at some length in my remarks in the second reading debate. The reason for the amendment is that in the transfer to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission of jurisdiction over Commonwealth employees, which at present is exercised by the Public Service Arbitrator under the Public Service Arbitration Act, the Government has not in this Bill provided for any exceptions which preserve the traditional position of the Public Service Board in these matters and which were contained in the Fraser Government's Bill to give effect to the same basic proposal-namely, the transfer of jurisdiction from the Public Service Arbitrator to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission-and this means that the Bill will confer upon the Arbitration Commission a greater power than is presently exercised by the Public Service Arbitrator in matters of appointment and promotion in the Public Service.

So if this amendment is not carried there will be duality of control by the Public Service Board and the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in relation to the Public Service matters set out. We believe that that is undesirable. The Opposition has already stated its position on a number of occasions; it is in line with the policy we pursued when in government. We think it is desirable to obtain this residual jurisdication for the Public Service Board which it has traditionally exercised and that this transfer, which is otherwise strongly supported by the Opposition, should be subject to an amendment of this kind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government really is of the view that this amendment suffers from some degree of misconception. Certainly it is different in its approach. I just want to make a couple of points about it to indicate the Government's view. It is not intented that this legislation provide a method of removing the essential managerial functions of the Public Service Board and those thereunder who exercise managerial functions in respect of day to day matters. The Government's intention is that if an industrial dispute arises as a result of promotion appeals and so on, the Public Service should be on the same footing as the private and the non-Federal Government sectors and those industrial disputes should be dealt with by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. If we were to restrict the jurisdiction of the Arbitration Commission in the manner of the previous Government, it would be inconsistent with that approach of equity across the board in dealing with industrial disputation that the Government seeks to achieve by this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: In a sense the amendment represents-I do not wish to be pejorative about it- sort of half-baked retreat from the Government's position which is, as I say, to seek equity across the board in terms of the method of treatment of industrial disputation. I just make the point that the Opposition opposed this sort of restriction when it was introduced into the Public Service Arbitration Act in 1978. It is not the Government's intention that the Commission would get involved in appeal processes involving individual promotion or appointment decisions in the Public Service, or those sorts of things which are traditionally defined in the Arbitraton Commission legislation as matters of management. If, however, a matter of management, whether it be in the Public Service or in the private sector, leads to an industrial dispute situation, it is the Government's view that the Commission should have jurisdiction, and that is why the amendment is not acceptable to the Government and will be opposed.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move the second amendment on the sheet circulated:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Page 15, clause 14, proposed new sub-section 70J (2), lines 25 to 27, leave out the proposed sub-section, insert the following sub-sections:
'' '(2) The orders that may be made under sub-section (1) are-

(a) orders relating to conditions of employment of employees (whether members of an organization or not) who are concerned in or affected by, or are likely to be concerned in or affected by, the industrial action;

(b) orders directing the cessation of conduct by employees that constitute, or encourages the continuation of, the industrial action or prohibiting conduct by employees that would constitute or bring about the industrial action; or

(c) orders authorizing the standing down of employees (whether members of an organization or not) who are concerned in or affected by, or are likely to be concerned in or affected by, the industrial action.
'(3) Where an employee has been stood down under an order made under sub- section (2), he is not entitled, in respect of the stand-down period, to-

(c) any other allowances of a prescribed kind.

'(4) Where an employee has been stood down, under an order made under sub- section (2), from his employment in a qualifying service, within the meaning of the Long Service Leave (Commonwealth Employees) Act 1976, then, for the purposes of that Act, the continuity of that employment of the employee shall be deemed not to be, or to have been, broken by that stand-down period but the employee shall be deemed not to be, or to have been, employed in that service during that stand-down period.

shall be reduced, or further reduced, by a period equal to-

(d) in any other case the prescribed fraction of the period that that credit would have been if the employee had been an employee for the whole of the relevant period in relation to that credit and that credit was not required to be reduced in accordance with any other law,
for each working day, or part of a working day, in the stand-down period ( excluding any part of that period that is not included in the relevant period in relation to that credit).
'(6) For the purposes of the application of sub-section (5) in relation to an employee who has been stood down as mentioned in that sub-section-
(a) each of the following recreation leave credits or sick leave credits is a relevant credit in relation to the stand-down period:
(i) any recreation leave credit or sick leave credit that, but for sub-section (5), would accrue to the employee concerned during (but not on the first day of) the stand-down period;
(ii) the first recreation leave credit and the first sick leave credit that, but for sub-section (5), would accrue to the employee concerned after the expiration of the stand-down period;
(b) the relevant period, in relation to a recreation leave credit or a sick leave credit, is the period of 12 months ending on the day immediately before the day of accrual of that credit; and

(i) where the employee works a five day week-
1; or

'(7) An order made under sub-section (2) authorizing the standing down of employees may include directions not inconsistent with sub-section (3), (4) or ( 5) that, for any purpose relating to their conditions of employment as employees that is specified in the order, the stand-down period is not to be taken into account, or is to be taken into account as provided in the order, and any directions so given, unless varied or revoked by another order, have effect notwithstanding any law, or any award, that is inconsistent with the directions.
'(8) The powers conferred on the Commission by this section are in addition to, and not in derogation of, the powers conferred on the Commission by any other provision of this Act.''.

The purpose of this amendment is again to provide for some qualification in relation to powers which will be transferred to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The previous Government did qualify the transfer in respect of powers in relation to stand downs and no work as directed no pay orders which may be made by the Public Service Arbitrator. There is also a provision which made it clear that public servants who were stood down were not entitled to salaries, wages or allowances while they were stood down and that the period for stand down would not count for purposes of recreation, sick leave , nor long service leave.

It may be true that the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission would have the general jurisdiction to provide for stand downs and so forth. But the Opposition believes that these matters should be very specifically emphasised in legislation of this character which deals with the problem of employees and public servants in particular. We have already expressed views in opposition to legislation to repeal a number of pieces of legislation relating to the Public Service, namely the Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Act 1977 and the no work as directed no pay legislation which was recently repealed by this Government. In our view there is a need for special provisions to be made in relation to Public Service employment because we believe that public servants have a very privileged position in the employment field. It may well be that when their conditions of employment are looked at in regard to the whole field by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, that may have some effect in bringing the two areas more closely together. I do not know; that could be a long term proposition, but it may not occur. But the fact of the matter is that by reason of the employment policies of successive Commonwealth governments very favourable conditions have been provided by the employer without necessarily the need to obtain arbitration decisions. Public servants have tenure, great avenues of appeal in relation to promotion, very favourable superannuation and so on. The Opposition believes it is appropriate that legislation covering the conditions of employment of public servants should emphasise some of these matters and that where they do not discharge their responsibilities to the community, which is the other side of the coin, they should very clearly forfeit some of these conditions and they should not be able to behave exactly the same way as other employees in private employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —They should not behave in that way either, should they?

—No, I know, but I think the arbitration system does not specifically deal with private employers in the same way. The Opposition believes it would be desirable, when this transfer jurisdiction legislation is passed, that some of these provisions that exist in the Public Service Arbitration Act should be set out and carried through to the new jurisdiction being provided to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. That is the purpose of what is our very long amendment, which I do not propose by any means to read or refer to further because it is taken from the wording of the Bill which was included in the Opposition's proposal when we were in government last year. All of these provisions were included in that legislation. I have given the reason why they were included. The Opposition has no reason to change its mind in relation to this matter. This amendment is designed to incorporate those provisions in this transfer legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —This amendment represents the tail end of a long debate, I suppose-it has been going on for some years in the Senate-as to whether various provisions relating to stand down, et cetera, should be in the Public Service legislation or whether there should be uniformity, which is the other issue which has been raised, between private sector systems and public sector systems. The effect of these provisions is to give the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission the same powers, as it were, to make the same kinds of orders, including stand downs and no work as directed no pay orders as the Public Service Arbitrator can currently make. So there is a transfer of jurisdiction from the Public Service Arbitrator to the Counciliation and Arbitration Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: That does not mean that the Public Service Board for example is in any different position from a private employer. The Public Service employer can apply to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission for a stand down order or a no work as directed no pay provision insofar as those provisions are included. That employer has the capacity to make orders relating to those matters which are included in the conciliation and arbitration legislation. Once again it is an issue in respect of which it is the Government's view that the position of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission should as far as possible be the same in respect of both public and private sector employees, and the relevant section 70J gives effect to that situation in the legislation.

The amendment proposed by the Opposition would retain separate provisions, as it were, in relation to the Public Service because, as Senator Durack would argue, the Public Service is in a special position in employment by virtue of the fact that the members of the Public Service enjoy a number of benefits, such as tenure of employment and so on which other sectors do not enjoy. I do not have a serious degree of disputation with Senator Durack about that, but the Government just does not agree that this is the way to address that matter and that the inclusion of what might be crudely described as penalty provisions in Public Service legislation-different jurisdiction from that applying to private sector employees-is not desirable. For that reason the amendment is opposed.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be left out (Senator Durack's amendment) be left out .

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause agreed to.
Clauses 15 to 21-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 22 (Registration of organizations).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Page 17, sub-clauses 22 (1) and (2), lines 2 to 30, leave out the sub- clauses.

There are two different questions at stake here. I do not know whether it is appropriate to deal with them together. I suppose that will depend a bit on the attitude of the Committee. Clause 22 deals with the entitlement of Federal organisations to cover employees, or people who in many cases are not employees in a strict sense but who are covered by a deeming provision of section 132 of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. Section 132 (4) provides that where people are regarded as employees under certain State legislation-I think this applies particularly in four States-they should be included as eligible for membership of Federal organisations.

This matter, of course, has a very long history and I do not propose to go into that. However, clause 22 (1) deals with a situation which has arisen in New South Wales following changes made in 1979 to the New South Wales Industrial Arbitration Act. As a result, the existing provisions of section 132 of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act are not applicable to people engaged in the transport industry because a new scheme of registration of associations of owner -drivers has been developed in that State. The provisions of the New South Wales Act enable special awards to be made in favour of owner-drivers in that State. The legislation before us is designed to preserve the position of people who would have been eligible under the old legislation but who are no longer eligible because of amendments in 1979 to the New South Wales Act.

Because of the existing provisions of the State Act and section 132 of the Federal Act, there has been a good deal of coercion of people to join State unions and, by using the eligibility provisions, become members of the Federal Transport Workers Union. Owner-driver organisations in various parts of Australia have expressed great dissatisfaction about this situation.

I have already referred to this in the second reading debate. We do not believe there should be any amendments which will in any way facilitate or perpetuate the situation which has arisen. Therefore, we are opposed to the provision in the Bill. What has happened in New South Wales in providing for a separate organisation to cover owner-drivers is, we believe, the right course to take. It is interesting that apparently the Government is also looking at that as a means of overcoming the problem which has arisen. I hope that in the near future it will be able to come forward with some proposals of its own to cope with the problem. It certainly is a great problem and has been for a long time. It does call for a special solution. It cannot be solved by the tinkering type of amendment that is provided for in sub-clause (1).

Sub-clause (2), which is also the subject of our amendment to delete, will validate the union membership of a number of non-employees again mostly independent contractors and owner-drivers, who were members of unions prior to the 1977 amendments to the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. Those amendments made them ineligible for membership. However, a number apparently continued to remain members. No doubt it was very acceptable to the union which obtained their fees but there seems to have been no justification for the situation being allowed to continue. Now the Government, by sub-clause (2), is seeking to validate that situation, at least in relation to those who have wrongly remained members of their union in defiance of the 1977 amendments. We believe those amendments should be observed and that no sanction should be given to the continued membership of trade unions by persons who are ineligible to be members . We believe that what the union has allowed to continue is a most undesirable situation. No doubt it has had some problems as a result of its actions and some problems concerning the validity of actions that it has taken. That is all due to the fact that it has not observed the very clear provisions of the legislation in 1977 which introduced the present scheme in section 132 of the Act. We do not believe the Parliament should not give its imprimatur to that situation, which has continued until this time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government opposes this amendment. First, the purpose of clause 22 (1) is to impose limitations on the right of organisations to recruit self-employed persons. Non-employees will be able to join a State branch of an organisation of employees only where, and to the extent that, State industrial arbitration, legislative authorities and legislation authorises non-employees to be members of State unions. I did not make that fluent little speech without notes. I was quoting what Senator Durack said in introducing the second reading of Conciliation and Arbitration Bill (No. 2) of 1977, as recorded in Hansard of 20 October 1977. That is what this legislation is designed to do, that is the result that it is designed to achieve. These amendments in the clause are, in a sense, purely of a technical nature. They are designed to enable those who were deemed employees prior to the 1979 amendments to the New South Wales Act to continue to be members of the branch of a federally registered organisation. It does not enable to become members of the Federal Transport Workers Union owner- drivers who were not, prior to the 1979 amendments to the New South Wales Act, capable of so doing. Therefore, it is consistent with the concept introduced by the previous Government's amendments of 1977. For these reasons, we see no cause to accept that aspect of the Opposition's amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to clause 22 (2), Senator Durack says that there is no justification for allowing those persons who joined a union, in the situation covered by the sub-clause, to remain in the union. The Government finds some difficulty with that view, the unions being essentially voluntary associations but, as was pointed out in the second reading speech with great clarity, the Bill deals with the position of non-employees who have validly become members of federally registered unions following the 1973-74 amendments to section 132 but whose continued membership is in doubt after the further amendments of 1977. I do not want to take the matter further. I simply say that it is the Government's view that those employees have to be dealt with, and are best dealt with, in the context of the legislation, for the reasons described basically in the second reading speech. As I said, the purpose is to validate the membership of affected non-employees who have legitimately become members and presumably wish to remain so. That situation, I might say, is not unusual in organisations. It becomes unusual in the case of owner-drivers but is not generally unusual. The Government sees no reason why the amendment moved by the Opposition on that point should be carried.
Amendment negatived.
Clause agreed to.
Clause 23 (Prescribed offences).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (4) Page 18, paragraph 23 (a), lines 3 to 7, leave out the paragraph.

Clause 23 seeks to remove from the Act a number of provisions, and to substitute others. In the process, what has happened is that the Bill will significantly reduce the number of offences for which, upon conviction, a union member can be barred from holding office in the union. Although it is claimed, I notice, by the Government that the provision is restricted only to offences relating to elections or ballots, it removes a number of quite serious offences relating to failure to comply with Federal court orders, including orders in respect of secret ballots. I propose to state the policy behind the provisions in the existing Act, as introduced last year by the then Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Macphee. He referred to the recommendations of the Winneke Royal Commission and said:

. . . these recommendations highlight the need for the honest administration of registered organisations. These bodies play a vital role in Australian society. It is plainly against the interests of the community and the members of registered organisations if their administration is not competent and honest.

The Government does not doubt that by far the majority of registered organisations are honestly run, and not only the Royal Commission into the Builders Labourers Federation but also that into the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union has shown that there is an urgent requirement for legislation to combat corruption in the management of registered organisations.

Mr Macphee said that it was desired to try to equate the position under the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, with, as far as possible, relevant provisions in the Companies Act. Of course, we know that people are debarred from being directors of companies if they have committed various offences, particularly those relating to fraud and dishonesty or specific offences under the Companies Act. As I have said, the present Government has not resiled from that principle as far as I can see. It has sought to reduce the range of offences under which debarring from holding office will occur.

We are opposed to the changes being made in the list of offences as they exist in the Act. As I have said, some of the offences which are being removed as grounds for debarring people from holding office include failure to comply with orders of the Federal Court of Australia, in particular an order made by the Federal Court to comply with the rules of the organisation in respect of secret ballot; failure to comply with a direction of the Federal Court in observance of the rules of an organisation; failure to lodge with the Industrial Registrar details of moneys held by an organisation; and failure to lodge with the Registrar details of loans or donations over $1,000. They are quite important matters which go directly to the competence and honesty of people involved in the administration of unions. We believe that those provisions should remain in the legislation as grounds for debarring people from holding office. Therefore, the purpose of my amendment is to ensure that the present situation is retained. It certainly should be retained pending the conclusion of the tripartite inquiry and further consideration by the National Labour Consultative Committee in regard to these matters. They are the reasons I have moved this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is proposing by this legislation to reduce the number of offences in this section of the legislation. The comments that Senator Durack has just made- and I do not intend to be disrespectful-are the sort of fag-end of the debate which we had when these provisions were introduced into the legislation by the previous Government. At that time, the then Opposition made the point that many of these offences were not encompassed in the report of the Winneke Royal Commission into the Activities of the Australian Building Construction Employees and Builders Labourers Federation, that the Government of the day was using a sledge hammer to crack a nut, for want of a more eloquent expression at 5 o' clock on a Thursday afternoon, and that a number of deletions should have been made from the offences at that time. The Government of the day did not choose to do that. The Government today does choose to do that for reasons which I will briefly explain and which I have already explained in the past.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Durack referred to the comparison between the Companies Act and the Conciliation and Arbitration Act which was a sort of trojan horse in the debate last time. I make the point that only three of the offences to be deleted carry a sentence of imprisonment as a possible penalty. This contrasts very sharply with the relative offences against the Companies Act which would have the effect , if a conviction were recorded, of leading to disqualification from being involved in the management of a company. Of the 15 offences against the Companies Act and related legislation which can lead to disqualification only two do not have imprisonment as a penalty. I make that general observation. I could in fact make it in more detail but the Government's view is that this provision brings the legislation more into conformity with the principle of equity which is sought with the Companies Act than was previously so.

I reiterate the point I made about a number of the offences in the existing legislation. In respect of the commission of those offences there is an alternative remedy. I do not know whether it could be argued-I do not seek to argue this-that in respect of some of those situations people could be put in double jeopardy. I refer, for example, to the issue of non-compliance with the relevant Federal Court order. That matter can be dealt with by the Court under its comtempt powers. In the case of offences involving non-compliance with orders made in deregistration proceedings, the Court has specific powers to suspend the rights or privileges not only of the organisation but also of the members of the organisation.

On the other hand, criminal offences are involved in the signing of misleading returns or breaches of accounting provisions which are more likely to lead to prosecutions under the criminal law than under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act where the penalties provided are far less serious. In fact, I take a particular example which was cited in the second reading debate-the contravention of section 185 which deals with false representations as to membership of an organisation. That is already covered by section 132F (1) (A) because that section provides for a penalty of six months imprisonment. The same point can be made about section 146. Without going into repetitive detail I indicate that it is the Government's view that the reduction of offences will be more satisfactory and will not lead to any dire consequences. I also make the point that the National Labour Consultative Council has recommended that section 132F and related sections should be looked at by the Hancock Committee of Review into Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems. The changes being made by the Government in this legislation are interim changes only to that extent.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask the Minister for Industry and Commerce: Why does the Government believe that the offence must be one for which a person, on conviction, has served or is serving a sentence of imprisonment? It seems to me that that does a number of things. It creates a burden on the judge who is considering what penalty he will impose on a person convicted of some offence. No doubt the barrister making the plea for the accused will draw the judge's attention to the fact that a penalty of imprisonment has a different consequence for the accused than the conviction on the offence.
—Why should that not be the case?

—Senator Georges asked me why that should not be the case. I would have thought the situation is that it is the offence which is important rather than the consequences applied by the judge. Let me give Senator Georges an example. Let us presume that a person is charged with drunken driving which has nothing whatsoever to do with his union qualifications or his membership of the union.
—That is not what you were saying last year.

—With respect, I do not think Senator Button could have been talking about comments made by me last year. I was trying to give Senator Georges an explanation of what I was talking about. A person may be charged with drunken driving-or even with some other driving offence not to do with drunkenness, which is now so strictly a criminal offence it ought perhaps be put in a different category-and the magistrate or judge may decide to send him to gaol for seven days. Under the proposed provisons the magistrate would have some difficulty in sending that person to gaol because it would be pleaded very strongly that the person's employment would be placed in jeopardy as a result of that term of imprisonment being imposed.
—And so it should be argued.

—Certainly it should be argued in favour of the accused if loss of employment is to be the consequence of the imprisonment, but is it not much more important that the nature of the offence with which he is convicted should determine whether his position as a union organiser will be placed in jeopardy? It seems to me that if the offence were of such a nature that on conviction the person would be liable to a substantial term of imprisonment his union ought to get rid of him. Even if the magistrate or judge decided in the circumstances to grant the person a bond or give him some leniency it would not alter the fact that he had beem convicted of a very serious criminal offence. The same sort of thing happens with public companies and company secretaries. It seems to me that to limit prescribed offences to those for which the person on conviction 'has served, or is serving, a sentence of imprisonment' goes about it the wrong way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not quite sure of the relevance of Senator Lewis's remarks to the amendment which is before the chamber but, as always, I am interested in his observations. They have a certain sense of deja vu about them, the last of the 1982 show. They are observations which might well have been made when this legislation was introduced last year by the previous Government. These provisions are regarded by the Government as interim provisions, pending the deliberation of the Hancock inquiry on these matters. I see some validity in the logical points the honourable senator made and I will personally see that the remarks he has made in the chamber today are directed to the Hancock committee of inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Durack's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause agreed to.
Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole, and agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Button) read a third time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I claim to have been misrepresented. I seek leave to make a statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Speaking in a first reading debate at lunchtime today, Senator Primmer made a series of extraordinary allegations, including one that I had, as a result of false information supplied to me, he said, misled the Parliament in answer to a question addressed to me by Senator Sibraa on 29 November. I raise this matter at the first available opportunity. I have only just, in the last few minutes, seen a full transcript of what Senator Primmer has to say.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, it will take more than Senator Primmer's assertions, unaccompanied as they are by any evidence, to make me believe that I have in any way misled the Parliament in my answer to Senator Sibraa. On the evidence presently available to me, I have no reason to doubt either the comprehensiveness or the honesty of the briefings on which I based my parliamentary statement. I regret that, not for the first time, Senator Primmer, whatever the sincerity of his beliefs, has chosen, without notice and under cover of parliamentary privilege, to make extremely damaging and defamatory allegations. I ask him, as both I and the current Minister for Foreign Affairs ( Mr Hayden) have done on numerous occasions, as indeed have Ministers in the previous Government on several occasions, to produce some hard evidence to substantiate his allegations. Unless and until he does so, they will remain not only very offensive to the persons concerned, including myself on this occasion, but also unbelievable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave, Mr President, to make a statement on the matter raised by Senator Gareth Evans.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it regrettable that Senator Gareth Evans has sought, by personal explanation, to make an attack against Senator Primmer.
—Oh, come off it, George; sit down.
—Mr President, let me say something to Senator Robert Ray who has not been here for very long.
—That is right, but I have learnt something, I will tell you.

—I have learnt something. But let me say that Senator Primmer, on a number of occasions, has brought information before this Parliament which on first consideration appeared to be exaggerated. Let my say, on behalf of Senator Primmer, that on both previous occasions-
—He is here now. He can speak for himself.
—Yes, he can speak for himself, but I am speaking on his behalf. On both previous occasions the information that he brought before the Parliament was subsequently substantiated.
—That is not true.

—I would suggest that the matters which Senator Primmer has brought before this House ought to be accepted and ought to remain not challenged in the way in which Senator Gareth Evans has challenged them for some time yet. There have been occasions on which matters to which Senator Primmer has referred have been brought before other forums of this Parliament, and the doubts which he has raised have been raised elsewhere. I do not think that it is quite fair that Senator Primmer should be put under the pressure that he has been put under by Senator Gareth Evans on this occasion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to move a motion that the Senate take note of the statement which has just been made.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement which has just been made by Senator Georges.

I welcome the fact that there has been some response, perhaps of necessity a rather brief response, from the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden). I hope that there will be a more formal response on behalf of the Minister at some later time. This is not the first occasion on which Senator Primmer has made extremely serious allegations about people who are servants of the Commonwealth and who have served the Commonwealth, as was said in an earlier discussion today, under governments of both Labor and Liberal persuasions. I believe that it is a matter which has to be taken very seriously by this Senate when people who are serving the Commonwealth as public servants are open to the sort of attack which has been made today and on other occasions here without warning and, indeed, without even giving Ministers the opportunity to be prepared and able to defend those servants of the Commonwealth as they may be entitled to be defended. I take issue with the statement made by Senator Georges that what Senator Primmer has previously put before the Senate has been substantiated.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not say that. I said that on other occasions his statements had been substantiated.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition has the call.

—I respond to that interjection. I meant to say, and I certainly understood Senator Georges to say, that information given on previous occasions had been substantiated. I join with the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) on this occasion who, by interjection, indicated that in his view that was not so, and that is my recollection also-that it is not so.
—He was right about the meat inquiry.

—There may be some bits and pieces, but there have also been lengthy statements put down in this place on behalf of Mr Hayden which have disputed matters brought before this place in the same way by Senator Primmer. I sought to move a motion to take note of this statement because I think that we need to debate and to consider what courses of action are open to the Government and the Senate to prevent abuses of the necessary privileges which attach to this place. Senator Georges is a man with whom I have worked closely. I believe that he is genuinely concerned about some aspects of civil liberties. That is certainly the evidence of my association with him. I believe that he shows an extraordinary lack of balance in coming to the defence of this sort of behaviour in the Senate. I do not believe that it is consistent with other aspects of his attitudes which he has aired in this place. I do not believe that we should be prepared to see the forms of this place used in the way in which they were used. I hotly dispute Senator Georges's defence of Senator Primmer.

SPEECH.PARA: In an earlier opportunity that we had to debate this matter I pointed out that there are other avenues available to honourable senators if they feel that there is a matter of maladministration which needs to be attended to. Surely the first step which should be taken, particularly when a government supporter is involved , is to take up the matter with the government of which he is virtually a part and to seek redress through the Ministers who have the responsibility for the administration of their departments. To fail to do that and to move straight into it is an act which would appear to have almost a vindictive quality to it. I have yet to see the total of the remarks made by Senator Primmer, but he referred to other matters which have occurred and which have caused some distress within the Australian Labor Party over recent days and weeks, and to use that as a reason for bringing into this place allegations about a public servant who may have been involved in some aspects of the security services is utterly inexcusable. There is a heavy obligation on the Government to look to the behaviour of its own supporters and to do something to prevent yet another repetition of this sort of behaviour.

TALK.START.PARA: —Gag me.

—I think that Senator Primmer said 'Gag me'. I would defend the right of any honourable senator to try to do something about the Administration if there is maladministration. As I tried to point out previously, there are avenues which would safeguard the citizens involved against possibly wrongful accusations, and in this case, I suspect, definitely wrongful accusation. I do not believe that one should, as one's first course, rush into this place and put the accusations on the table in a way which leaves the citizen utterly defenceless. That is inexcusable and I regard it with abhorrence.

SPEECH.PARA: There should be an opportunity for us to debate this matter fully. Earlier today Senator Jessop made a particularly constructive contribution when he mentioned something that he has raised within our Party on a number of occasions and which I know he will be pursuing, that is, the possibility that we could have some sort of machinery that would provide redress for the citizen who is caught in the situation that Mr Ryan is caught in today. I do not believe any of us would want to see the privilege of the Parliament removed. Quite clearly there are in extremis situations where one has to say things which one needs the protection of the Parliament to say. Presumably Senator Primmer made that judgment today. But the fact is that we do that in a system which provides no redress and no real right of reply to the citizen. I think we should consider the sorts of views that Senator Jessop put today about whether it would be possible to provide some mechanism for complaint, for inquiry, for retraction and so on. That is one element that this place needs to consider.

I do not wish to make a lengthy speech as we have a great deal of business to get through. But I believe that the whole of the Opposition regards it as totally unacceptable that servants of the Crown are treated in this way by people who are elected to the Parliament. The failure of Senator Primmer to follow the other avenues available to him is an approach that just cannot be justified. I totally disagree with the sort of justification which was put up by Senator Georges. It is perhaps more serious that there was something close to a justification from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt), who initially responded but who is not in the chamber at the moment. I think that warrants further examination and I believe that the Senate should consider the way that Senator Gietzelt responded, keeping in mind that he bears ministerial responsibility, that he is part of the Government and that he has some responsibilities not just on his own behalf and not only to reflect the views of his Caucus, his faction or whatever else he might reflect, but also to reflect the views of the Government.

This is not a very good day for the Senate; indeed it is a very bad day for the Senate. I will not seek leave to continue my remarks because it may be that others will wish to speak but I believe that we should address ourselves to the principles which are raised by Senator Primmer's further excursion in smearing people of whom he disapproves and of attacking people of whom he disapproves. I believe we should attend to that in a conscientious way which might do something to restore not merely the reputation of those who have been traduced, but also the reputation of the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the reasons that the Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, and Senator Chaney have given, I believe that this is a serious matter and deserves serious consideration by the Government. What is more important, it deserves serious debate in this place by both the Government and the Opposition. For that reason, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the debate be now adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek the call.
—Can we speak to that motion?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —There can be no debate on the adjournment motion.

INTERJECT.PARA: That the motion be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rose earlier today when Senator Primmer made his comments because I regarded the issue as a very grave one. I rise now not in any contentious fashion but to put some points. I say from the beginning that I appreciate that the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs has not had any adequate time to reflect upon the material or to reflect upon the possible consequences. I acknowledge that fully and therefore am not combative about the issues.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to try to define, in any future approach to this matter, the magnitude of what I think the problem is because, in my judgment, the problem is not a narrow one at all. There have been a number of occasions on which Senator Primmer has made in this chamber a wide series of allegations about a considerable number of senior officers and officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs. Today he made an additional one about the Director of the Australian Secret Intelligence Service. If one looks at the totality of what has been said, charges were made which could suggest, if there were any truth in them at all following investigations, only that there was some massive conspiracy and massive corruption, not among a few people, but in the whole Department. I reject that. I put the matter in terms of its magnitude. There have been allegations of theft, of lying, of alcoholism and of bad behaviour. There have been allegations of a total pattern of misbehaviour by a number of officers and an allegation that the senior officers in the Department have known these things and are covering up. Of course, if this were so, not only would the reflection be upon the whole Department but it would be upon the Minister. The allegations would apply not only to the present Minister, Mr Hayden, but also to the previous Minister. The allegation could be made that he must have been covering up because the Minister has a responsibility to look at these grave charges to see whether they are true or not.

There have been wide investigations of this matter. Senator Primmer has not produced hard evidence at all. Today he widened his charges. We are not just considering individuals of a department. We are considering charges covering, first of all, a whole Department and, secondly, charges covering the Director of ASIS. If one allowed allegations to be sustained about the whole Department of Foreign Affairs we are saying to the world outside that the whole of our international contact is defective in that the Department is contaminated, corrupt and subject to all sorts of criminal offences. It cannot be left at that . It is of that magnitude. Nor can it be left at the magnitude that the Minister has either been defective in his inquiries or that, knowing these things, is covering up.

What happened today went a step further. Senator Primmer started off by saying that David Combe and Mick Young had been in trouble and that the trouble had arisen partly out of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation. I think he used the words: 'Here was proof that there should be an axe taken to ASIO and to the intelligence services'. I hope I am not distorting that. That was the general thrust, as I understood it. It has been known for a considerable period that certain elements of the Australian Labor Party want to destroy ASIO and ASIS and would take any opportunity that they could to do so. I sound a warning: There is a very grave danger, indeed, if, in the course of the Combe affair and the Mick Young affair, anything should be done to damage the intelligence systems of Australia or to damage the diplomatic system of Australia.

A respected Royal Commissioner has already carried out one inquiry into ASIO and ASIS and is doing another. Let us not do wilful damage to the systems upon which the integrity and security of our country depends. If something is wrong let us clean it up. We cannot have the terrible argument which was put to us today by Senator Primmer which was that ASIO has reported upon David Combe who was found responsible and instead of that reflecting upon David Combe or Mick Young, ASIO should be abolished; the police force that has brought the evidence should be abolished. I know of nothing that is more distorted or more convoluted than the idea that the way to reduce offences is to abolish the ability to detect them.

I do not want to be combative at all but to say that if we are to consider this matter in depth we will be considering a massive problem. We are considering now allegations made about a total department, not just one, two or three people. Allegations have been made about a permanent head of a department, a Minister responsible for a department, and therefore, the Government and, of course, the intelligence services. I regard this matter as extremely grave. I believe this matter should be debated next week. There is a necessity for the Government to respond in such a way that it is possible, once and for all, to put this matter to rest.

There is a secondary situation in this matter. I think that the closest attention should be given to the speech today by Senator Gietzelt. I think the words and the arguments that he put today must give the gravest concern to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —And to the Government.

—To the Government and to the Senate. I do not raise this matter today because that will come in the course of things. I said that I do not wish to be combative. I think we ought to look at suggestions such as Senator Jessop's but above everything in this world we have to take the view in this place that people are innocent unless we can come forward and prove guilt by very firm methods. It is a very sad day indeed. I acknowledge the Attorney's difficulty at this moment. I look forward to a thorough debate in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter which we are discussing was raised during a period which has been set aside for debate of non-contentious matters, by agreement between members of this chamber. When we discussed the hours of meeting for the Senate we agreed that the time between 12.45 and 2 o' clock on Thursdays would be devoted to the debate of non-contentious matters. Honourable senators can imagine my surprise when, going from one meeting to another, I went to my office and heard what could be described only as a most extraordinary and outrageous attack on a public servant who has served both the Australian Labor Party and the Liberal Party governments internationally and nationally. That person has no recourse available to him to refute those outrageous comments made about him other than to be defended by a Minister. Instead of going to the second meeting which was a meeting of the executive of Amnesty International, I immediately made my way to the chamber. Prior to entering the chamber I was absolutely amazed to hear the comments made by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt). It is no reflection on Ministers and no reflection on the Government because they, like the rest of us, believed that the Senate would be having a non-contentious debate. However, it appears that Senator Gietzelt heard on his intercom some parts of the statement made by Senator Primmer. What Senator Gietzelt said was designed-or if it was not designed this was the effect-to clothe with some degree of respectability the attack made by Senator Primmer, and in particular the attack that he made on Australian security services. Of course this is in direct defiance of the publicly expressed attitude of Australia's Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). I agree with what Senator Sir John Carrick said-this is a matter which of course ought to be of grave concern not only to the Senate and to us as individual senators but also to the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said before, if something is not done about the question of having non- contentious debates during that period, if people are going to come in here and raise contentious matters, other forms are available to senators to achieve a result in that particular area. I hope that it does not have to come to that but I do feel-I do not reflect at all on the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) who manages Government Business because obviously he was not aware of it -that some action should be taken to ensure that this part of the day is used for non-contentious debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to enter into the substance of this debate; I merely want to make a couple of points. The first is that when I moved for the adjournment of this debate the suggestion was made-maybe it was a reflex action, this being a political chamber -that I was trying to gag debate. I was not trying to gag debate at all; in fact , before moving the adjournment I made it clear that I and the Government consider this to be a serious matter, a matter which deserves serious response from the Government and the Minister concerned, the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans). He has not been able to give it that consideration, a fact that is recognised on both sides of this place. The fact that Senator Sir John Carrick and Senator Harradine wished to speak immediately meant that the adjournment motion was defeated but in moving the adjournment I made it perfectly clear that I did not consider that that was a means of gagging or preventing debate on this subject. What I want is a debate which involves serious response from the Government and a serious non-heated atmosphere for the debate from both sides of the House.
—Most senators probably did not even hear it.

—I did not hear the debate. It is unfortunate that the debate started in that period, which is supposed to be for non-controversial matters, but I want to make it perfectly clear that we believe this is a serious matter. We believe it raises serious implications and we believe it deserves the serious consideration of this chamber. That consideration cannot be given without proper preparation. It was for that reason that I moved the adjournment. I repeat that any adjournment moved now, as I expect Senator Ryan will do, will not result in the cessation of this debate. Quite clearly it is a matter that has to be settled not only for the Government and the Opposition but also for the Parliament as a whole.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate (on motion by Senator Ryan) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill returned from the House of Repre- sentatives without amendment.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (EDUCATION ASSISTANCE-PARTICIPATION AND EQUITY) BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: [COGNATE BILLS:
STATES GRANTS (SCHOOLS ASSISTANCE) BILL 1983
STATES GRANTS (TERTIARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1983]
Debate resumed from 2 December 1983, on motion by Senator Gietzelt:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on Friday last when we were debating cognately the States Grants (Education Assistance-Participation and Equity) Bill, the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Bill and the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill, I was at the point, with a few minutes to go, of trying to outline how we see the strategy of the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan). I described it as political schizophrenia-how to maximise support from the public by saying things that the public wishes in some instances but with the party ideologues, the party members and the branches saying other things. There is a direct dichotomy between, on the one hand, what will make for democracy and what will make for public support by the Government moving to reassure the public and, on the other hand, the Government fulfilling the ideological commitments of party members. Similarly, I referred to the statements the Minister made during her visit to Ireland. She said that the Government was serving the Catholic schools wonderfully and yet, at the very same time, Catholic bishops and representatives of Catholic schools were decrying the Minister. If only the people of Ireland had seen that, they would have seen that it was a much more complex picture than the simple, happy story she was telling them.

SPEECH.PARA: Another illustration of this political schizophrenia are the facts with regard to level 2 and level 1 schools. Quite apart from the 41 schools on the hit list, the Minister has acknowledged in the Senate that level 2 and level 1 schools will not be given greater support than they would have received under the nexus or percentage link formula of the past.

TALK.START.PARA: —They will get less.

—They will be getting less for the most part, except for some level 2 schools. The great majority of level 2 schools and all level 1 schools will be getting less than the formula. The example of political schizophrenia is that the Minister will not acknowledge that to the schools; she will acknowledge it only under careful questioning in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: I summarise my plea again to the Minister and to the Government with regard to these Bills: Please do not distract us in this debate and please do not distract the country from the main thrust of helping those schools that are most in need or from the issue that is most important in the education area; that is, quality of outcome for Australia's school children. The same could be said with regard to tertiary education. By the abandonment of the guidelines and established principles of funding for non-government schools, the Senate has been distracted by this kind of debate and by the uproar that is all about the country. I again say to the Minister that for $20m or less this Government could redress that situation by restoring the basic grant for all school children on the basis of the principles of the past, by restoring the nexus or the percentage link, and by making it possible for newly established independant schools to have the same access as in the past to capital funds for their establishment. I implore the Minister, in this six months of review, to re-establish those principles so that we are all pulling together in this country and focusing upon the education questions that matter.

In conclusion, I urge that honourable senators support the second reading amendment moved by my colleague Senator Baume. I understand that he is seeking to leave out one word from the original proposal. I do urge honourable senators to support that opposition amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I understand the wish of the Government at least that we reduce the length of our speeches on these matters because of the Government's program. It is unfortunate that measures of such importance as the States Grants (Education Assistance-Participation and Equity) Bill, the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Bill and the States Grants ( Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill have come before the Senate in the last couple of weeks of parliament. Of course, the measures deal with a wide range of educational matters, some of which I am the first to acknowledge are welcome initiatives or improvements, although if time permitted I would have liked to have made some substantial comment on the participation and equity program. Nevertheless, because of those circumstances I will concentrate briefly on those areas in the legislation which implement the Government's guidelines in respect of the funding of non-government schools; in other words the matters of real contention which, as the previous speaker has said, have overshadowed other areas of educational interest which are of real importance to the whole of the community. In my view it was totally unnecessary for the Government to bring down these guidelines to break the nexus, abolish the basis grant and insist upon a type of impact study before new schools are funded. It was unnecessary for the Government to do what it did in those three areas, as I will point out during the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not intend to argue the way I did in previous debates on these matters because I think the atmosphere has slightly changed since then. I hope that it has because at that stage-I am referring to the stage until about a fornight ago -the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) was accusing persons who were concerned about these educational issues variously of being anti-Labor, of stirring the pot or of having some ulterior motive. Just to give honourable senators an example of that, on 9 November, when replying to the matter of public importance that I raised in the Senate, the Minister said:
We know Senator Harradine's motives. They are what they have been for a very long time. They are aimed at eroding the Labor forces in this country and the Labor Government.

Of course, it is of great concern to Senator Harradine and his echo in News Weekly, Santamaria, that the catholic education commissions are, in fact, extremely supportive of our needs-based approach to education.
She went on to say:
One could find almost word for word what Senator Harradine has just said in this article by B. A. Santamaria in News Weekly. That would not surprise anybody in this place.

They are extraordinary statements from a Minister who should know better. They indicate not only her lack of grasp of the real educational concerns of people but also her lack of knowledge of the political circumstances of the nation. Of course not only had I not even read what News Weekly had said about this matter- although if it agreed with what I was saying it was obviously on the right track -but also, and this was the most disconcerting aspect of the Minister's observation, she failed to understand that at that time there were people like me who were genuinely concerned about education. After all, I have some reason to be concerned about the issue. I have thirteen reasons to be concerned about it. I was concerned also about the fact that the Minister was engaging in what appeared to be, on the face of it, a deliberate tactic of intimidation towards non-government school parents and their principals in the non-government school area.

I hope to be able to acknowledge that the Minister has changed her attitude in that respect. Having gone to some of these meetings I think she now realises-I hope she does-that this is a matter of genuine concern. To me and to many of the parents who have gone to these meetings it has nothing to do with party politics . After all there is no election in the offing for another two years, and these people are concerned.

At a meeting in Ballarat the Minister acknowledged that the nexus gave some security in planning to the non-government school sector. She said that the advantage of the nexus was that it gave confidence for the future and that it gave some security in educational planning in the non-government sector. She said that the disadvantage was that the nexus was not flexible enough that the Government had decided to abolish it, that it would attempt to rearrange the amount of money that was available from Commonwealth funds within the non- government school sector and that it would increase the grants to non-government group 3 schools; the most needy schools. As I said on that occasion, we would have all gone home happy if the Minister, who is proposing a 3 per cent increase for non-government group 3 schools, had simply said: 'For the time being we will make that 43 per cent-and keep the nexus'. We would also be happy if she withdrew her comment, which is on the record, relating to the basic grant. I hope the Minister will see her way clear today either to say that the comment was not adequately detailed in the Press or at least that she now rejects it. In the Canberra Times of 26 September 1983 the Minister is reported as saying:
The view that parents who choose non-government schooling for their children had a right or entitlement to government funding of that choice because they were taxpayers was a specious argument.

TALK.START.PARA: —When did she say that?

—It is reported in the Canberra Times of 26 September 1983. I would say that very few Government members would adopt that point of view. I am just wondering whether the Minister will take the opportunity that is now available to refute that statement and say that in fact there is a prior right for parents to choose the education best suited to their child or children.

SPEECH.PARA: It may be, as is very often the case, that because of certain circumstances parents choose a state school for one child-say, a child attending primary school-and a non-government school for another child. But if the Minister is able to see her way clear to refute that statement, so much the better.

TALK.START.PARA: —But, Senator, you do not get the right as a taxpayer; you get the right as a person sending your child to a school.

—Yes, one gets the right as a person. A parent has the prior right to choose the education that is best suited to his children. In Australia, for example, we have compulsory education. We have no choice about that. However , a parent has the right to choose freely the type of education best suited to his child and that right should not be qualified by overburdensome fiscal pressures. The fact is that parents who choose to send their children to non- government schools are taxpayers. Part of their taxes is earmarked for education . That is another reason why the Minister ought to retract her statement. That is the basic reason for the establishment of the basic grant. In my book it was too low, but it has been taken away from 41 schools and naturally the parents of children who attend those schools are concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: I make the point that some people are saying: 'You are going to bet for these 41 elitist schools'. I am not going to bet for any school. I am going to bet for the right of the parents to choose the form of education best suited for their children and their right to have a portion of the educational expenditure from government sources-in other words, taxpayers' sources-directed to their children . I would like to read a letter from a parent of a child who attends one of the schools that has been hit. This parent is either a deserted wife or divorcee. I think honourable senators should listen carefully to the letter. She states:
Dear Senator Harradine,

I am a sole parent with two children, both boys. My elder boy is at an Independent School, although he attended his local State School until Grade 6. I was forced (although I knew it would be a shocking financial strain) to change his school because of behavioural problems due to the breakdown of the marriage and complete rejection by his father. I am hoping I can keep my second boy at the State School.

The stress of bringing up two boys, working full-time and caring for an ailing father is enourmous and we are forced to lead a very spartan existence. At the time I decided to change my elder boy's school, I thought I could handle the financial strain whereas I could not handle two delinquent teenage boys.

Now, what do I do? Do I unsettle my boy even more by changing his school when he has settled in (he is now in Year 7), formed friendships, is very happy, working well and receiving the extra care and attention he so badly needs?

I am writing to you as a concerned parent. I pay taxes, part of which are set aside by Government for education of my children. I feel strongly that it is discriminatory to give my elder boy less grant because he attends a private school when my tax grant alone would fully fund him if he attended a State School. He should at least get the same grant as the school of my choice as he would if he attended a State School, because I pay the same tax levy. Why should the State Schools get my share of my elder boy's grant when he does not attend a State School?

The logic is unanswerable. Yet this right is being undermined by the Government' s guidelines. This lady's child attends one of the 41 schools which have had their grants reduced. This letter indicates that it is not so much a matter of wealthy schools as a matter of wealthy or poor parents. Many wealthy parents send their children to government schools. Therefore, in that sense, this is not a social justice issue. The burden placed on this single parent is quite enormous. What does she do in a situation in which although her child is happy at the school she may well have to take him away and thus create real problems for him? What happens when people go to bat for these 41 schools? I am disturbed and sad to say this, because I respect many of the things that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is doing, but I am concerned that, presumably on very bad advice, he said recently that there was an unholy alliance between the 41 schools and some Catholic schools. I do not know to whom he was referring or where this unholy alliance is. As far as I am aware all of the Catholic authorities, including the National Commission of Bishops and the National Catholic Education Commission, have expressed grave concern about these aspects of the Government's guidelines. They have done so in statements that have been made after conducting a very rigorous examination of them. It has been put to me that these 41 schools should not be supported because most of their students go on to universities and there hit the taxpayer jackpot. That is no argument for the guidelines. It is an argument for the reintroduction of tertiary fees. If the Government wants to bite that bullet, I invite it to do so. It might be get more support than it expects.

In what I hope is a more conciliatory atmosphere that is developing, I wish to ask that the Minister bear certain things in mind. I ask her, first of all, to acknowledge that there is real, genuine concern amongst many parents. They are concerned about the future. They are concerned also that the future is being designed by the Commonwealth Schools Commission whose membership is now influenced by appointees of the Minister, three of these having a long track record of anti-State aid campaigning. Non-government school parents are concerned that their representative was not reappointed to the Schools Commission. I am not talking about education officers. I am talking about a parent representing non-government school parents. The Schools Commission is, of course, now deeply involved in the study, as directed by the Minister, of a number of areas including the target recurrent resource standard study. It is most unfortunate that there is such a weight of anti-State aid people on the Commission when considerations of the future of non-government schooling are being undertaken. It is probably too late now totally to reverse the situation just by filling vacancies with people but at least that would be a start. Let us at least now approach this matter recognising that there is very deep concern throughout the community. If the Minister does that, I am sure that she will be surprised at the co-operative attitude that may develop. But how can the Minister get a co-operative attitude when she has pulled the rug from under the parents of the children attending these 41 schools-children who have had their just rights denied to them.

My suggestion to the Minister is that she withdraw this legislation; that she tie the level 3 schools, for the time being, to 43 per cent, of the nexus; that she restore the basic grant to the 41 schools and withdraw the forthrightness, if that is the word, of her guideline relating to the establishment of new schools. Then she will certainly open the door to co-operation on the part of concerned parents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —In listening to the debate on the substance of these Bills, both in this chamber and in the media-and we have heard a lot of it lately-I am struck by the great emphasis being put on the non-government schools. In fact, we have heard for just on half an hour from Senator Harradine virtually solely that topic. Yet this group of schools together educate only about one-quarter of the school population of Australia. Three-quarters of all primary and secondary students attend government schools; yet the Opposition and the noisy minority that is supporting it out in the community are only concerned , it seems, about non-government schools. Clearly, they care little for the rights and needs of the other 75 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: Much of the argument we have heard from the Opposition benches-and it features in their proposed amendments to the Bills-focuses on the freedom of parents to choose their children's school. In fact, Senator Harradine spent a lot of time on that also. I agree with the comments made by Senator Macklin the other day that complete freedom of choice, even if it were available to all parents, is not necessarily in the best interests of the child. In this regard I welcome the provision made to implement educational accountability as well as financial accountability for the spending of taxpayers' money on non-government schools. I hope that it will lead to the badly-needed betterment of educational standards in some of those schools. I believe that every child has the right to education but at the moment some schools provide a minimum of education and a maximum of indoctrination.
