The fact that mothers go to work to pay non-government school fees is supposed to convince us that a bigger slice of the education cake should go to those schools. That is a spurious argument. Mothers go to work for all sorts of reasons apart from urgent financial need, for example, to pay for swimming training or a tennis court for their children. Are we, then, to subsidise these choices? Other mothers go to work to feed and clothe their children and maintain them at school past the minimum leaving age. Should the taxes that they pay be used to subsidise resource-rich schools? Freedom of choice in this sense is not available to most Australians. Fees at the schools where parents are protesting loudest are way beyond the reach of most families. Those who do have the choice often choose a government school because they prefer a good education within a group which represents the total community.

One of the sorry side effects of the present debate is the implication that non -government schools provide a superior education-apparently just by reason of the fact that they are non-government schools. On an educational scale, from my own experience, both government and non-government schools are spread throughout the range. In my experience, parents are often falsely persuaded that what they pay highly for is necessarily better. Some of the speeches on this topic in recent months might be described as misleading advertising in this regard.

I would like to refer to some of the comments that Senator Harradine has just made. He quoted from a letter from one of his constituents. I wonder why she sent her child to one of those 41 very expensive schools, considering the sort of financial situation in which she was obviously placed. I cannot believe she could not find any other school which would meet the child's needs. It has been my experience, for example, that counselling and guidance staff of education departments meet these problems all the time and satisfactorily solve them if they are given a chance by finding a school that will fit the needs of that child whether it is within the government or non-government systems. Yet some non-government schools also in my experience give false information and claim that they had a monopoly for caring or catering for children who have special needs. Some non-government schools do not reach minimal educational standards in relation to trained staff, adequate equipment or curriculum. Yet, some people assume that those schools are bound to be better because they have to pay.

Senator Teague was critical last week of secondary schools whose curriculum is geared solely to higher educational entry. Such schools are most often found in the non-government sector. In fact, many of those schools discard students or weed them out if they are unlikely to do well in academic courses. Frequently, at the end of the tenth year at school it is suggested, to put it kindly, that a student move to a government school. The real reason, of course, is that the non -government school wants to keep up its final year pass rate. Diversity of curriculum, that is, real educational choice, is more often found in government schools which do cater for all students.

The States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1983 has attracted much less attention in this cognate debate than the other Bills. Perhaps this is because tertiary education has no significant private sector. I would like to refer to a few aspects of that legislation. University administrators and staff with whom I have spoken in recent months have welcomed the provisions for retrospective cost supplementation which will allow tertiary institutions to plan for the future on a more secure basis. In passing, it should be noted that that cost supplementation also applies to school funding. It is wrong, therefore, for non-government schools to claim, as some have, that fee increases for next year are due to wage rises. It is very good to see the ending of compulsory amalgamations of tertiary institutions which was so strongly opposed by both the staff and the students who were affected by them. This does not mean that there will be no further amalgamations. Some such amalgamations will have substantial benefits educationally as well as financially, but the decision will no longer be forced on the institutions concerned. This is in contrast with the policies of the previous Government which forced amalgamations which are little more than cost cutting exercises, with small regard either for the wishes of the people concerned or for the educational consequences.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about undoing amalgamations? Do they do that too?

—Possibly. We have heard criticism from the Opposition about the minor cut in subsidies to collegiate residences. It seems to me inequitable that the accommodation of some students should be subsidised, without any means test, while the vast majority of students living away from home receive no such subsidy. I believe we need to find a better way to assist students who cannot live at home.

SPEECH.PARA: The States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill provides $10. 5m to assist institutions in meeting the expenditure involved in increased enrolments for 1984. This complements the participation and equity program legislation. Both these programs aim to increase the participation in education of those who are at present under-represented in both the higher levels of secondary schooling and higher education. Participation and equity program guidelines aim to encourage young people to continue their education within the existing framework such as in technical and further education colleges and also within more diversified programs within schools or other community facilities. The participation and equity program will also encourage young people and older people too to come back into the education and training process. It is very important to encourage this second chance. Many young people leave school and later learn, often the hard way, that their level of education does not equip them for what they want to do with their lives. They need encouragement and programs designed to meet their needs. A participation and equity allocation will help to provide that.

Finally, I would like to pay a brief tribute to the parent and teacher organisations in government schools which have done so much to raise the standards of education in government schools, even under the financial strictures of the previous Government. They too need to be reassured that the Government is committed to funding schools according to need and will not be diverted from that commitment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to add a few comments to the cognate debate on the States Grants (Education Assistance-Participation and Equity) Bill 1983, the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Bill 1983 and the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1983 which are now before the Senate. I have listened with interest to the case that has been put by honourable senators from this side of the chamber. I agree with what has been said by those honourable senators. I would like to raise one or two points. Senator Zakharov just said that 75 per cent of children go to government schools and only 25 per cent go to non-goverment independent schools and they have not been hurt. I suppose that is why those schools have been particularly mentioned by honourable senators on this side of the chamber. We have all heard a lot about the hit list of 41 wealthy non-government schools, as they are called, whose funding is to be reduced, whose basic grant is to be taken away. I would like to point out to the Senate that many parents who send their children to these schools are not necessarily wealthy parents. They scrimp and save so that their children can go to the school of their choice. The parents might have gone to those schools, the parents might feel there is better discipline at those schools or they might feel that their children can get religious instruction at those schools. For some reason or other they want to send their children to those schools and they make an effort to do so. I know of one family which had a home worth $80,000. The family sold it and moved into a house worth $50,000, so the $30,000 left could be used to pay for the education of their children.

SPEECH.PARA: I received a copy of a letter in the mail just recently in which I was told that it was estimated that 65 per cent of mothers of private school children work to keep their children at those schools. These mothers cannot really be classed as wealthy. I think it is probably a matter of priorities. A lot of people feel that the education of their children is a priority. Some people buy new cars, caravans or whatever they want to buy. I would like to say that I do not think-

TALK.START.PARA: —How many of the 65 per cent have kids at the 41 schools? You have not got the faintest idea.
—I do not interrupt Senator Walsh all the time. I wish that he would refrain from interrupting me.
—I just wish you would provide relevant information.

—I am saying to Senator Walsh that education is very important to these people. I feel that this is something that needs to be said. Many parents make a real sacrifice to be able to choose the school to which they send their children. The trouble, as I see it, is that after the 41 schools have had their funds cut the next thing that will happen will be of course, that funds will be cut to other private schools. As a matter of fact the grammar schools in Queensland have written to me. They have been very concerned about the cutting back of funds for boarders. I see this as a penalty, in the main, for rural people throughout Australia. I was at the speech day for Scots College in Warwick just recently and many of the parents-
—Its funds were not cut.

—I realise, Senator Ryan, that its funds have not been cut. It is very concerned because although it is not on the hit list of 41 schools, it is sure that the funding for the boarding facilities eventually will be cut for children who are going to board at the school. It seems to me that this is a matter of regret. I feel that this reflects in many ways the way that the Government seems to hit at people who live in the country. People with children at boarding schools certainly feel that there is a need to help them with their education costs. Through the years people living in the far outback of Australia have had problems with education. They have had to employ governesses and the children have had to work through the School of the Air and have correspondence lessons.

SPEECH.PARA: Parents who live in isolated areas have to send their children to boarding school out of pure necessity, yet these people, like others, will be faced with prohibitive fees. This needs to be taken into consideration. I feel sure that help from the Federal Government to these schools will eventually be reduced. Of course, if the funds are reduced, fees will have to rise. Some principals claim that one of the side effects will be the isolation of children of lower income earners from the independent school system. This will make the private schools more elitist because any places left vacant in those schools by withdrawals will immediately be filled by pupils whose parents are better able to bear the cost of sending their children to these schools. It was recently reported in one of the Brisbane newspapers that the Isolated Children's Parents Association in Queensland, the children of whose members are dependent on boarding schools for most of their education, wrote to the Minister because they were worried about this problem. The article reported:
A resolution was sent to Canberra . . . saying the education of isolated children would be jeopardised if the cuts went ahead.
Some schools have already closed their boarding sections because of the financial strain. Others have reduced their capacity and are faced with big increases in fees.
This is why the grammar school representatives are very concerned about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are these schools in Queensland?
—They had a meeting in Toowoomba not so very long ago.
—No schools in Queensland were cut.

—I am saying that in future there could be further cuts to these schools and that that needs to be taken into consideration. At the meeting in Toowoomba it was reported that the grammar school representatives said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . non-government schools were receiving only 13 per cent of government funds to finance 25 per cent of the school population.
One leading Brisbane school, attended mainly by children of middle-class families, will lose $240,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which school?

—As the paper did not name the school, I cannot inform the Minister of that. I feel sure that the Minister must recognise that if parents have to pay increased fees because of cuts in government funding, many children will be taken away from private schools and sent to government schools. Of course, the cost then comes back to the Government. I chose to send my children to state primary and high schools. I was quite satisfied with them, but perhaps I was not in the same situation as many people in outback Australia.
—Tell Senator Ryan what they were like.

—Our government schools were actually very good at Kingaroy. I was very pleased to be able to get a bus that went from my door to the school. I like to feel that my children got good educational training. But I think it should be the right of every parent to choose the type of education that they want for their children. I believe it is the right of every child to educational justice and it is the duty of the Government to protect the right of parents to choose the type of education that they want for their children. As I said earlier, some parents want their children to receive religious education at school. That might be the only way, regrettably, that they ever get it and it is not always available within the State system. I believe that an equal share of tax to help in educating children no matter where they attend school is a democratic right for all parents. Therefore, I join with other senators on our side-Senator Baume and Senator Teague and other speakers-in opposing the proposals in this legislation and in supporting the Opposition's amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the 30 years that followed World War II, successive governments of Liberal faith set out progressively to bring about a uniting and a unifying in education. They looked towards the pre- war years and to the divisiveness, religious bigotries, and the rich and poor strata of the community and they set out with goals to overcome the divisiveness and bigotry and to get an education system which would cover all Australians. They set out to bring the best quality education to all Australians, whether in government schools or independent schools. They set out to establish a dual stream of education in the general concept of the United Nations charter and a recognition of the right of parents to choose. Indeed, as the decades went on, they achieved a great unifying and a great healing. I pause to say that in a matter of a few short months the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, Senator Ryan, and the Hawke Labor Government have done great harm to the unifying of the dual system. No government, no Minister, could have done more to revive divisiveness, to revive bitterness, to pit Australian against Australian, than the present Minister and the present Labor Government.
—That is just rubbish.

—That is the tragedy of this situation. Let me spell this out, because some like Senator Cook might have short memories. I remind the Senate that for the first 20 years or more of the post war period, the Australian Labor Party was opposed to any direct aid at all to independent schools. It was only in the early 1970s that that policy changed. I myself had a great deal to do-
—And you fought and struggled to keep the Schools Commission Bill from being enacted. You opposed the Schools Commission Bill in this place.

—Senator Ryan can interject, but she will not alter the facts. Let me recite them because they are very important and the people of Australia are entitled to know them. I remind Senator Ryan that in the 1950s the Menzies Government brought in interest subsidies for capital privately raised in the Australian Capital Territory and was violently opposed by the Opposition even though the public servants-and public servants have long memories-who were forced to come to Canberra from Melbourne and other cities were denied the right of choice and were forced into greatly overcrowded schools. When governments of Liberal faith said 'Wouldn't it be reasonable to help the independent sector to build their schools and to give them freedom of choice?' there was violent opposition. In the 1950s and 1960s came the indirect aid-the science blocks and the library blocks. Again, there was very great resistance by the Labor Party, particularly by its militants, to any kind of support for independent schools. As the governments of Liberal faith moved on further towards direct per capita grants, it became absolutely necessary politically for the Labor Party to come in and to adopt direct per capita grants. The leads in giving assistance to the independent system and in creating and establishing the dual system were given by governments of Liberal faith. Senator Ryan has asked about the Whitlam era. I remember that there was a category 1 in the Whitlam era, devised so that some schools in the independent sector would get nothing. I think those who now look with a little deja vu at the situation might not wonder where the axe will fall.

SPEECH.PARA: I make it perfectly clear. I speak as one who was educated, and proudly so, in state schools-State primary schools and state high schools. I speak as one who has been very active in parents and citizens associations in state schools. I speak as one who would want to see the highest quality education that one can get in both state and independent schools. But whenever there is a Labor Party in office, there will be pressure from a sector within the Labor Party and from an enormously powerful sector in the militant teachers unions to weaken and destroy aid to independent schools. It is important to remember that the militant unions themselves, which support the Labor Government with enormous donations and bring great pressure to bear on it, aim to destroy all support for independent schools, not just to reduce it. That is the pressure that is constantly upon the Labor Party. It is true also that a number of members of the Labor Party, in the branches, the leagues, the conferences and, indeed, in the Caucus, would like to see no support for independent schools; they would like to see integration, as the Radford Committee has indicated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Make up your mind; you cannot have both.

—There is no need for me to make up my mind. The one problem of making up the mind is with the Minister and the Government, because the Minister speaks one thing and acts another thing. If the Government wanted divisiveness, it could not have done more. If it wanted unification, a healing process, a dual stream, the key situation was to have three main principles. They were, first, the principle of a direct per capita grant clearly established for every student. Also, so that every school could predict for next year with certainty that it could survive and grow, it was necessary to have a fixed percentage link between the cost of an average student at a state school and the grant itself. Also, there was a need to have a Schools Commission which, in its membership, would be balanced, so that it would have a balance of viewpoint between the independent sector and the government sector.

SPEECH.PARA: It is an outrage that one should directly and knowingly put on the Schools Commission people who are out to destroy the independent system. Any Ministers who have done that on their own personal responsibility must be flying a clear signal that they do not believe in a balance between the two streams at all and that they are willing to put in a white-anting system to destroy it. Why else would any Minister put on a commission people who, by their declaration, are out to destroy? Why else would they ignore the representatives of the parents? Why else would they ignore the broad cross section?

That is what the Minister has done. She threatened direct per captia grants. She has abolished the percentage link, and every school in Australia including the category 3 schools, to disadvantaged schools, now has the total uncertainty about what will happen next. It is no use the Minister trying a little fancy socialist propaganda by distributing some financial berley on the waters at this moment, making a Robin Hood gesture and sprinkling it in category 3, which she has done. That is no use, because the schools want to know not about this year but about next year, the year after, and the year after that. It is no use the Minister, in response to the massive public demonstrations-5,000 people in Sydney, and 3,000 people in Malvern Town Hall-saying, 'These are people from the rich schools; these are the people who do not know', because the facts are against her. The facts are that the parents, the teachers and the principals of the category 3 schools throughout Australia are saying to the Government; 'You are doing something wrong, something philosophically totally wrong. You are being divisive. You are setting up division between one category and another'. Every one of them is opposing it. The Central Committee of the Catholic Bishops of Australia has rejected the principle, step by step. At all levels of the independent system, the people have said that what the Government has done is wrong.

Let me test the very principle of the ugly and devisive concept of wealthy schools. There is an old fashioned belief in this community that people ought to have the right to choose. I commend that, because the Minister may want to ask the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) about this.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much would you subsidise a pensioner to choose Kings School?
—Order! The Minister is interjecting too much.

—I suggest that the Minister save her interjections for the meetings which she ought to be attending. Let me simply say that this community believes that people have a right to freedom of choice in a whole series of situations. If anyone is sick, the community says: 'If you believe that you ought to go to a private institution, a religious institution, a St Vincent's or a St Luke's, if you believe that the surgeon there with the scalpel in his hand and the prayer in his mind has something that you would want which others do not, go there and we will give exactly the same per capita grant to that hospital as we give to the public hospitals'. If one is considering a nursing home and one wants, in one's older years, to spend one's time there, not in a secular situation but with religion there, with a belief in the spirituality of the circumstance, the Government and the public say: 'You ought to be able to get the same grant, rich or poor, with no means test wherever you go. If it is child care, or orphanage, or whatever, the test is simply this: You want your choice, and a service is provided. We will give the same and we will not apply any test. We will not say, and it would be wrong to say it, that we think that St Vincent's Hospital is wealthy and ought not to get the money'.

SPEECH.PARA: Why do we not impose this test? It is a nonsense test. The per capita grant is the same for every hospital. It is the same for every nursing home. It is the same for the institutions. But the only time that it is deviated from is on education, and the Labor Party is retreating from it. So we have a completely ugly situation. The Labor Party will not only do that but it will also make darned sure that there will not be the growth of new schools in the independent sector which will allow freedom of choice.

This philosophy of the Labor Party is utterly ugly. Over the years the Liberals have said: 'We believe that there should be equality of opportunity. We believe that everybody, however poor, however disadvantaged, should lift upwards and be helped upwards. Whether a person is bright, average or disadvantaged, we should beckon people on because we believe that one should develop the personality, the talents and the dignity of people, allowing them to do their best and allowing the brightest to help to develop a community to help the others'. But what is the Labor Party talking about? We have heard phrases such as 'equality of outcome'. What an ugly phrase that is. It is a socialist phrase of destruction and of levelling downwards. How can people have any concept of the individual when they want to level down rather than beckon upwards?

In all of the Labor Party policies there is a divisive note running through them, a splitting of the public. The independent system has been protesting against this because it has spent three decades unifying. But where in the Labor Party's policies is it talking other than quantitatively? Where is it talking qualitatively? Where have we heard talk of quality of education? Not a bit of it . 'Equality of outcome'-an ugly destructive situation if ever there was one. Nothing could be more ugly in its concept, and nothing more stifling of a community than that. Equality of opportunity, beckoning onwards, beckoning upwards and saying to people 'Do the very best you can' is a great thing.

How is it that in this community our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is willing to associate himself with the pursuit of excellence in everything other than education? If the America's Cup can add to his glory, he is there to put in his cheers. If somebody runs fast or if somebody plays Australian rules or rugby league well, he is there to enshrine the best and to pursue excellence and elitism. In education the Government is out to destroy. The way Government members talk about wealthy schools is outrageous in error. The way they attempt to destroy excellence is terrifying.

I know most of the schools that they call wealthy. Many of them that they call wealthy have been built up in bricks and mortar by benefactors, by donations, by capital contributions of parents over the decades, and indeed over the centuries . There is no way one can look at those resources and say: 'We are going to isolate them'. If we look at the measure, in some schools the principals and the parents choose to have more teachers and smaller classes. In others they have more physical resources. That is their right of choice. But fundamentally the Minister falls down again when she says: 'Our aim throughout the whole of education is to give to the needy. That is what we will do. We will take from level one and give to levels two and three'.

But when asked why the Government does not apply that money in the same way when it gives it to the government schools, she retreats by saying: 'But we do. We do it for disadvantaged schools'. She knows and everybody knows that that is nonsense, that the great bulk of that money that is given, the direct per capita grants go to all the government schools. She knows very well that the Karmel targets showed-I was proud when Minister for Education to be associated with this-that the targets set for the years 1980-81 were surpassed in government schools two or three years ahead in the whole of Australia. I was immensely proud that we could put resouces into government schools to lift them up. She knows also that when that happened the resources in most of the non-government schools were still at 70 per cent, trailing behind. Yet the Government goes on in its divisive way, pretending that more money is given to independent schools than to government shcools. It pretends because it is unwilling to add together the totality of the money from the Commonwealth and the money from the States. It uses the fact that the Commonwealth has set the pace in having a dual stream over the years and therefore is carrying a greater burden than the States in the independent sector. It uses that to suggest that in Australia more money is going to non-government schools. This is outrageously wrong and ought to be rejected out of hand. But wherever there is a corruption of a principle in education, the Australian Labor Party will surely do it.

In fact, it is retreating now under the pressure of huge amounts of finance that come from the teachers unions. Let nobody believe that they have no influence. I have it on the authority of the Labor Party members on the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform that the pressure of money of that magnitude does bring about influence. The Hansard records are full of it. It was said from their mouths that the pressure of giving money can influence their normal objective judgment.

What we have at the moment is a system. Honourable senators on this side of the chamber know that the unifying journey from indirect grants with Archbishop Eris O'Brien, a man of great name in his time, for libraries, for science blocks, for direct grants, to pick up the non-government training colleges and helping them has been undertaken by governments of the Liberal faith. We are able to say that in our time the state school system had been so supplied with resources at Federal and State levels that the schools reached targets years faster than the non-government schools. Nobody attempts to classify government schools in terms of category one or category two. Everybody is proud when we can produce a first class resource unit in a government school. I for one would be the greatest advocate of it.

What the Government has done is to take something that was precious, sensitive and delicate-the development of a dual system over a period of two to three decades-and to set about being divisive. To the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs who now giggles, let me say that what I have just said has been said by all the Catholic Bishops. They have said that what the Government is doing is aiming at divisiveness. The parents have said that the Government is creating divisiveness. The parents have said that the Government is creating a sectarianism that had died down, and a division between one sector and another. Indeed, all that the Minister's response can be is pathetic giggling. We had done something in Australia to unite all Australians. Let us not have any nonsense talk about rich schools and poor schools. The simple fact is that we do not do that with hospitals, nursing homes or any other institution. We accept the right of the parents.

I heard a horrible phrase, I think from Senator Zakharov, who said that she and Senator Macklin agreed on the principle-I hope I am not misquoting her-that parents are not always the best judges of what is best for their children. My goodness, Brezhnev or Andropov may well say that. The day that this society believes that the family is not the deciding unit, that the family does not have the right to decide what it shall do and what the parents shall do, is the day that democracy and good solid principles, as we know them, disappear. To say in this chamber that parents do not know best is to corrupt our principles.

The only societies that I know of which hold that view are the collective societies of Russia and the socialist states. To say that many of these independent institutions do very little education and a great deal of indoctrination is not only grossly insulting but also utterly wrong.

What right has anyone in this place to decide what quantity of spirituality or spiritual intake anybody in this community shall have. Those who are quick to refer to United Nations treaties in respect of the Tasmanian dam or sex discrimination should now look at the very heart of the human being, because the declaration on human rights gets to the heart of it. It states that the individual and the individual family are the matters that we should cherish. The right of individuals to choose for their children not only their education but also their spiritual and temporal development is profound and should not be contaminated. I never believed that I would come into the Senate and hear someone say that parents do not know best and that there is too much indoctrination. This is an outrage. I for one want to say that I uphold the right of every school registered in this country to increase to whatever limit it wishes the degree of spiritual training.

I will now put into perspective what this is all about. In the 1890s in this country, and until then, education was done voluntarily by private schools. Then governments made decisions which forced consecutive decisions. Governments said: 'We will compel all children to go to school and we will compel them to go to school for a certain period of years and to follow certain curricula'. Those governments decided that to make sure everyone was compelled to attend schooling those who could not afford private schools would have government schools education available to them. But all they regulated was the age to which students must go to school and the basic curriculum to be followed. No other compulsion applied. All other aspects were open to freedom of choice. Indeed, governments then started raising taxes for education purposes. If, in fact, in accordance with what Senator Harradine read out of the newspaper, Senator Ryan's view is that there is no right for those who pay taxes generally in the same way as anyone else to some benefit for independent education of their children, I reject that view out of hand. The compulsion applies to age of leaving school and curriculum. Taxes are raised to help education. They are not raised to help government schools. When did anybody evolve that kind of concept? Taxes are raised to be applied for the purpose of education. Do we apply divisive measures to universities and colleges. How extraordinary is the situation that in post- secondary education all fees have been abolished and no means test at all is applied but now, down further in the education system, divisiveness is being reinforced.

I rose because I wanted to say what a tragedy it is that this community is now being divided. Spokesmen for the key groups in this society are saying that; and they regret what is happening. The responsibility for that development lies squarely on the Minister's head and lies also on the Hawke Government because a unifying and a healing process was going on. I reject the ugly philosophy that has been espoused here. The equality of outcome is the ugliest philosophy of all : Parents do not know best. That is a very ugly philosophy. This Government has attacked institutions through the claim that they are guilty of indoctrination. How could any member of a labour or socialist cause inveigh against doctrination . If there is a doctrinaire philosophy and if there is an indoctrination of the minds of people, how further is the step to socialism? Yet, the philosophy is: It is right to indoctrinate when we believe in it: It is wrong to indoctrinate for the freedom of others! Parents do not know best!

If indeed it is right for us to allow a surgeon, with a prayer in his mind, to operate when we are sick, if it is right for us to choose a nursing home when we are old, if it is right for access to orphanages and other institutions to be gained without means tests and without any division at all, how much more right ought it not to be for people to choose the type of education that they want for their children. That is what we should aim at. What we should be hearing about today is how we can get the best education for both state schools and independent schools; how we can get quality into education; how we can look to the primary and secondary schools where many students feel that education is not for them and there is no concern for them and where they are not getting pastoral care. We need to build into that system freedom of choice for parents in the government system between one government school and another. We need to build parent councils into government schools in the States as in the Australian Capital Territory. We need to do all those things. But, above all else, we need to recognise one fact: Throughout Australia today, many parents are concerned that the quality of education that their children are getting is not good enough . They want the right of choice whether it be between government school and government school or government school and independent school. We will serve this nation well if our policies unify and not divide.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I rise to close the debate. In doing so, I will address some of the points of information or of factual confusion which were raised during the debate. I will not address the rhetoric because I feel we have heard a great deal of it over the last few weeks. Really, there is no substance to much of what has been said. However, on those points which were factual points, I will attempt to give some information.

SPEECH.PARA: When speaking on the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill, Senator Peter Baume questioned the $10m participation money. He asked what use would be made of that money and how that program would work. I inform him and the Senate that the report on that aspect will be tabled in the Senate shortly-next week, I expect. It will demonstrate that there will be increased participation in the numbers involved in tertiary education in 1984 even though, of course, the year after year reduction of Federal funding for the tertiary sector under the previous Government has made it difficult, in one Budget, to turn that situation around and increase numbers. However, numbers will be increased.

Of course, in the special extra participation program, the Government is supporting better access to higher education by a wide range of groups, a wider range of groups than is represented at this stage in tertiary education. It is a fact, of course, that the previous Government, on this access point, made no adequate provision for higher education in the outer metropolitan areas of Sydney and Melbourne. Under the participation initiative, the Macarthur and the Nepean colleges of advanced education in Sydney and Footscray Institute of Technology and La Trobe University in Melbourne will benefit and thus provide increased access in areas of very high need.

Senator Peter Baume raised the question of standards. That question has been raised by other speakers as well. He seems to think that, by providing opportunities for people from a disadvantaged background to get into higher education, there will be an inevitable drop in higher education and an inevitable drop in standards. I assure him that that is not the case. That matter will be addressed in the participation report that I will be tabling next week. It is certainly not the intention of the Government, while increasing participation, to take any steps that would lower standards. In fact, it would defeat our whole purpose. Our whole purpose is to increasing equity, that is to give people who have previously not had the opportunity the access to and the benefits of higher education. If those benefits were to be eroded through a loss of standards, of course, the action would be self-defeating. The Universities Council and the Advanced Education Council is well aware of this. Although in some cases universities may develop courses to assist people who have had a disadvantaged educational background to get to the level where they can competently undertake higher educational courses and succeed in them, this will mean a raising of standards for that individual and not an overall reduction of standards.

Senator Peter Baume also questioned the statement in our Budget statement that, in the participation program, the average cost of each student would be about $3 ,300. That is, of course, much lower than the existing average cost per student. But Senator Peter Baume will be aware that the existing averaging cost per student covers all faculties. It is an average of the cost in all faculties including very expensive faculties such as medicine and veterinary science. He will be aware, I think, from his experience as Minister for Education, that the cost in areas such as commerce and business studies are lower. The Tertiary Education Council has advised that more than $10m will be needed to maintain intakes in later years.

I stress, of course, that this Government recognises that, if our increased participation is successful this year, there will be flow-on costs. There will be flow-on recurrent costs because the number of students will be higher and there will be flow-on capital costs because more facilities will be needed. We accept that and we will be addressing that in subsequent Budgets. Of course, as I pointed out, we are faced with the enormous task of having to turn around the situation which the previous Government prevailed over for many years of reduction after reduction, year after year, in funds available to tertiary education. We have not been able to do that completely in our first Budget. We have made a start. Of course, it is our intention to continue in subsequent Budgets.

I should point out too, in terms of our commitment to growth in this sector, that we have restored retrospective cost supplementation in place of the previous Government's unsatisfactory prospective allowance system with all the uncertainty in planning that that entailed. As Senator Zakharov pointed out, this step is being widely-I would say universally-accepted in the higher education sector.

The matter of the tertiary education assistance scheme allowance was raised by Senator Baume and other speakers. I point out that the allowance for students receiving TEAS has been increased for 1984 by more than the national wage case increase. It is true, of course, that the rate for unemployment benefit is still much higher. This Government, faced with a $9.5 billion deficit, had to make some very hard choices. We made the choice that a significant increase in unemployment benefit particularly for the young unemployed who had received no increases for many years just had to be a higher priority than a very substantial increase in TEAS allowances in our first Budget. However, we did increase the allowance by more than the national wage case rise and we are continuing with our commitment to further increases in the TEAS allowance in subsequent years.

Senator Baume said that the TEAS means test had declined in real terms. In fact , the Government adjusted the means test upwards according to the best estimate we had available to us at Budget time of the likely increase in average wages. It is a fact that average wages did rise by about half a percent more than the estimate we had available to us at the time; so it is true that there is a half a per cent gap. Nonetheless, it was a genuine attempt to make a full adjustment. To be perfectly clear about what that means, it does not mean there is any ceiling on the numbers of people who can qualify for TEAS. Anyone who can qualify under the adjusted means test will receive it. As many people who qualify will receive the allowance; so it is wrong to argue from the level of increase in the means test that there is some sort of ceiling on the numbers of students who are eligible for TEAS. Eligibility, where it is achieved, will result in the allowance being paid.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is marginally less because the MAFI has not gone out enough.

—It is half a per cent less than average earnings. The record of the present Opposition when in government on adjusting the means test is a very sad one. Over the period 1977 to 1983 increases in average weekly earnings exceeded increases in the TEAS means test by a massive 50 per cent. Yet Senator Baume, of course, has the hide now to criticise us because we are half a per cent behind.

SPEECH.PARA: Criticisms have been made of the Government's decision to reduce by 25 per cent the $9 a week grant to residential colleges. This decision is one that we made in the light of cost pressures and the economic difficulties we inherited, and the savings did help to establish more broadly based initiatives such as the participation and equity program available in the higher education area. I point out that the total subsidy is worth $9 a week per student while the fees range around $75 a week. The 25 per cent cut amounts to $2.25 a week, which is a very minor reduction. It is not a decision we were happy about having to make, but I should point out there is no needs based assessment of students who get the benefit of this subsidy. Indeed it is my view that the majority of really low income students are not living in residential colleges. Nonetheless, we have announced a review of the accommodation needs of students and I should point out that at this stage only those students who are in residential accommodation do get any subsidy for their accommodation needs, even though many other students need it. We expect that as a result of this review we will have a more equitable way of distributing the funds that are available to assist students who need accommodation. The particular needs of country students and of students attending regional colleges are being addressed in this review.

The debate on schools was for some speakers at least a very heated debate the likes of which we have heard a great deal in recent times, although other speakers made constructive contributions. I simply remind the Senate of the facts with regard to school funding. They are that most schools in the non- government sector received increased funding and of course there was increased funding for the government school sector. Again, there was the restoration of the retrospective cost supplementation, a very important element in enabling schools to plan for their future. We introduced the participation and equity program which will benefit children in a range of schools, government and non- government, although it will be targeted in the first instance to those schools which have low participation rates, be they in the government or non-government sector. We expect that the changes to and regeneration of secondary curriculum which will come about, partly stimulated by this program, will benefit all students in all schools.

I must condemn entirely the kinds of attacks that have been made on government schools and particularly on teachers in government schools during this debate. It is extremely unfortunate that in a society where 75 per cent of children are educated in government schools, and I presume about that number will continue to be, honourable senators take it upon themselves to condemn in the most outrageous terms the activities of the people who teach in those schools. It is not the view of this Government that every industrial action by every teacher union in this country is something that can be supported; of course it is not. On the other hand, the dedication, the commitment, the creativity and the caring approach of government school teachers throughout this country are things that I think we should all acknowledge and things which I as a parent am very happy to acknowledge. It is most unfortunate that the parents of those 75 per cent of children, who have chosen either because of their philosophy or because of their economic circumstances to have government schooling for their children, have to be subjected to these tirades against the people who teach in these schools.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition did not attack teachers.
—Who did that, Minister?

—I refer honourable senators who are now questioning this to the remarks of Senator Baume, who never seems to speak on the subject of education without attacking the teachers in government schools. I just refer honourable senators to Hansard, where they can see an ongoing attack particularly by the Opposition spokesperson on education, Senator Baume, on teachers in government schools.

SPEECH.PARA: The question of the pursuit of excellence has been raised. I and the Government have been accused of wishing to destroy excellence in schools, of not wishing to see children raise their standards or raise their aspirations and performance. Of course this is an absolute contradiction of the real situation. What we do resile from is the idea that excellence is something that is applicable only to a very few students, only to certain kinds of schools or to certain kinds of subjects. It is the view of this Government that excellence-that is, the highest possible standard of achievement-is an aim applicable in all schools, for all children, whatever their natural capacity may be, and in all subjects. Every child can increase his or her level of performance to what is, for that child, a high standard. Every subject ought to be taught, although I know it is not, at a very high level of intellectual demand and challenge. It is false and distorting to accuse this Government, which is concerned with allowing all children and all schools to raise their standards, of wanting to destroy excellence.

Senator Baume has made much of what he claims are 123,000 students in group 1 schools who will receive less in 1984 than under the previous percentage link policy. Of course it is the case that schools in group 1 will receive less-I acknowledge that-because it is the policy of this Government to engage in some redistribution. Under our policies, over 540,000 students in group 3 schools will receive higher grants than under the old percentage link, higher by a total of $5m in 1984. If any honourable senators are under the impression that that extra funding is unwelcome or not needed in group 3 schools, I suggest that they spend more time visiting these schools particularly in the less affluent areas. They will find that the increases are not only greatly needed but also very warmly acknowledged. I have no doubt that they will be put to very good use.

Of course we have heard again in the debate this evening, mainly from Senator Sir John Carrick, accusations that we are provoking sectarian hostility. Again I can only say that I find this kind of accusation personally offensive as well as deeply offensive to the Government in which I am a Minister. Everybody in this place knows that the way in which decisions were taken to redistribute funds in the non-government area had nothing to do with the religious affiliations of those schools; it had everything to do with the private income available to them . It was an objective formula; I have described it many times in the Senate and all honourable senators will have received copies of it. They will know that those decisions, whether they like them or not, had nothing to do with religious affiliation.

It is also very offensive and a rather contradictory allegation, but one I have also received, to say that I am concerned only to assist poorer Catholic schools . I certainly am very concerned to assist them, but I and the Government are equally concerned to assist all of the needier schools. I should point out that group 3 schools are not all Catholic schools, that non-Catholic schools represent about 10 per cent of the schools in the category 3 area, and that 10 per cent covers a wide range of denominations. So again, although I say this with some pessimism because I expect that at least some honourable senators opposite believe that it is in their political interest to keep on saying this, our concern is with the level of resources available in the schools and not with making judgments about the religious affiliations of the people who have organised these schools.

The facts about the 41 schools that received a reduction of 25 per cent in their Commonwealth recurrent grants still seem to be ignored or rejected by some Opposition speakers, so I will simply list them again. Of course we are not being broadcast but it is something that I think parents are still having kept from them by some opponents of our policies. The facts are that the 41 schools will still receive in 1984 basic recurrent grants; that is, they will still receive $270 per primary student and $428 per secondary student, which is a total of over $13m in recurrent grants to the 41 schools alone. I should point out that that contrasts somewhat unfavourably with the $5m available to the disadvantaged schools in the non-government sector. Some of the proponents, and by no means not all of the parents or teachers associated with those schools, have said: 'Well, we don't care. It is not enough'. They have said: 'The sum of $13m is not enough. Despite the economic situation and despite the existence of many schools which have inadequate resources, we just want more. We just want more than half a million dollars for our school'. Well, it may be that they want it: It is the case that our Government has decided in the present economic circumstances with the present inequalities that prevail in Australian education systems that we were not prepared to give more than $14m in recurrent grants to those 41 schools.

If we look at those schools, we see that Knox Grammar School in Sydney, for example, is getting half a million dollars in recurrent grants alone. Now Senator Peter Baume and Senator Sir John Carrick will immediately say: 'Oh well, it is not a wealthy school'. I wonder how many people whose children attend category 3 schools have even been into schools such as that, have ever been able to make for themselves an assessment of what those schools have to offer the students and whether they do indeed justify receiving more than half a million dollars in recurrent grants alone, whereas some little convent school out in Marrickville will probably get something like $150,000 in recurrent grants. While that situation prevails it is a situation we are going to change. The Opposition can shout and claim that this is somehow an erosion of choice to give only half a million dollars to Knox Grammar. I do not think it is and I do not think that most of the parents whose children attend category 3 schools, especially the poorer category 3 schools, would really think, once the facts were presented to them and once they had an opportunity to look around a school such as that, that it was an erosion of anybody's democratic rights that Knox Grammar got only half a million dollars instead of the three-quarters of a million dollars or whatever it says it wants. But these are judgments that every citizen will have to make for himself or herself. The Government has made its decision, and that decision is as reflected in these Bills.

I will pass quickly to the contribution of Senator Macklin, which was extremely constructive and I think very thoughtful and very intelligent. In fact I would say it was the most intelligent contribution to the debate because he did acknowledge that there are complexities. He did acknowledge that a slogan like ' freedom of choice' does not cover and does not of itself guide a government in how to distribute money equitably, or it does not necessarily guide parents in how to make the best education choices for their children. Nobody denies freedom of choice, and this Government has done and will do more than any preceding conservative Government to entrench the rights of individuals through the human rights package that the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) is preparing and so on. But simply to say 'freedom of choice' is not the end of the argument. Decisions still have to be made about how the education budget is to be spread about. I did appreciate very much the contribution of Senator Macklin.

Senator Harradine made a constructive contribution to the debate tonight and raised some points which I think are entitled to a response. Senator Harradine raised, as he has done several times, the question of the rights of taxpayers. He quoted a report, which was a truncated report but nonetheless a report, of part of a speech of mine, in which I said that being a taxpayer of itself does not bring automatic rights to automatic levels of grants. I would just like to expand on that view. I think it is the only logical and reasonable view that one can have. All people in this society with incomes over a certain level are required to pay taxes. Because of that they have a general right to a whole range of services within our community. But one cannot argue that that gives them a specific right to a specific amount of money for a specific purpose, because conversely we have to consider the position of people who do not pay taxes, such as the pensioner parents who pay no taxes. Are their children to be denied the right to education? Of course not. The right to education comes from being a child in our society, not whether one's parents pay taxes or not.

TALK.START.PARA: —I disagree with you.

—Is the honourable senator saying that a pensioner's child has no right to education because the pensioner does not pay taxes? Is he saying that the childless taxpayer should get a rebate because his or her taxes are not being spent on education? Is he saying that the pacifist should get a rebate because he or she does not want his or her taxes spent on military weapons? That is not the way the taxation system works. Every child in this society has a right, acknowledged by this Government and funded by this Government, to education, but the level of taxes that one pays, or whether one pays taxes or not, is not what confirms that right. Being born into this society, in the view of this Government, gives one a right to education. One's parents have the right of choice as to where that education is carried out and we subsidise that choice to the extent that the Budget permits it and according to our philosophy of needs.

SPEECH.PARA: I am informed, Mr Deputy President, that there are some procedural matters that need to be addressed before the Senate adjourns, so I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

The House of Representatives desires the reconsideration by the Senate of the Bill in respect of the amendment disagreed to.
