PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Gareth Evans) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This bill gives effect to the undertaking by the Government to establish a Prices Surveillance Authority. This body is an important part of the Government's prices and incomes policy and its establishment will honour a major commitment by the Government as part of the prices and incomes accord. The Government's mandate to establish the Prices Surveillance Authority has been widely recognised in the community, including by business in the National Economic Summit Conference communique.

SPEECH.PARA: Following the National Economic Summit Conference a working party was established to provide advice to the Government on the legislation for the establishment of a prices surveillance body. I seek leave to incorporate the remainder of the speech in Hansard.
Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The working party, comprising representatives of the trade union movement, business, state and local government and community groups has been extensively consulted by the Government in drafting the Bill I bring before the Senate. Before explaining the measures provided for in the Bill, I would like to make some remarks concerning the Government's approach to prices surveillance. I seek leave to incorporate the remainder of the speech in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The Government is firmly committed to restoring economic prosperity in Australia and to bringing about the sustained high rates of economic growth that are necessary to reduce present high levels of unemployment. At the same time inflationary pressures need to be reduced so that economic recovery can proceed unhindered. The Government's policies, based on an effective prices and incomes policy, are directed toward achieving these goals of sustained non-inflationary economic growth.

Substantial portions of the Government's prices and incomes policy are now in place. Establishment of the Prices Surveillance Authority will help to complete the implementation of this policy and will encourage price restraint as a counterpart to the wage restraint being exercised by wage and salary earners under the wage fixation principles established by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.

I draw the attention of honourable senators to the title of this Bill, which indicates that the scheme embodied in the Bill is one of price surveillance, not price control. The Prices Surveillance Authority will monitor and examine prices . It will not attempt to hold down prices by administrative fiat. The Government is well aware that the private sector employs the majority of workers in Australia and that it must play a central part in any broadly based economic recovery. We recognise also that sound profits are an essential requirement for increased employment in the private sector. The approach of this Bill reflects these concerns. The best form of price restraint comes from the effective operation of competitive market forces. The majority of businesses in Australia operate in competitive market environments, and the effectiveness of the constraints that this imposes on prices is illustrated by the very low profitability that has applied over the past eighteen months.

An increase in profitability from last year's historically low level will be a necessary part of any broadly based recovery. Prices surveillance will not be used to impede such a development. Recognising this need, the approach to price surveillance envisaged in this Bill is selective. The Bill establishes a broad framework for surveillance of prices set by corporations and public authorities, but the selection of goods and services subjected to surveillance will focus on areas where effective competitive disciplines are not present and where price or wage decisions have pervasive effects throughout the economy. Generally, both conditions will have to be met before a body is made subject to surveillance.

As a result, the great majority of Australian businesses will not be subject to surveillance. In deciding which industries or bodies need to be covered the Treasurer will consult with the Authority which, in turn, will liaise with the Trade Practices Commission as appropriate. This will be one of the first tasks of the new authority. Initially, the new Authority will undertake surveillance of wholesale petroleum product prices which is presently carried out by the Petroleum Products Pricing Authority. The latter Authority will be abolished by the present Bill. In addition major Commonwealth public authorities will where appropriate be subject to surveillance. We intend that Telecom Australia and Australia Post will be brought under surveillance from an early stage in respect of their principal charges, subject to suitable directions to the Authority regarding the matters to which it should give special consideration when examining those charges.

The Bill does not apply to State authorities. However, as pricing guidelines are developed for application by the Authority, particularly in relation to public sector prices, we will consult with the States on the desirability of major State authorities observing similar guidelines. The Government intends that other Commonwealth authorities that are not directly subject to surveillance should also apply those guidelines where appropriate to their own pricing or price regulatary decisions.

As with the present Petroleum Products Pricing Act and the former Prices Justification Act, there are no penalties in the Bill for failure to comply with the Authority's findings. Penalties attach only to failure by declared organisations to observe the required procedures for the notification of price increases or for the provision of information and evidence, or in relation to the freezing of prices during inquiries.

The Government expects that bodies subject to the Authority will abide by its decisions. While compliance will be voluntary, consistent with the consensus approach on which the prices and incomes policy is based, the force of public opinion and companies' recognition of their public responsibilities will be powerful factors ensuring compliance with the findings of the Authority, as past experience here and overseas indicates.

The Government does not wish to inhibit normal business operations. Every effort has been made to keep the costs of surveillance to business to a minimum. The Bill itself, which affects the rights and interests of individuals, is of necessity somewhat detailed. But our intention is, as far as possible, to keep the procedures simple, speedy and non-legalistic.

Turning to the main features of the Bill, its broad thrust is, as I have indicated, to provide a capacity for price surveillance and inquiry which will be exercised selectively and with an emphasis on reducing as far as possible the amount of legalism in procedures.

Thus, whilst the ambit of the Bill includes the supply of any goods or services by foreign, trading and financial corporations and Commonwealth authorities, referred to as 'persons' in the Bill, the notification procedures will apply only to those goods or services and those persons that have been declared under section 21. Declared persons supplying goods or services will be required to give prior notice of a price increase and to wait a statutory period before implementing the increase.

The authority will normally have 21 days to examine a proposed increase, although this period may be extended with the consent of the notifying person. Where the authority objects to a proposed increase it will be able to suggest a lower increase to the person concerned or, where necessary, recommend an inquiry .

Whilst the notification procedures will apply only to declared persons, the Authority will be able to inquire into prices charged by any person subject to the Act and will be able to conduct general price inquiries not necessarily tied to the justification of prices charged by a particular supplier. Inquiries, however, will only be held at the direction of the Treasurer or with his approval.

The Treasurer will also determine limits for the duration of inquiries, which will generally be no longer than three months, and he will be able to direct the Authority regarding the conduct of inquiries and matters to be taken into consideration.

Where an inquiry relates to the supply of goods and services by particular persons, prices charged by those persons will be frozen during the course of an inquiry, subject to a provision empowering the authority to grant interim price increases.
Reports on inquiries will be made public, as also will the outcomes of price notices dealt with outside of inquiries.

Selection of areas and persons to be brought under price surveillance will be by the Minister, or by the Authority subject to the approval of the Minister. The Bill does not stipulate criteria for selecting goods and services or persons for surveillance. I have already made clear, however, the principles on which that selection will be made.
The Bill incorporates legislative guidelines which require the Authority, in exercising its powers and performing its functions, to have particular regard to the following matters:
(A) the need to maintain investment and employment including the influence of profitability on investment and employment;
(B) the need to discourage a person who is in a position substantially to influence a market for goods or services from taking advantage of that power in setting prices; and
(C) the need to discourage cost increases arising from increases in wages and changes in conditions of employment inconsistent with principles established by relevant Industrial Tribunals.

These guidelines will ensure that the Authority's approach to price surveillance both conforms to and supports the Government's broad economic strategy. They are subject to any additional directions that the Minister may give to the Authority under Section 20.

The overwhelming majority of unions have undertaken to comply with the new wage indexation guidelines by undertaking to make no extra claims during the currency of the wage system. We are heartened by this development. However there is also a need for a comparable supportive mechanism on the employers' side. Section 17 (3) (C), which I have just quoted, provides this by requiring the Authority to have particular regard to the need to discourage cost increases arising from settlements that are inconsistent with principles established by relevant Industrial Tribunals.

This approach thus places an obligation on business to comply with the wages side of the prices and incomes accord which matches the commitments already given by the overwhelming majority of unions. The Government recognises that, where a company has clearly and strongly resisted attempts at breaching the wage system, it should not be subject to a second possible penalty and in these circumstances it is not intended that the Authority would disallow cost increases. If necessary, where it is clear that a company has taken all reasonable steps to resist a breach, a ministerial direction under Section 20 will be issued to the Authority that the resulting cost increases should not be disallowed. But where a company has not so resisted, or has offered wage or other increases to suit its own purposes in disregard of the national economic interest, it cannot expect that the costs involved will be accepted by the Authority as justification for price increases.

As I have already indicated, the legislative guidelines under Section 17 (3) are supported in the Bill by a provision (Section 20) for ministerial directions to be given to the Authority. This will ensure that the operations of the Authority remain within the framework of Government policy, including Government policies on pricing by Commonwealth authorities.

This provision will also allow, upon ministerial direction, the Authority to have particular regard to other matters which may be of special concern, such as the use of non-market transfer pricing, if there were indications that these were being used to circumvent the intentions of the prices and incomes policy.

The Authority will consist of a Chairman and three other members who may be appointed on either a full time or a part time basis. Whilst the members will not be representative of particular interests, it is intended that one of the members will have a background in the trade union movement and another in business. The Bill provides for the appointment of associate members for the duration of particular inquiries. This will enable the authority to be assisted where necessary by persons who have special expertise in areas subject to inquiry.

The Authority's secretariat will be located in Canberra but, as a transitional arrangement, staff of the Petroleum Products Pricing Authority, whose operations will be subsumed by the new authority, will remain in Melbourne as a branch of the Authority. The Bill provides for repeal of the Petroleum Products Pricing Act and for transfer of the records of the Petroleum Products Pricing Authority and the former Prices Justification Tribunal to the new Authority. Provision is made in the Bill to protect information and documents provided to the Prices Surveillance Authority.

Establishment of the Authority will add only marginally to Budget Outlays in 1983-84 but its operations are estimated to cost around $1.5 million in a full year. This estimate is based on the proposed coverage of major Commonwealth authorities and assumes some increase in surveillance in the private sector beyond the present surveillance of oil company prices by the Petroleum Products Pricing Authority.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Bill (on motion by Senator Chaney) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Restriction of Standing Orders-Safety Provisions in Australian Uranium Industry- Wilfred Burchett-Absence of Ministers from Chamber

PROCTEXT.PARA: Restriction of Standing Orders-Safety Provisions in Australian Uranium Industry- Wilfred Burchett-Absence of Ministers from Chamber

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7.30 p.m. I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to a matter on the adjournment debate which more properly would have been addressed yesterday when papers were presented. The annual report of the Supervising Scientist for the Alligator Rivers Region which dealt with radiation safety standards in the Northern Territory was not able to be discussed and debated in this place because of the custom we have whereby a set time is laid down for discussion of papers. The Government can reasonably judge that a paper will not be dealt with on the day it is presented by the position in which it is placed on the list of papers for that day. Additionally, since a motion to adjourn the debate on the paper was carried debate was effectively stifled and the matter was placed on the Notice Paper until it comes forward for debate. This in effect, whether intentionally or unintentionally, amounts to a situation in which debate on the paper was not possible yesterday and it will not be possible in the indefinite future. Standing Orders prevent me from making any further reference to the paper, which is regrettable because it reveals that what has been suspected in the past is now clearly apparent. There is a serious breach in the safety provisions of Australia's uranium mines. There is probably some awareness of this, although a subdued one, on the part of the scientists who make these reports and who, reading between the lines of this report, are eloquent in the problem.

SPEECH.PARA: In order to clarify some certain obscure matters which occur in that report and which include incidents at Ranger in which people were exposed to overdoses of radiation as a result of-(Quorum formed) I reiterate that I am dissatisfied with the system by which we deal with reports in this place which effectively censures discussion on at least half the papers that are presented every day. I want to draw attention further, in view of the fact that I was not able to discuss the report on radiation safety standards of the Supervising Scientist, to a document that has come into my hands. I refer to a letter from Mr D. T. Woods, the General Manager, Operations, of Ranger Uranium Mines Pty Ltd to the Director, Mines Division, Department of Mines and Energy, Minerals House, The Esplanade, Darwin-that is the Northern Territory Government. This internal house document elucidates quite clearly one of the incidents. I feel it is in the public interest that it should be made public and I seek leave to incorporate it in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
The Director,Mines Division,Department of Mines and Energy,Minerals House,The Esplanade,Darwin, N.T.
Dear Sir,
RE: JOHN B INHALATION OF YELLOWCAKE DUST
John B is an employee of Ranger Uranium Mines Pty Ltd who was involved in an incident on 5 July 1982, in which a spill of product occurred in the ranger product packing facility.
As a result of this incident, it was evident that he and a workmate (Paul T) had both inhaled and ingested an unknown quantity of yellowcake dust.
Samples of urine and faeces were obtained from each of the two men and were analysed for Uranium.
The results of the analyses confirmed that some yellowcake had been ingested by both men, but indicated that Mr B had probably taken in considerably more than Mr T.
Whole body counts were performed on both men by Mr L. Kotler in the whole body monitor operated by the Australian Radiation Laboratory (A.R.L.) in Melbourne on 11 July 1982.
The results of this test were inconclusive to the degree that the lung burden for each man was below the detection limit available from the machine, (e.g. 43 mg of U238).

Further whole body counts were carried out on both men by Mr Kotler using the A .R.L. equipment and by Mr Parsons of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission (A. A.E.C.) at Lucas Heights on 9 and 10 November 1982 respectively.
In the meantime, improvements had been made in the A.R.L.'s technique to lower the detection limit.
In each case the lung burden carried by Mr T was below the limits of detection, but that of Mr B was descernible.

The A.A.E.C.'s measurements were, however, not inconsistent with the results of calculations made by our Radiation Safety staff using the other bioassay data and extrapolation from dust concentration measurements and estimates.

It was concluded that Mr B had received close to the authorised annual lung dose-equivalent specified in the 1980 Code of Practice for the Mining and Milling of Radioactive Ores. As Mr T's lung burden was too small to detect, testing was discontinued in his case.
Further whole body counts were carried out on Mr B at the A.R.L. on 2 February 1983 and at the A.A.E.C. on 3 February 1983.
Results obtained by the A.A.E.C. were on this occasion consistent with the results obtained by the A.R.L.
The results as communicated to us are as follows-
Australian Radiation Laboratory: 25 + 8 mg natural uranium
Australian Atomic Energy Commission: 25 + 18 mg natural uranium
(Note: That this represents Mr B's lung burden as at 2 and 3 February 1983).

Considerable interpretation of these results is required to estimate the original lung dose inflicted on Mr B. To do so assumptions must be made and I.C. R.P. philosophies and models must be accepted.
The attached internal reports by our Radiation Safety staff address this problem from two directions:
One approach uses the 1980 Code of Practice to estimate a lung dose-equivalent and the other uses I.C.R.P. 30 to estimate the Effective Dose-equivalent.
On the basis of calculations which follow the 1980 Code philosophy, Mr B's dose approximates to 78% of the relevant annual limit.

However, using the changed philosophy and models of I.C.R.P. 30 (which have not yet been implemented in the Northern Territory), the same dose would be approximately 4 times the relevant annual limit. However, the Effective Dose- equivalent is a committed dose for the 50 years following intake.
In making these estimations, assumptions have had to be made in regard to certain factors which are not well known.
One of these is the value attached to the AHAD which in the absence of better data is taken as 1um. In the circumstances of this incident, it is unlikely that the A.H.A.D. would be so small.
The other factor is the biological half-life of the deposit in the lung.
In this connection, it is planned to carry out further whole body counts on Mr B at intervals of 6 to 9 months.
The observed decrease in motivity (if any) will provide data relevant to the determination of a biological half-life.
With these comments, we commend to you the following internal company reports for your consideration:
1. Technical Report
Product Spill 5.7.82 involving Mr J. B and Mr P. T
Revised May 1983
O. S. Bowson
2. Addendum to Technical Report
Product Spill Incident
22 April 1983
Whole Body Counting of Mr J. B
Latest Estimates
O. S. Bowson
3. Medical Examination Records-J. B and P. T
If there are further developments pertaining to this incident, we will keep you informed.
Yours faithfully,D. T. Woods, General Manager Operations Encls.
EVENTS-PRODUCT BIN UNBLOCKING 5/7/82.
TIME

Packing of yellowcake commenced and the blockage was noticed immediately. The operator notified the foreman who then requested a fitter. Successful unblockings had been carried out previously and the usual method involved inserting a steel bar up into the spool and physically ''breaking-up'' the hardened product. This method requires that the spool piece be removed and and that the sliding gatevalve and the rotary valve below the cone of the product bin be opened. Refer Figure 1.1
Usually the gate valve is closed and slowly opened while the steel bar is inserted, but in this particular instance the gate valve was jammed about 75% open.

The fitter arrived and attempted to close the gate valve but he was unsuccessful . He then removed the bolts holding the spool piece in place but he did not remove the spool piece at A's request. This operation took approximately 10 minutes.

A, with B's assistance, commenced the unblocking operation. The spool piece was removed and no product was observed to fall out after its removal. A steel conduit was inserted and a very hard substance was encountered which could not be penetrated, even with repeated ''poking''. The conduit was withdrawn and the bin vibrator started. Nothing fell out of the product bin and this sequence was repeated several times until finally the blockage gave way and a steady stream of product fell from the bin. This poking and vibrating procedure was estimated to take about 5 minutes.

Product flow continued for approximately 5-6 minutes before A was able to replace the spool piece. The quantity of dust generated by this product flow was so great that both men lost sight of one another. It is believed that during this period the men actually removed their masks so that communications could be established. B reported that he lost his mask during this time and left the room instantly. A remained in the area until he had stopped the product flow. It took approximately 10 to 15 minutes before the dust had visibly settled.
Radiation Safety Section notified of incident. Radiation Safety sent A and B to shower and placed a security guard at product packing to prevent unauthorized access.
Both operators reported that they were sick and that they regurgitated substantial amounts of product whilst showering.
RANGER URANIUM MINES PTY LTD
(A Subsidiary of Energy Resources of Aust. Ltd.)Incorporated in N.S.W.
Ref: DIW:ABMCI:OT:0361:0361-1
Address reply to: General Manager-Operations Energy Resources of Australia C/ oRanger Uranium Mines JABIRU N.T. 5796
The DirectorMines Division,Department of Mines and Energy,Minerals House,The Esplanade,DARWIN N.T. 5794
Dear Sir,
I refer to your letter (Ref: 83/22) in connection with the B T incident.
I enclose an up-dated report and covering letter which had been prepared for you prior to receipt of your letter.
We are also in receipt of a similar letter from the Chief Medical Officer of the Department of Health who wishes to be informed on this.
The attached report covers most of the points raised in his letter also.
With reference to the particle size of the product to which B and T were exposed, we are unable to obtain the data from the period you suggest.
Unpulverised samples are not retained for more than 2 months. Samples retained for longer periods are all in the pulverised state and hence useless for determining particle size.
We have, however, sizing analysis for typical product which were made early in the history of production and we propose to carry out further tests on current or near current production.
This will give a better estimate that the assumption of 1mm.
With regard to emergency procedures, I draw your attention to the procedure presently employed for all non-routine work in the PDP area.
When a non-routine task becomes necessary, the preparation of works permits is initiated by the person responsible for initiating the work. This may be a mill supervisor or an engineering supervisor.
It is then passed on to the other supervisors involved in the work and to the Radiation Safety Officer, the Safety Officer if required, and Security.

The supervisor responsible for the workers involved nominates the workers by name and they are required to attach their signature. The Radiation Safety Officer specifies the precautions to be taken and the protective equipment to be used.
The permit is displayed in the area while the job is carried out and is cancelled at the end of the job.
An example of a typical permit is attached.
This procedure has effectively prevented the occurrence of unplanned exposures since its introduction some six weeks ago.
If further information comes to hand, it will be made available to you as soon as possible.
Yours faithfully,sgd D. T. Woods General Manager Operations Encls.

TALK.START.PARA: —The document is headed 'Inhalation of Yellowcake Dust'. I think this is one of the more important aspects which have not appeared in other material. It appears from information that we have received from the report and from this letter that no effort is being made to protect miners against what is recognised world wide as probably the most dangerous form of radiation to which they could be exposed. The report points out time and again that exposure to radioactive dust and its inhalation into the lungs is a regular occurrence but that monitoring and control is undertaken only in relation to gamma radiation. I wish to make this point to honourable senators because I think it is of immeasurable importance. Long range radiation which can penetrate even relatively large thicknesses of lead is, of course, gamma radiation. However, alpha radiation is much more dangerous in its effect although its range is very short. At this stage I would like to make an essential technical point by quoting from page 627 of volume 1 of the United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission's draft generic environment impact statement on April 1979. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The alpha-emitting isotopes of the U-238 decay series-
and U-238, of course, is uranium-
are generally weak gamma emitters and can contribute relatively little to external exposure.
The point continues:
However, when they-
that is, the alpha emitting isotopes-

enter the body and come directly into contact with living tissue, their alpha radiation will deliver substantial dose equivalents compared to that imparted by equal concentrations of beta/gamma emitters. Because these radionuclides are present in mill effluents, it is important to analyse the pathways by which they might become deposited in human beings . . . The two major pathways to be considered are inhalation of airborne material and ingestion of food contaminated with radionuclides.

The basic point appears to be that at Ranger we are assessing danger to people which is coming from the ingestion or the inhalation of radioactive dust by taking a body count of gamma radiation from the exterior. It seems that no effort is being made to protect, monitor and control the much more dangerous and insidious alpha radiation present in dust and its associated radon gas. The basic point is that we are allowing practices in our uranium mines that are almost certain to result in accelerated and possibly massive cancer rates among workers. As with the asbestos industry in Western Australia, this country will rue that day because in 20 or 30 years time somebody-presumably the Government- will have to pick up the tab for cancers caused by alpha emissions in the lungs of uranium miners just as we are paying $120,000 to each person in Western Australia who has contracted lung cancer as a result of asbestos emission. This problem is analogous; it is one of similar proportions.
The situation is being covered up by statements. The official paper refers to an accident that occurred earlier this year. It states:
Significant radiation exposure in excess of the regulatory limits occurred, but adverse effects as a result of the radiation dose are unlikely.

That is an actual quote from the paper. That is irresponsible and criminal rubbish. It is universally recognised in the rest of the world that alpha radiation presents a major risk and that large and unpredictable health hazards, mainly cancerous, exist for uranium miners if there is a failure to cope with that problem. This involves, among other things, absolute and total control of dust, that is, dust of any mineralised nature or any ore or substance among the known alpha emitters.

I believe that this is a matter the Government ought to look at more carefully; it is something that ought to be checked immediately. I understand that there is a committee of some kind somewhere looking into the question of radiation effects and means by which these could be improved. Until that happens I think it is an urgent matter that the Government impose in uranium mines in Australia much more stringent controls on dust and radon than it has done in the past. We will ignore this at our peril; the peril is not so much us in this chamber but to the health risk of the men actively engaged in this industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to mention a couple of matters. The first is that raised by Senator Mason. I noted his tender regard for the Standing Orders and I understood him to feel that he could not refer to the report of the Supervising Scientist which is an order of the day. That is probably a rather too tender regard but it is nice to see someone bending over backwards to respect the Standing Orders. I have read the material that he has had incorporated in Hansard and that he very kindly circulated to give us notice that he was going to seek to do so. I note the sort of point that he made out of it-that difficulties were experienced in July 1982- and I note that one of the letters he provided for me also includes information about the changes which have been made to meet the problem which arose in July 1982.

SPEECH.PARA: The only other point that I wanted to make with respect to that is that the uranium industry is unusual in that it is subject to a much greater degree of control and screening than is almost any other industry. I was intersted the other day to look at some statistics about fatalities in the coal industry. I found that in one year, in a limited number of countries, there were something over 1,600 deaths directly caused by coal mining. So one ought to take into account the fact that in the alternative energy sources with which we deal there are also significant hazards to life. I think that there would be an extraordinary public outcry if even a tenth of the actual deaths were occasioned in the mining of uranium that appear to be occasioned in the mining of coal.

At the same time, I do not wish to minimise the importance of the sort of care which is taken and I appreciate Senator Mason's major interest in the subject, but it is worth noting that the incident which he has mentioned and documented in the adjournment debate this evening has been the subject of not one but two detailed reports which have come to this Parliament and which are available to us for our perusal and examination. I think it also does demonstrate the extent to which there is public supervision and public disclosure of the difficulties of the industry. We have the Office of the Supervising Scientist. That was established by the previous Government pursuant to the recommendation of Mr Justic Fox. I think that even Senator Mason would agree that beyond question we have had these issues exposed to us very fully and fairly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not on the alpha radiation one. It is not even in the index of the report.

—I do not wish to show a less tender regard for the Standing Orders than has Senator Mason but I must say that in my examination of the report there does appear to be a clear expression of both concern and description of the problems which seems to be coincidental with the material that Senator Mason has put into Hansard tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: The only other point that I wish to mention relates to the slight display of irritation that I showed earlier in the adjournment debate and which caused in turn some irritation on the part of the Government Whip. As is is a serious matter I will refer it to the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) and get a considered reply if that is needed. He then said that he was going to maintain the dignity of silence.
—I did, I referred to Wilfred Burchett.
—I know that he was referring to Wilfred Burchett but he did not say what it was that he had said about him, so I will leave the matter until I have looked it up in Hansard.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 3 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister for Health seen an article in the British Government publication Survey of Current Affairs, Volume 13, Number 9, page 312 of September 1983 headed 'Asbestos', which reveals that the British Health and Safety Commission has decided that the import, manufacture, marketing and use of blue asbestos, and products containing it, should be prohibited and that brown asbestos should be similarly treated.

(2) Is the Minister also aware that the Commission recommended that control limits for asbestos that were introduced in January 1983, be further reduced from 0.5 fibre to 0.2 fibre per millilitre for brown asbestos and from 1 to 0.5 fibre per millilitre for white asbestos and with the possibility for further reductions in this limit in the future, and 0.2 fibre per millilitre for blue asbestos.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (3) Yes. The National Health and Medical Research Council Occupational Health Guide 'Threshold Limit Values' includes recommendations on control limits for occupational exposure to asbestos.

At its 96th session (October 1983), the Council endorsed a revision of the threshold limit values for asbestos which will reduce the recommended acceptable occupational exposure level for amosite (brown asbestos) from 1 to 0.1 fibre per millilitre, while leaving the limits for chrysotile (white asbestos) and crocidolite (blue asbestos) unchanged at 1 fibre per millilitre and 0.1 fibre per millilitre, respectively. This change is recommended to come into force on 1 July 1984.

The Council also recommended that importation to Australia of amosite be prohibited as from 1 July 1984. Prohibition of the importation of crocidolite was recommended by the Council in June 1981-'Report on the Health Hazards of Asbestos'.

The limits recommended by the Council are more stringent than those proposed in the United Kingdom for brown and blue asbestos. These types of asbestos are widely recognised as constituting a significantly greater health risk than white asbestos. While the limit recommended for white asbestos is higher than the UK, it compares favourably with other Western nations.
The recommendations proposed by the Council are not mandatory: their incorporation into appropriate legislation is a matter for consideration by the individual State and Territory governments.

Imports of sheepmeat from New Zealand over recent years have been:
In the first three months of 1983-84 844 tonnes of New Zealand sheepmeat have entered Australia. There were no imports in the same period last year.

These quantities are insignificant compared with the average Australian production of around 520,000 tonnes per year and it is not considered that they would have any significant impact on domestic prices.

Although statistics are not presently collected which would enable a breakdown of imports between lamb and mutton it would appear from the low unit value of imports that New Zealand has been shipping to Australia mainly mutton for manufacturing.

The Government is concerned at the depressed state of the lamb market. On the basis of information available it would seem that factors within the Australian industry are the primary cause of low prices. The decision of producers to retain large numbers of last season's lambs for fattening when the drought broke together with an earlier than usual turnoff of this season's lambs because of favourable seasonal conditions has resulted in an oversupply reaching the market .

In respect of the honourable senator's suggestion that the increase in imports is in some way attributable to the closer economic relations trade agreement with New Zealand, I would point out that the position of sheepmeat under the Agreement is no different to that which applied under the earlier Australia-New Zealand free trade agreement.

Finally, I would point out that the Government is aware of the concerns held by some Australian producers that possible increases in imports of New Zealand lamb may cause, or threaten to cause, injury to the Australian industry. In recognition of the sensitivity of the issue the New Zealand Meat Producers Board has given an assurance to the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation that lamb or beef will be exported to Australia only to meet genuine market shortages and they would discuss with the AMLC any future exports of lamb to this country before shipment is made.

Furthermore, the New Zealand High Commission has advised that prices of any lamb sold in Australia would not be supplemented by the New Zealand Government. In addition the Department of Primary Industry has set up a monitoring system with the Sheepmeat Council of Australia for imports of New Zealand sheepmeat.

Should the Australian industry feel that imports from New Zealand are causing, or threatening to cause, injury to the Australian industry, it is open to the industry to apply to the Department of Industry and Commerce seeking an anti- dumping investigation under the Customs Tariff (Anti-dumping) Act.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 November 1983, (Hansard, page 2487) Senator Macklin asked me a question without notice concerning safeguards inspections by the International Atomic Energy Agency.

QUESTION.PARA: I undertook to provide further details for the honourable senator's information .

The International Atomic Energy Agency IAEA, which is responsible for the application of international safeguards, reported that at the end of 1982 it had 132 inspectors and 854 facilities under safeguards.

Safeguards agreements provide the IAEA with the legal right to inspect facilities. Inspection frequency varies with a number of factors including type and amount of nuclear material and the type of facility. Thus a mixed oxide uranium/plutonium, fuel fabrication plant, or a reprocessing plant, which would handle large amounts of nuclear material, may well attract continuous inspection ; whereas a small research reactor involving a small amount of nuclear material may be subject to only one or two inspections annually.

The IAEA's working languages are English, French, Spanish and Russian. Plant operating records and reports to the Agency are kept in one of the Agency's working languages. The Agency runs intensive language classes for its inspectors in seven languages including the four working languages. Much of the language of safeguards is mathematics.

Non-proliferation treaty safeguards agreements provide that for routine inspections of facilities containing plutonium and highly enriched uranium a minimum of 24 hours' notice of inspection is required; for all other facilities a minimum of one week's notice of inspection is required. These agreements also provide that a portion of routine inspections may be carried out without advance notice. Additional special inspections may be carried out for purposes specified in those agreements.

NPT safeguards agreements provide for a country to reject a proposed inspector without giving a reason. The IAEA has advised that it has proposed, and Iraq has accepted, the designation of inspectors from France, Hungray, Switzerland and the Soviet Union.

Safeguards are a system of technical measures within the framework of international non-proliferation policy and rendered in international agreements negotiated between the IAEA as the international safeguarding authority and the member states in which the safeguards are to be applied. It is necessary for those agreements to be considered and approved by the Board of Governors of the Agency in order to ensure that the provisions of the agreements would enable fulfilment of the purposes of safeguards, namely:
To assure the international community that States are complying with their non- proliferation and other 'peaceful use' undertakings;
to detect and thereby deter;
the diversion of safeguarded nuclear material to the production of nuclear explosives or for other military purposes, and
the misuse of safeguards facilities with the aim of producing unsafeguarded nuclear material.
The Board of Governors also has a special statutory responsibility in respect of ensuring compliance with those arrangements.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Queensland Committee for International Year of Youth

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 9 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs aware that the recently formed Queensland Committee for International Year of Youth contains 15 members all of whom represent the Brisbane region; if so, will the Minister investigate ways in which the views of young people from regional areas can be represented on this committee, in view of the Government's commitment to decentralisation.
(2) Will the Minister consider either enlarging the committee to ensure representation from rural and provincial city areas or establishing satellite committees in regional areas.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The International Youth Year Planning Committee in Queensland has been established by the State Government in Queensland and its composition is therefore the responsibility of that Government.

From information provided by the Queensland representative on the National IYY Co-ordinating Committee, I understand that the Planning Committee comprises 26 members representative of a range of government and non-government sectors. I also understand that this Committee will be setting up sub-committees and an extensive network of regional committees to ensure that young people in country and outback areas can be included in the planning.
The national planning for IYY will be placing emphasis on the maximum involvement of young people, including those who are disadvantaged geographically or in other ways.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 9 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Defence aware of reports emanating from Lavarack Barracks in Townsville indicating that the dismantling of the North Queensland Army Band will commence next week when affected personnel are given leave to commence the transfer procedure.
(2) Does the operation negate the public announcement by the Minister on 2 November 1983, that 27 January 1984 would be the date of dismantling.

(3) Will the Minister request an immediate report on the situation; if so, and in view of the extensive resistance to this decision as evidenced by in excess of 15,000 petitioners and direct approaches from local government authorities, will the Minister undertake to review this decision in the light of the overall cost to the Federal Government of maintaining its military bands in capital cities and the Government's commitment to North Queensland which hosts 100 per cent of Australia's operational deployment force.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) No. The date for the disbandment of the North Queensland Band remains 27 January 1984.

(3) A report was requested and received from the Department of Defence Army Office. It stated that the North Queensland Band would be available to meet all its previously arranged public commitments until 27 January 1984. After that date, the Band's present function in North Queensland will be taken over by unit bands in the area, supplemented when necessary from Brisbane.

In order to do this, the Regimental Band of the 1st Battalion, the Royal Australian Regiment-1RAR will be built up forthwith to the level of competence of the North Queensland Army Band. A bandmaster will be provided and the total strength of the Band will be increased, as will the number of Band Corps members in it. The Pipe Band of the 2nd/4th Battalion, the Royal Australian Regiment is also to assist.

As 1RAR is part of the Australian Army Operational Deployment Force, it will be necessary for the 1RAR Band to exercise with its battalion from time to time away from Townsville. On such occasions the Band of the 1st Military District in Brisbane, or the 2/4 RAR Band, could be made available to assist in meeting important North Queensland engagements.
These arrangements should prove adequate to meet deserving requests for support .
